PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHARLES; CHILD; DUFFY; HAWKE; HOLDING; JENKINS; JONES; KENT; MILTON; THEOPHANOUS; WILLIS

PETITION.TITLE: Diabetics: Insulin
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Diabetics: Insulin
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in view of the recent standardisation of insulin and insulin syringes, having the effect of increasing the cost of both items to the Diabetic in general, and as every insulin-dependent Diabetic must use the same, daily or twice daily according to medication.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that syringes be made available on the NHS and that insulin prescriptions revert to 10 bottles as previously supplied.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles,Mrs Child,Mr Duffy,Mr Hawke,Mr Holding,Dr Jenkins,Mr Barry Jones,Mr Kent,Mr Milton,Dr Theophanous and Mr Willis.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans-Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans-Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in:
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child,Mrs Darling,Dr Everingham,Mr Mountford and Mr Wallis.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That many Australians will be financially disadvantaged by the health changes proposed by the Federal Government, expecially the withdrawal of Commonwealth medical benefits for the uninsured, and the introduction of a means test for free public hospital care;
That the health insurance changes promote inequity, inefficiency and lack of universal coverage;
That the public hospital system and community health programes will be financially disadvantaged by the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility and funding.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will take all steps necessary to reintroduce a system of health care based on ability to pay, and access to health care based on medical need.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Howe,Mr Les Johnson and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament Assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. Because of an anomaly in tax rates a single income family pays nearly $10 a week more tax than a dual income family earning the same total amount.
2. Family allowances established in 1976 have not been increased since then, yet over the same period living costs have increased by nearly 60 per cent.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that:
The Parliament should act-
1. To restore the lost value of family allowances and to index them for future price rises.
2. To increase the spouce rebates from $830 to $1,342 per year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hodgman and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament Assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is not fulfilling its responsibility in ensuring an adequate standard of living for all Australians, which is causing untold hardship on relief agencies' limited resources, and require the following steps to be taken as a matter or urgency:
1. That the Commonwealth Government raise the level of all pensions and benefits at least to the poverty line.
2. That the Commonwealth Government reconsider its recent decisions in relation to the health system and cuts to Commonwealth activity.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert further poverty and suffering in our community by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Shipton and Mr Street.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament Assembled. This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The proposal to introduce fees for higher and second degrees will mean that access to post-graduate and recurrent education will be limited to the rich; Australian research and ability to cope with technological change will suffer; this proposal must be seen as a step in the direction of the introduction of fees for all tertiary students.

2. The proposed introduction of a loans scheme for students will mean graduating with a heavy debt or being denied a tertiary education if loans are refused because a student is seen as a ''poor risk'' (particularly affecting women and those doing non-vocational courses); only the rich will be able to get a tertiary education without course restrictions and the burden of indebtedness.

3. In regard to the proposal to restrict eligibility for TEAS and the foreshadowing of reviewing TEAS levels only in the light of the availability of loans, it should be noted that any further downgrading of TEAS, which is already inadequate, can only further limit access to education.

4. The proposed restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance to those needing qualifications for employment will severely restrict access to a full high school education and necessary bridging education to tertiary education for those who left school early.

5. The proposal not to fund 30 Colleges of Advanced Education if they are not rationalised is an attack on teacher education. This attack will create teacher shortages in the mid 1980s, restrict access to education now and endanger the future quality of teaching available to Australian children.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(i) post-secondary tuition fees not be introduced for any courses or for any category of students.
(ii) that the TEAS scheme be extended so as to more fully meet the real financial needs of students.
(iii) that a comprehensive loans scheme not be introduced.
(iv) that there be no restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance.
(v) that the proposal not to fund 30 CAEs unless they are rationalised be rescinded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Shock Syndrome
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned by the threats to women's health and lives posed by Toxic Shock Syndrome, and urge the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:

(1) Tampons, sanitary napkins, vaginal deodorants and similar sanitary products to be re-classified under Therapeutic Agents (not under ''Cosmetics'' as at present), in order to bring them under the scrutiny of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. We believe manufacture must be under the strictest hygienic conditions.

(2) After re-classification, we urge an immediate government-funded inquiry into all aspects of manufacture and content of these products. This must lead to: (i) contents of product and instructions for correct usage to be shown on packaging; (ii) removal of synthetic fibres, chemicals or ingredients that are potentially or actually harmful to users.

(3) Allocation of extra funding for ongoing research by the National Health and Medical Research Council into these products, results of this research to be made public to ensure all health workers and potential users are fully informed. This campaign of public education would necessitate multilingual distribution of the information where appropriate.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert possible threats posed to women's health by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Institute of Early Childhood Development
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the Federal Government should reconsider the proposal to merge the Institute of Early Childhood Development with another tertiary institution.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Institute of Early Childhood Development be allowed to continue operating as an independent and autonomous institution providing specialised skills and unique training applicable to the development of children aged 0-6 years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That retired low and middle income superannuants are disadvantaged by:
(a) inflation
(b) double taxation
(c) low means test for the aged pension.
(2) That the age pension means test has not been increased since September 1972.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will increase the means test for all pensions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we strongly condemn any action taken by the Federal Government which will lead to the destruction of the Free Hospital and Medical Services of the State of Queensland.
And your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Parliament reject the proposed health cost sharing arrangements between the Commonwealth and the State governments and guarantee the maintenance of the present scheme whereby all Queenslanders who wish to avail themselves of these services may do so.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the pressure of cheap imports, the high cost of new homes and the effects of the credit squeeze are seriously weakening consumer demand for furniture.
That an increase in sales tax for furniture and mattresses would be a complete disaster for the furniture industry causing widespread bankruptcy and unemployment.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Government will not proceed with an increase on sales tax for furniture and mattresses.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That serious concern has been generated in the migrant community following the Government's endorsement of decisions of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Government Functions to:

Restrict the role of the Commonwealth in Adult Migrant and Refugee Education Program to the arrangement and co-ordination only of such programs and relinquish responsibility for the conduct of individual programs,
Terminate some and rationalise other information services provided by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs,
Terminate forthwith the migrant assisted passage scheme,
Transfer the translation/interpreting services to private agencies or withdrawn altogether,
Reduce hours of operation of the telephone interpreting service,
Discontinue production of the national groups directory,

Reduce overseas based staff associated with the recruitment and selection of persons for permanent settlement in Australia, which will result in greater delays in the processing of immigration applications.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government respect the needs of Australia's migrants and accordingly rescind these decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Social Security
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That concern has been generated by the Government's decision to cut back expenditure in the Department of Social Security as outlined in the report of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Government Functions, ie, by reducing the rate of expansion of regional offices of the Department of Social Security, confining social work activity to that relating to departmental functions, scaling down the Social Welfare Division of the Department.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will rescind these decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Post Office Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Government's decision to provide brochures and information on government programs at post offices around Australia highlights further the Government's excessive use of public money for its own propaganda machine;

That the listing of this decision by the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Government functions under the heading ''Post Offices as agents for Government activities'' strongly implies the use of Postal Officers as Government Servants, not Public Servants.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will not abuse its authority in this way and will reverse this decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Women's Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That womens refuges have provided on a 24 hour a day basis, emergency accommodation, child care, financial aid, moral support, legal advice and guidance in dealing with government departments for over 13,000 women and children in the past year, at a cost to the National Government substantially less than $4 million which is half the cost of holding the Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting in Australia later this year.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will not proceed with its stated intention to withdraw from funding women's refuges and pass this responsibility to ill-equipped and sometimes unsympathetic state Governments and will increase Federal funding levels for women's refuges.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Legal Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That serious concern has been generated in the Australian community following the announcement of the government's decision to :
Attempt to transfer responsibility for legal aid, presently provided by the Australia Legal Aid Office, to the States of New South Wales, Tasmania and the Government of the Northern Territory.
Abandon the new buildings for the Institute of Criminology and apply pressure to State Governments to contribute six-sevenths of all costs of the institute.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will rescind these regressive decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the list of the Australian Heritage Commission and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the Island.
3. That the Queensland Government has recently approved sand mining on Moreton Island against the advice of conservationists.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Federal Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products mined from Moreton Island.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That concern has been generated in the Australian community following the announcement of the Government's decisions to:
Not proceed with the establishment of a broadcasting information office.
Abolish the Australia Post courier service to reduce competition with private companies.
Maintain a postal express service for postal times only
Use private contractors for mail cartage.
Pave the way for delivery of mail by private companies by examining Australia Post's powers with the stated view to their reduction or elimination.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will rescind these regressive and provocative decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Day Care Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned express our concern over the sale of the Belconnen Mall and its likely detrimental effects on the provision of community facilities and community services in Belconnen.

In particular we seek assurances that the Occasional Care Centre and other services of the Belconnen Community Service including Family Day Care will be able to continue operating from the Mall and continue to receive the same real level of assistance and support in the future.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this petition be considered.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That funding in the area of childrens services, which has been reduced by almost 40% in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-76 Budget. And further, that annual budget allocations in the area of childrens services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other business expenses.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully requests that the Federal Government ensures that:

(a) The Federal Government honours its 1975 election promise to maintain Medibank-a free, universal health insurance scheme, and institute methods of improving hospital and health services for the Australian people.
(b) The Community Health Program remains a Federal Government responsibility, with increased funding and expansion of services.
(c) The means-testing and the re-introduction of charges at public hospitals will severely disadvantage low and middle income groups, and should be abandoned.
(d) Every effort be made by the Federal Government to ensure that the health care needs and demands of the Australian community are met.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled will give earnest consideration to this most vital matter.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Automotive Industry: Tariff Protection
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia being employed in the automotive products industry respectfully showeth:
1. That the automotive products industry is vital to the livelihood and well being of many thousands of Australian workers and their families.
2. That if imported automotive products are allowed to flow freely into the Australian market it will deprive over 100,000 workers in the industry of their work opportunities.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament recognise the rights of Australian workers in this industry and that proposals to reduce the level of protection in the future be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Roads Construction Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners believe that:
The decision to subject the National Roads Construction program to the tendering system will:
(a) Threaten the jobs of 790 workers employed in 17 main road depots in New South Wales;
(b) impair the day labour system and undermine the capacity of Departments of Main Roads to train staff and test road construction concepts;
(c) have a disruptive effect on the employment opportunities available in small communities;
(d) reduce the flexibility of the Department of Main Roads to handle emergencies caused by flood or fires;
(e) ultimately increase the cost of road construction at taxpayers' expense.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government withdraw this disruptive proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(a) Present income tax laws are unfair to single income families.
(b) All marriages should be recognized as partnerships by allowing partners to divide their joint income for tax purposes.
(c) The family, which is the natural and fundamental group unit of society, should be an economic unit in tax laws.
(d) Children are Australia's future and their individual care by a parent at home should not be discouraged by extra tax.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament will-
Reform income tax laws to allow the joint income of husband and wife to be equally divided between them for taxation purposes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medibank
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That many Australians will be financially disadvantaged by the health changes proposed by the Federal Government, especially the withdrawal of Commonwealth medical benefits for the uninsured, and the introduction of a means test for free public hospital care;
That the health insurance changes promote inequity, inefficiency and lack of universal coverage;
That the public hospital system and community health programmes will be financially disadvantaged by the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility and funding.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will take all steps necessary to reintroduce Medibank.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the Federal Government's decision to abolish the Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS). There is no other agency to give the support and care which the participants of the Community Youth Support Scheme require. Transitional Education schemes are suitable for only a small number of the unemployed.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament allocate the necessary funds to enable the continuation of the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South-west Tasmania: Wilderness Area
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament Assembled: This humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South-West Tasmania. This area is on the Register of the National Estate and therefore is of national concern.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South-West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of Disabled
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament Assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The failure of the Federal Government to seek information from the census re disabled people-i.e. partial or total disability-to enable for adequate planning of, and for, types of services needed by disabled people to be undertaken.

2. The failure of the Federal Government to lead the way in employment of disabled people by employing a greater number of such people within the Commonwealth Public Service-note the small number currently employed within the Service.

3. The wastage of the Federal Government funds perpetuating large, bureaucratic institutions and organisations where there are often few disabled people on their boards and little emphasis is placed on consumer participation in decision making.
4. The failure of the Federal Government to encourage independence of disabled people, or to develop 'normalised' support systems-attendant care.
5. The failure of the Federal Government to provide 'non-institutionalised' specialised accommodation for those people who would not be able to benefit from, or cope with attendant care.
6. Failure by the Federal Government to alter, or create a 'disability' allowance means test free for all disabled people-this would assist with necessary equipment and mobility costs.
7. Failure to provide a national compensation scheme thus saving time and enabling people to be automatically covered in the event of a disability.
8. Failure by the Federal Government to abolish tariffs on all equipment available to the disabled-e.g., Optacon.
9. Mismanagement of Federal I.Y.D.P. Funds-e.g., non-receipt by some States of funds through unresolved negotiations.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that immediate action be taken to remedy the above stated and that the Federal Government recognise that disabled people are citizens who should have equal rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament Assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern at the way in which children are now being used in the production of pornography, call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:
1. To prevent the sexual exploitation of children by way of photography for commercial purposes;
2. To penalise parents/guardians who knowingly allow their children to be used in the production of such pornographic or obscene material depicting children;
3. To make specifically illegal the importation, publication, distribution and sale of such pornographic child-abuse material in any form whatsoever such as magazines, novels, papers or films;

4. To take immediate police action to confiscate and destroy all child pornography in Australia and urgent appropriate legal action against all those involved or profiting from this sordid exploitation of children.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will protect all children and immediately prohibit pornographic child-abuse materials, publications or films.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth our gravest concern about the detrimental effects of the abolition of the Engineering School at Deakin University. We respectfully showeth that:

(1) The Engineering School at the Gordon Institute of Technology and now at Deakin University has been serving the Geelong region and Australia for the past 60 years. It would be the waste of a great service to the Australian public.
(2) The phasing out of Deakin University Engineering by not enrolling students in 1982 will greatly disadvantage students and lecturers via unemployment and curriculum difficulties.
(3) Geelong, being the largest industrial centre in Victoria outside Melbourne, will be disadvantaged industrially through the lack of locally trained engineers.
(4) Geelong students will have to put up with the inconvenience of travelling to other Victorian Education Centres for studies, as well as the expense of such a move.
(5) The Geelong community and small industries will be disadvantaged through the Deakin University research and consulting engineers (D.U.R.A.C.) not being able to function.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you reverse the decision to abolish the Engineering School at Deakin University immediately for Australia's and Geelong's sake.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Community College
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned members of the Community of South Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That despite Ministerial and Departmental assurances, decisions regarding the future of the Aboriginal Community College are being made without consultation with the Aboriginal community;

2. That the Minister's decision has the effect of either closing the College or placing it under the control of the Department of Further Education, a decision which goes against the expressed wishes of both the College and the wider Aboriginal community;
3. That the effect of such a move will be to remove effective control over the College out of the hands of the Aboriginal community and into the hands of a non-Aboriginal bureaucracy;

4. That the Minister has failed to recognize the real achievements of the College in the past nine years in spite of the handicaps of uncertain funding and poor facilities and has failed to take cognisance of the high regard which Aboriginal people have for their College;
5. That such a decision goes against the recommendations of the team who evaluated the College in 1980;
6. Moreover, that such a decision belies the expressed policy of the Australian Government, of self-management for Aboriginal people.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will:
(1) Consult fully with both the College community and the wider Aboriginal community before reaching any decision on the future of the College.
(2) Follow the expressed wishes of the Aboriginal community when making such a decision.
(3) Ensure that control over the College remains in the hands of the Aboriginal community.
(4) Make the policy of self-management for Aboriginal people a reality.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned members of the electorate of Dundas respectfully shows our concern regarding the proposed introduction of fees for post-graduate researchers in Universities and Colleges of Advanced Education, since it appears likely that this action will have a serious and detrimental effect on cultural, scientific and technical research and development within the Australian community.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Government will change the decision to introduce tuition fees for post-graduate study.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hyde Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House asserts that while foreign companies such as General Motors are welcome to seek profit in Australia they are not welcome to publish blatantly dishonest advertisements seeking to influence Australia's democratic process in favour of less competitive and more favoured positions for themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes with alarm that 350 cases of salmonella poisoning have been reported in Australia over the last month, including most regrettably the death of a seven-year-old child;

(2) condemns the failure of the Government to implement the recommendations of the National Health and Medical Research Council for a national code of food purity standards with legislative power to demand recall of dangerous products, and

(3) demands that the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs use his undoubted powers under section 62 of the Trade Practices Act to implement legislation immediately to minimise any similar outbreaks of such disease.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALES TAX: SEAT BELTS AND OTHER CAR SAFETY DEVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. I ask him, when answering it, to use the knowledge that he gained when he was Minister for Health. How can a responsible government impose a 17 1/2 per cent sales tax on seat belts and other car safety devices for children and adults, but not increase excise duty on alcoholic beverages and tobacco products?

—The question clearly relates to revenue matters in the last Budget. The honourable gentleman completely neglects to acknowledge the undoubted fact that already in this country extremely high levels of excise duty are imposed on alcohol and tobacco. His question implies that in some way, as a result of the Budget, the items that he mentioned are more heavily taxed than are beer or cigarettes. That is a palpable nonsense. The level of taxation through the excise on those items is already extremely heavy. Whenever there is a broadening of the taxation base, it is inevitable that taxation will apply to items in respect of which in isolation a case can be made for no taxation at all to be applied. Many components which make up the safety features of a motor vehicle are already subject to the general rate of taxation which has now been increased from 15 per cent to 17 1/2 per cent. In that respect the analogy with the seat belts is entirely relevant.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HOUSING COMMISSION OF NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs been drawn to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald on 24 August 1981 which states that Vietnamese and Aborigines will not be permitted to be tenants of proposed Housing Commission homes in the Menai area of New South Wales and that tenancies will be reserved for 'decent white Anglo-Saxon Australians'? Will the Minister refer this matter to the Commissioner for Community Relations, Mr Grassby, for appropriate action?
—I take a point of order. Surely the honourable member would have read the retraction the Sydney Morning Herald had to print the day after it printed that rather slanderous article.
—There is no point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was alarmed when the honourable member for Wentworth brought my attention to that item. I was no less alarmed by the so-called retraction because Mr Keane, the Labor member concerned, stated that, while he had said those words, he did not expect the media to take him seriously. He said that the remarks were meant to be ironical. I do not believe that any other member of parliament, State of Federal, has chosen to make light of a matter which recently has been the subject of some criticism from what one might call an uninformed right wing fringe in Australia. It does not help when a member of parliament, even in an ironical fashion, makes such remarks. It is not surprising that the Sydney Morning Herald reported the matter in the way it did.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not doubt that the Commissioner for Community Relations has looked into the matter. He certainly never hesitates to look into other utterances. Whether the remarks were made ironically or not, it is a matter of concern that they were made at all by a member of parliament. We all know how greatly enriched our society has been by the diverse flow of migration. I hope that in future other members will take an educative role--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. As the member for the area concerned, it is impossible for me to suffer this hypocrisy because the Liberal Party was organising against Housing Commission homes--
—The honourable member will resume his seat. There is no point of order.
—Because it thought that the Aboriginal people--
—I warn the honourable member for Hughes.
—Would be brought into that area.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I name the honourable member for Hughes.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr SINCLAIR New England-Leader of the House)-Mr Speaker, I move:
That the honourable member for Hughes be suspended from the service of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the motion be agreed to.

—Let me make some comments in the interests of harmony in the House. This is a most contentious matter. Mr Speaker, whilst you are entitled to say that the honourable member did not pay attention to your request, the matter raised presents some difficulty in his area. It is well known that the public interest in that area has been against any Housing Commission development. I ask that you give the honourable member a chance to withdraw on the basis of the circumstances which are associated with what you regard as some reflection on your authority.

—It is not a reflection on my authority; it is a reflection on the dignity of the House when a member continues to speak when I ask him to resume his seat. The honourable member for Hughes has an opportunity to use the forms of the House to make any statement he wishes to make in accordance with the forms of the House. He rose in his place and then continued to speak without the call, masquerading his remarks as a point of order.

—Without cavilling about the matter, the honourable member for Hughes is the Opposition Whip, a man who abides by the forms of this House. This matter has been raised because of the other political events happening in New South Wales. It has very little to do with what we would normally discuss in this House concerning Federal authority. In the circumstances, Mr Speaker, I think that unless we can get an intelligent appraisal of the underlying political situation--
—Isn't Grassby a Federal authority?
—The honourable member for Macarthur will remain silent.

—I am talking about matters in this House. Mr Speaker, the Opposition seeks your leniency and requests that the matter of the honourable member being named and removed from the House not be proceeded with.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I named the honourable gentleman was that I asked him to resume his seat. I warned him. Despite that warning, he continued. I had no hesitation then in naming him. If the honourable gentleman wishes to indicate to me that he will comply with the forms of the House and apologise to the House-not to me-I will withdraw the naming of the honourable gentleman.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the honourable member for Hughes be suspended from the service of the House.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hughes is suspended from the service of the House for 24 hours.

INTERJECT.PARA: The honourable member for Hughes thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
—Mr Speaker, the point which I had reached--

—Order! I ask the House to come to order. The House will not proceed with its business until I feel confident that the honourable member who has the call, in this case the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, can be heard. The Minister will draw his answer to a conclusion.

—Mr Speaker, the point I was making when the interruption occurred was simply that most members of parliament recognise the educative role they have when it comes to those people who do not have direct contact with migrants and who do not recognise the great and enriching contribution which migrants have made. I do not believe it is appropriate for the honourable member concerned, Mr Keane, as chairman of a committee on Aboriginal affairs and with migrants in his electorate, to make jokes on an occasion such as this. I trust that the Commissioner for Community Relations will look into the matter. I trust that the New South Wales authorities will make it clear that Housing Commission accommodation will be available to all, regardless of their ethnic origin.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In view of the serious charges made in the South Australian Parliament on Tuesday concerning the financial and business affairs of the Australian Consul-General in Los Angeles, the former Liberal Minister, John McLeay, can the Minister assure the Parliament that Mr McLeay fully informed him of all his business affairs before the appointment was made? If he did not do so, will he ask the Consul-General to step down until a corporate affairs inquiry is held, as Australia is already in enough trouble with its exports to America?
—I have no reason to believe that the Consul-General in Los Angeles should be asked to step down.

—I ask the Minister for Health whether changes in Federal health funding arrangements have been responsible for the cut in real terms in health spending in New South Wales as revealed in last night's State Budget.

—I am grateful to the honourable gentleman for his question because it gives me the chance to point out to the House and to the people, particularly those in New South Wales, that in fact a great fraud is being attempted in New South Wales by the State Government. In fact, the amount of money available to the State Government in relation to health services could rise by as much as $51m this year. I point out to the House and the people of New South Wales that that money can be spent as the State Government wishes. It has complete flexibility and autonomy in relation to the spending of that extra health revenue. I am conscious of the attempted fraud in New South Wales because, as the honourable member for Macarthur has pointed out on other occasions, there does seem to be a discrepancy in the funding which is going to various hospitals in that State. In the attempt at rationalisation of hospital beds there does seem to be an emphasis, as I mentioned earlier, on picking on hospitals in non-Labor electorates at the expense of hospitals which in terms of priority of attention should have come first. I guess some aspects of this can be understood when one takes into consideration the fact that the New South Wales Premier appointed a special adviser on health matters over the head of his own Minister for Health.
—Order! I remind the Minister that he must remain relevant to the question. The question concerns Budget funds, not the appointment by the Premier of New South Wales of any officer.

—I acknowlege that point, Mr Speaker. The point I intended to make was that the appointment of the special adviser to the Premier's Department was in relation to the funds which were to be made available for health services in New South Wales. I can understand the New South Wales Minister for Health being very upset about that appointment.

—I raise a point of order. Mr Speaker, this morning you have suspended from the chamber the Opposition Whip for disregarding your order. I ask you to apply a similar measure to the Minister for Health.
—I have asked the Minister to remain relevant to the question. He is attempting to explain the relevance but I do not see the relevance. I ask him to proceed with an answer to the question as asked.

—Let me sum up by saying that there is no substance in the statements by spokesmen for the New South Wales Government-whether they be attached to the Premier's Department or the Health Commission of New South Wales-that the health funds have been reduced. In fact, additional resources are available to that State as a result of the new health arrangements put in place by the Commonwealth.

—I wish to ask the Minister for Health a supplementary question arising from the answer just given. Is it a fact that his Government has altered the cost sharing arrangements in respect of health so that, whereas previously the Commonwealth was prepared to pay half the costs, on this occasion it has decided that New South Wales will have to accept a block grant? Is it not a fact that if the Commonwealth Government had honoured its commitments to New South Wales in accordance with previous arrangements New South Wales would have received $100m more in this financial year for health alone?

—The specific answer is that the Commonwealth's contributions are not being made available in block grants. They are part of the recurrent tax sharing arrangements. They are being specified for the health area but they are part of the general tax sharing arrangements. As I have pointed out to the House on a number of occasions, the basis for the funding is last year's expenditure, escalated by 10 per cent, minus a proportion of the increased revenue which will become available to the States resulting from the imposition of charges agreed to and put in place by the New South Wales Government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DONATIONS TO LIBERAL PARTY OF AUSTRALIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hyde Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to reports headlined 'P.M. warned no donations if tariffs cut'. Can he assure the House that in no way will the Government's decisions be influenced by such threats?

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! This morning the House is subject to considerable noise. I ask honourable members on Opposition benches to cease their constant interjections.

—I am not aware of the article and I did not read it this morning. I do not think any Government Minister sets out to read articles relating to donations to the party when making a decision on Government policy. I am quite sure that that is the case.
—Rubbish!

—Order! The Minister will resume his seat. This morning the noise is intolerable to the Parliament. I ask honourable members to maintain their dignity and thereby contribute to the dignity of the House. It is not necessary for loud noise to follow a statement of the kind the Minister has just made.

—I assure the House and particularly the honourable member for Moore that decisions made by the Government in relation to tariff items will be made in the national interest. The Government will not be dictated to by various interest groups.
—What about the Bowen report?
—Show us your receipt book.
—I indicate to the Leader of the Opposition and members on the Opposition benches that I do not propose to proceed with Question Time if it is constantly interrupted by loud noise.

—In conclusion, I think it is worth while pointing out that people support the Liberal and National Country parties because they represent private enterprise and stand very strongly against the socialists.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of a report in the Jerusalem Post of 19 to 25 July this year to the effect that the United Nations Secretary General, Dr Waldheim, is expected to release soon a report on a study by an expert panel which concludes that Israel can make nuclear weapons? Is he aware that the report apparently concludes that Israel may already have enough weapons-grade material to make several bombs comparable with the one dropped on Nagasaki in 1945 and that the Dimona reactor alone could have produced enough weapons-grade plutonium for 10 to 15 weapons? Is he aware that Israel has refused to ratify the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty and has refused to allow international inspection of its facilities, including inspection by the International Atomic Energy Agency? In view of the extraordinarily grave implications these circumstances create for the Middle East and, indeed, for international stability, can the Foreign Minister state whether the Government has undertaken or will undertake initiatives aimed at encouraging Israel to ratify the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty and allow appropriate international agency inspection of its nuclear facilities?

—I am not aware of the particular report to which the honourable gentleman has referred but, as is well known, Australia is a strong supporter of the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty and urges all countries to ratify it and observe its provisions. I agree that the spread of nuclear weapons, whether to Israel or any other country in the region, has grave implications for the future of peace in the Middle East. Australia would certainly urge all countries in the area to become signatories to the NPT.

—I ask the Treasurer why he and his Department have held until 1 January 1982 the levelling of the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on those items that have not previously been taxed, yet imposed on the night of 18 August an increase to 17 1/2 per cent on grain trucks, some mining vehicles, aircraft for private use and oils and greases which were not taxed previously, without any notice to people engaged in the purchase of these items. I ask whether he will allow that section which is asked to pay the 17 1/2 per cent sales tax to wait until 1 January 1982 before it is levied.
—I call the Treasurer.
—Mr Speaker, I also extend an invitation to honourable members of the Labor Opposition to attend the Birdsville races to allow them to cool down.
—The honourable member for Maranoa will resume his seat.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I think I have explained to the House on a couple of occasions, three categories of sales tax changes arise out of the Budget. The first category of sales tax changes involves an increase of 2 1/2 per cent in the three previous rates, the second batch of changes involves the removal of a series of anomalies and inconsistencies in the application of the sales tax law and the third category involves a broadening of the sales tax base to bring to sales tax for the first time a wide range of items. All these matters will be the subject of debate in this House later today. I simply say to the honourable gentleman that I have had some research carried out by the Australian Taxation Office as to the practice in these areas. I can assure him and the House that on every previous occasion-I refer in particular to 1967 and 1968 when a significant number of anomaly changes of a similar kind to the ones to which the honourable gentleman refers were undertaken-those changes were imposed with effect from the night of the announcement. It has been the long-standing practice when increases in rates occur for those increases to date from the time the increase is announced. That has been the invariable practice with increases in excise. It has been the invariable practice with variations in the rate of sales tax. Equally, if we are changing the sales tax law to bring to taxation for the first time items which are similar in character to other items that are subject to sales tax, it is not unreasonable that they also operate from the date of announcement.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the particular example to which the honourable gentleman referred, people who are at present not paying taxation on trucks used for the particular purposes, as I think the honourable gentleman will acknowledge, enjoy an advantage over people who have to pay the 17 1/2 per cent and have always had to pay it since tax has applied to those trucks which are used for other purposes. It is because of that inconsistency, that advantage-that privilege perhaps-that the Government decided to make the change. The methodology adopted has been the methodology adopted by successive governments and successive Treasurers of both political persuasions in announcing and implementing sales taxes and indirect tax changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the Treasurer's attention to an advertisement which has appeared in recent issues of the Australian Financial Review and in which Mr Peter Clyne invites readers to purchase six tape cassettes at a cost of $150: Such cassettes explain to people how they can dodge new laws on tax avoidance, how not to pay tax until 1995, how to cheat legally, et cetera. I ask the Treasurer whether he will approve of the Commissioner of Taxation acquiring a set of the cassettes so as to learn more of the ineffectiveness of the Government's tax avoidance measures and then to be in a better position to advise the Government on effective counter-measures. Alternatively, will the Treasurer agree to the commissioning of a taxation consultant to advise the Commissioner of Taxation as to the best means of ensuring that future legislation is effective so that it places an equal obligation on all Australians to pay a fair share of tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe the Commissioner of Taxation needs either my authority or my encouragement to obtain a copy of those tapes or, indeed, otherwise find out what advice Mr Clyne and others are giving in this area. I will make two other comments. Firstly, the Government has already-I think it is important that this is said in response to the honourable gentleman's question-sought the advice of people beyond the Australian Taxation Office in drafting tax avoidance legislation. In fact, the new section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act was the result of the combined efforts of the Taxation Office, the Commonwealth Atttorney-General's Department, two extremely competent and highly regarded private legal counsel who are expert in taxation matters as well as the Government's own taxation advisory committee which is chaired by the managing partner of one of the most reputable accounting firms in Australia and includes a number of lawyers and accountants who are highly regarded throughout Australia for their technical competence in the taxation area.

ANSWER.PARA: I am very pleased to say to the honourable member for Banks that in every respect his suggestion about the Commissioner of Taxation engaging people in the private sector who are expert in these matters has already been anticipated and taken up. I believe that the new taxation laws will be effective. That is a view which is shared very widely throughout legal and accounting circles. I believe the new section 260 or Part IVA will be effective. I share totally the view of the honourable member for Banks that it is desirable and in the interests of tax equity that the section be effective. That is why the Government went to such extraordinary pains to work out an effective section and why we consulted and engaged a wide variety of views, not just views within the Australian Taxation Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is it a fact that former world champion runner Herb Elliott faces dismissal by the Government from his job as chairman of the National Australia Day Committee as was widely reported in the Press this week? Is there any truth in the report that Mr Elliott's dismissal is connected with the selection of Professor Manning Clark as Australian of the Year and that Professor Clark was regarded by Liberal conservatives as an unsuitable choice? Is it a fact that the National Australia Day Committee does not even choose the Australian of the Year, nor does it have a representative on the panel which makes that selection? Has not the Government shown its confidence in Mr Elliott by recently reappointing him as a commissioner of the Australian Broadcasting Commission?

—I have seen the recent Press reports alleging that Herb Elliott was to be sacked as chairman of the National Australia Day Committee. The reports to which the honourable member refers are thoroughly mischievous, they are without foundation, there is no truth in them and I refute them utterly. The National Australia Day Committee was established some two years ago. Herb Elliott, who is a distinguished and great Australian, was appointed as its first chairman. He has served the Committee with distinction and his work on the Committee and the work of the Committee have encouraged a greater awareness about Australia's national day. The National Australia Day Committee comes under my ministerial responsibility. As a result, I have been in regular communication with Herb Elliott. Some time ago Herb Elliott drew to my attention the fact that he had recently been appointed as general manager of a sports store in Melbourne and that as a result of his new responsibilities he would not be able, following the expiration of his present appointment, to continue as chairman of the National Australia Day Committee. I was very disappointed to receive this information, but I accepted the situation. The Government has been most appreciative of the leadership that Herb Elliott has shown, and it is thoroughly mischievous of people to put about rumours to try to denigrate people such as Herb Elliott who have served their country well in many ways. I want to put on record the appreciation of the Government for the work Herb Elliott has done on that Committee.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I wonder whether the Minister will table this written reply to this question without notice.
—There is no point of order. I ask the honourable Minister to draw his answer to a conclusion.

—I make two points in conclusion. The first point is that the Australian of the Year is not selected by the National Australia Day Committee. That person is selected by a group of independent Australians representing a wide cross section of the community. Secondly, I say that the Government has demonstrated its confidence in Herb Elliott. He was recently appointed, as the member for Petrie mentioned in his question, as a member of the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

—Has the Acting Prime Minister's attention been drawn to reports that the Western Australian Government has given approval for the operation of segregated hotel bars to separate Aboriginal drinkers from white drinkers? Will the Acting Prime Minister have this report immediately investigated? In doing so, will he bear in mind that, if it is correct, segregation of this kind would be in serious breach of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and the Human Rights Commission Act 1981, both of this Parliament? If he does find these reports to be correct, will he take prompt action to terminate any such intended action, odious as it is on racial grounds, by the Western Australian Government and certainly before the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no knowledge at all of what the Leader of the Opposition has mentioned. If he provides me with information I will look at it to see what action needs to be taken.
—Here it is; I give you a copy.
—Is this all you have-a newspaper report?
—Well, it is from the Murdoch Press, your bible.

—Is the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs aware of suggestions by youth organisations in Victoria, reported in this morning's Press, that the decision to terminate the Community Youth Support Scheme should be deferred until next May? This would be to allow an evaluation of all existing job training and support programs to take place. Will the Minister seriously consider this suggestion? Is the Minister also aware of a proposal by the Victorian State Minister responsible for employment and youth matters, Mr Dixon, for the creation of a youth employment support scheme? Will the Minister examine this proposal to see whether it can be supported by the Commonwealth?

—I have seen the two suggestions to which the honourable member refers. I certainly will examine the suggestion made by the Victorian Minister to see whether it comes within the ambit of the Government's already declared position with regard to the assets of Community Youth Support Scheme projects, that is to say, that the Government would be prepared to donate those assets to local youth organisations which are approved for that purpose.
—Mr Speaker, it is interesting to hear this performance--
—The Minister will proceed with the answer.

—Yes, I will proceed with it, Mr Speaker, and say this: The decision having been made, it has been appropriate to put machinery in place to bring to the notice of both project officers and participants in the CYSS projects the wide range of activities which are available for the project officers and the participants to take part in. Consequently, machinery has already been put in place for all CYSS projects to be visited by officers of my Department, for interviews to be given to participants and to project officers so that there is no doubt whatsoever in the minds of all those people as to what our schemes are and how those people can take part in them. Furthermore, as a result of the visits to the CYSS projects and as a result of the discussions which will take place with the project officers and with the participants, those officers of my Department will report back to me on what the local needs are, what the local facilities are and how, if it is at all possible, the programs can be given a more extensive and wider application.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Firstly, has the Minister authorised the issuance this day of the publication Youth Affairs Newsletter of August 1981, No. 15? Secondly, I ask the Minister whether he agrees with the following statement contained at page 8 of this publication of his Department under the heading 'CYSS groups provide valuable experience for young people':

QUESTION.PARA: Young people in three Community Youth Support Schemes in Victoria are working their way towards full time and rewarding employment.

The schemes, in Echuca, Corio and Sherbrooke are giving young people valuable experience in a wide range of activities. For some of them the job search has been a demoralising experience but now they can find the support, plus job preparation and training from the Commonwealth Government sponsored CYSS projects.
I ask the Minister whether he also agrees with the following statement:
This diverse range of pre-employment programs for young unemployed people indicates the value of the project, which has the support of local service clubs and the community.
Government supporters interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirdly-I understand how disappointed Government supporters are at this question-does the Minister, having authorised this publication endorsing the value of the Community Youth Support Scheme projects--
—What is the question?

—It is coming. I am just waiting for the Minister to listen. Does the Minister, having issued this publication, agree that the decision of the Government contained in the Budget to abolish the CYSS projects represents the height of hypocrisy on the part of the Government of which he is a member?

—The honourable member for Wills thinks that he has made some great discovery. However, if he had been in the Parliament last night-he was not but he should have been-he would have heard me pointing positively on my own initiative to the fact that the publication was there and pointing on my own initiative to the fact that the Government has always maintained that there were some good CYSS projects. We have gone out of our way to make that point clear. The honourable member thinks he has made some great discovery whereas, in fact, the matter was raised on my own initiative. The difference between the Australian Labor Party and ourselves on this issue is that we have maintained that there have been some good CYSS projects but that across the board we can do much better for young unemployed people in this country through our training schemes and work experience programs. In contrast to that the Labor Party has done nothing but pour scorn on CYSS since the day it was born. The former spokesman for the Labor Party on this subject described it as tokenism. He described it as recycling.

—I raise a point of order. The Minister's answer should be relevant to the question. I asked specific questions about the authorisation of the publication and further specific questions. The Minister's answer is not relevant to the questions. Mr Speaker, there should be consistency in your rulings in this chamber.

—The essential part of the point of order of the honourable member for Wills is that he claims that the Minister is not answering the question he asked. The honourable member is not entitled to demand a particular answer. All he can require is that the answer be relevant. My judgment is that what the Minister has said so far is relevant to the question.
—Despite the attempts of the members of the Labor Party to parade themselves as great defenders of CYSS--
—Order! The Minister will answer the question and not engage in irrelevancies, such as contrasting the Government and the Labor Party.

—Yes. It was described, as I said, as recycling young people. I ask-this is relevant to the question-what project officers and local committees think when they know that the Labor Party described their functions as being a recycling of young people.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. What sort of double standards are you allowing in your ruling?
—You are allowing him to get away with murder.
—The honourable member for Wills will remain silent.
—When the House comes to order we will proceed.
—I will conclude by making two points. The first is--

—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. The Minister has cast a very bad reflection which amounts to a lie in regard to the relationship between Labor Party members and CYSS. I ask that he withdraw that. Most Labor Party members are actually chairmen or are involved in their CYSS programs and have supported those programs.

—The honourable member for Bourke will resume his seat. I remind the honourable member for Wills that in asking the question he concluded by asking the Minister whether the action taken by the Government amounted to hypocrisy. I allowed the question to go. But he must understand that if he includes in his question an allegation of the kind, then it must be expected that a Minister, in answering, will defend the Government against the allegation. I have so ruled. I indicate to the Minister that he has delivered a defence. It will be judged on its merits by the House or by anybody who hears it. I now ask him to deal with the question asked and to remain relevant to the specific points in the question. He may answer the question or he may not. But it is a matter for relevancy.

—The publication which the honourable member referred to and which I raised in the House last night, was, of course, a publication authorised by my Department. It makes the point that we have made consistently, that is, that there were some good CYSS projects. Across the board we can, and are, doing much better for young people through our training programs. When we put in place the machinery which I outlined this morning, all CYSS participants and all project officers will be informed of our programs and will be invited and encouraged to take part in them. May I say in conclusion, Mr Speaker-I ask you to let me say it in view of the attack that has been made by the honourable member on me and on the Government-that there is hypocrisy on the part of the Labor Party--
—No, I will not permit the honourable gentleman to proceed on that matter.
—I accept your ruling and conclude my answer Mr Speaker.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. That is the third time--

—Mr Speaker, I apologise for having demoted you. That is the third occasion on which the Minister has defied your ruling and has gone on and contradicted the ruling that you have given. The Opposition Whip has been suspended because he contravened, in your judgment, your ruling once. The Minister has done it three times. There is a double standard in this House.
—I move that further questions--

—The right honourable gentleman will resume his seat. The honourable member for Wills made an allegation which I do not appreciate. I will not proceed with it because my judgments will be on the record in Hansard. The honourable member for Hughes was suspended because he refused to obey the ruling of the Chair. He heard me. What must be understood is that on occasions when I ask a Minister to resume his seat, he cannot hear above the noise which is being made in the chamber.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Dr Klugman

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to General Business Notice No. 24 standing in my name which reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: That this House is of the opinion that the words hypocrisy and hypocritical, defined in the Concise Oxford Dictionary as simulation of virtue or goodness, are not unparliamentary.
Mr Speaker do I take it from what has happened this morning that you have accepted my notice of motion?

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot assume that. The way in which the honourable member for Wills phrased his question was not an allegation against a person; it was an allegation of hypocrisy by the Government in the broader sense. The Minister was about to use the word 'hyprocrisy' in a more direct sense and I stopped him from doing so.

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The Minister was asked to withdraw certain statements which he had made about Labor members. The statement he made last night referred to the Sherbrooke Community Youth Support Scheme group. That is in my electorate of La Trobe. I have very good relationships with the people in that group and I consider that the Minister's remarks are directed against me personally. I ask, Mr Speaker, that you ask the Minister to withdraw those remarks.
—The honourable member for La Trobe feels that the remarks were directed against him and feels offended by them. I ask the Minister to withdraw.
—I withdraw my remarks against the honourable member for La Trobe for the simple point that I said that Sherbrooke was one of the projects--
—The Minister will withdraw unqualifiedly.
—Yes, I withdraw.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF INDUSTRY AND COMMERCE: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS ON NOTICE

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for you, Mr Speaker.
—Is the Leader of the Opposition directing a question to me?
—Question Time has concluded.
—No. I would have put the question on notice had there been provision for a question to the Speaker to be put on notice.
—I see. The honourable gentleman is asking for detailed information about one of the parliamentary departments?
—No, I am asking you whether you will investigate what would appear to be an infringement of the right to information of honourable members of this Parliament.
—I give the Leader of the Opposition indulgence to proceed.

—I ask you, Mr Speaker, whether you will investigate an instruction which apparently has been issued by a member of the personal staff of the Minister for Industry and Commerce to that Minister's Department that officers of the Minister's Department must cut down on the amount of information provided in answers to questions on notice. I ask you to do so because it seems to me that it is an invitation to a serious infringement of the right to information of honourable members and a cynical abuse of the procedures of the Parliament. I ask you to investigate the circumstances in which the instruction was issued and to report on them to this House. Will you also consult the Minister, advise him of the impropriety of such an order and suggest that it be countermanded immediately?

—I indicate to the Leader of the Opposition that I will not investigate the matter. The reason for that is that the Speaker has no control whatsoever in relation to the content that a Minister chooses to put into an answer, except to ensure that it is parliamentary and it is relevant. The question that the Leader of the Opposition directs to me ought more properly be directed to the Minister himself. The Minister will have to answer for the instruction, if such an instruction exists, and be judged by the House on the answer.

—Mr Speaker, I seek your advice again. Could I have the matter considered by you in terms of a breach of privilege of the Parliament? It does seem to be a serious encroachment on the rights of members of the Parliament to information. The circumstances in which the instruction has been issued, I am assured, are clearly fabricated to indicate to members of the Department that they should try to conceal information which should be made freely available to members of this Parliament. In those circumstances there seems to be a breach of privilege. I ask you, Mr Speaker, to consider that.

—I indicate to the Leader of the Opposition that the practice in relation to matters of privilege which are raised is for me to receive information from the member raising the point of privilege and to consider the matter to see whether there is a prima facie breach of privilege. On what the honourable gentleman has so far said I could not reach the conclusion that there is a prima facie breach of privilege. However, it may be that the honourable gentleman possesses other information. I invite him, if he possesses such information, to put it before me in the House. I will then consider the matter as a breach of privilege.

—I do not have any more information than that. My source is quite reliable. However, it would seem that it is within your authority to require the provision of the details of the instruction which has been issued. In the circumstances in which the matter is raised and because of the seriousness with which members of this Parliament regard it, I would have thought that there would be some concern instead of hilarity about this issue on the Government side. It seeks to erode the standing of this institution even further. Mr Speaker, I think you should exercise your authority.

—The honourable gentleman is under a misapprehension. I do not have the power to investigate the matter in the sense that he seeks. I must first make a decision on the material before me as to whether there is a prima facie breach of privilege. If there is such a prima facie breach of privilege the matter will go to the House of Representatives Committee of Privileges and then that Committee may call for papers or witnesses. At this point I do not have enough material to find a prima facie breach of privilege.
—The honourable member for Barker has indicated to me that he wishes to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented.
—If the honourable gentleman wishes to proceed with a personal explanation he may do so.

—I refer to a report on page 32 of yesterday's Advertiser headed 'Sack Rodda over prawn control, ALP demands'. The article reports a debate in the South Australian Parliament where the Australian Labor Party Opposition moved a motion of no confidence in the State Minister of Fisheries, such motion being defeated on the floor of the House. In the course of the debate, as reported in the Advertiser, improper motives were attributed to me. The subject of the motion involved a move earlier this year by the Gulf of St Vincent prawn fishermen to force a closure of the neighbouring Investigator Strait prawn fishery. This move was based on the belief that the financial returns to the Gulf prawn fishermen would increase if the Investigator Strait prawn fishermen were thrown out of their own area.

SPEECH.PARA: The Gulf fishery is a State fishery whilst the Investigator Strait fishery is under Commonwealth control and is fished by some of my constituents. For many reasons I believed it was unfair to force a closure of the Investigator Strait fishery, thereby directly affecting the livelihood of fishermen in my area without any action being taken by the Gulf fishermen. During the debate in the South Australian parliament, Mr Keneally, an ALP State member, is reported to have alleged that my action was not based on a concern for my constituents but rather because a member of the Kangaroo Island community had made contributions to the Liberal Party of Australia. Such a suggestion is utterly false. I have no idea who from Kangaroo Island contributed to Liberal party funds.
