In fact, I conscientiously avoid having anything to do with the handling of party funds. The action I took on behalf of the island fishermen and their community was because I believed they were being unfairly treated, and the allegations of this poor little Keneally man are totally without foundation.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the report of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) on the social impact of uranium mining on the Aborigines of the Northern Territory-for the period 1 October 1981 to 31 March 1981-together with the text of a statement by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: -In speaking very quickly to the motion and the accompanying statement of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). I would like to draw the attention of the House to the importance of the Government having in the East Alligator Rivers region a monitoring team which is capable of working with Aboriginal communities and making ongoing reports and assessments, not merely to the Minister but also to the House, as to the impact of uranium mining and mining generally in that region on Aboriginal communities. The Minister's statement indicates a number of points on which he felt the report showed some very positive achievements. I had the benefit of being in this region for some three and a half weeks during the recess. I would like to pay a tribute to the people involved for and on behalf of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies for the work they are doing in the field. I was able to observe at first hand their relationship with the Aboriginal community and with the mining community. I believe they are fulfilling a very important job, under often very difficult and isolated circumstances, for Aboriginal residents in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of aspects, however, which I believe the report does not cover at this stage and which ought to be drawn to the attention of the House. Firstly, there is genuine concern amongst traditional Aboriginal owners and affected Aboriginal communities at the increasing pressure which is being placed on those communities by the various meetings being called in respect of the Pancontinental Mining Ltd project and the Koongarra project. Some Aboriginal leaders spend more time at meetings than the average parliamentarian. I think this is producing many problems for them and is placing them under considerable stress.

If one looks at the recommendations of the Fox report one sees that Fox was adamant that if mining were to continue in this region it ought to take place slowly and in a way which minimised disruption to the lives of traditional Aboriginal communities. If we look at the intensity at which these negotiations are proceeding, we will see clearly that the actual recommendations of the Fox report and the spirit of that report are not being honoured. I believe the Government and the Minister have a responsibility to see that, in considering the alternatives that are being put to them, the Aboriginal community in the east Alligator Rivers region has an opportunity to consider these matters in a traditional Aboriginal way and that it is not jammed, as it is at the moment, into making decisions.

Fox found also that traditional owners, if they had their choice, would choose to have no uranium mining at all, but he pointed out that they felt genuinely that they would be unable to prevent it. My observations in the region confirm that view. I think it is still their view. It is a matter of concern to me that the Minister says-I believe genuinely-that traditional owners do have an alternative, they do have a right to say that they will have no mining at all in the region. That is not the position as it is taking place on the ground. The negotiations that have taken place and the advice that has been given to traditional owners has been given in such a way that they do not believe, and they are not being told, that one of their very real options is a no mining option. I believe that if the Minister seeks the views of those who are living in the community and perhaps seeks a further interim report from the team from the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies he would find that the statements that I have made would be confirmed.

Grave problems are confronting Aboriginal communities for the future. Some of those problems have been highlighted by this report. There have been a number of developments in recent times, the most recent one being the leak at the Nabarlek mine which must give concern to the Government. Often all sorts of promises are made by mining companies, but when it comes to fulfilling those promises they are unable to do so. I think the report also notes, in fairness to Nabarlek, that certainly its promise to restrict the sale and supply of alcohol in the region has been honoured. From my observation that is very much the case. I believe that Nabarlek in this regard has made all attempts that could be made in order not to impinge upon the traditional life style of Aboriginal communities in the region.

One other matter that is worthy of comment is that the report highlights again that, although mining has taken place, very few employment opportunities are being offered to Aboriginal communities. That does not mean that the mining companies are not concerned to make those opportunities available; it is just that the nature of the work opportunities that are available cannot always be filled satisfactorily by Aboriginal people. However, it is interesting to note, as the Minister notes, that very real progress has been made by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service in its employment of Aboriginals. That is a very positive feature. I believe that Service and its Director are to be commended for the way in which they have involved Aboriginals, particularly younger Aboriginals, in training schemes which are giving them a very useful and positive role and satisfactory employment within their locality.

I believe one aspect of that ought to be drawn to the attention of the Government as a matter of some seriousness. This Government entered into contractural relations with the traditional owners when the Kakadu National Park was established. The Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service signed leases for and on behalf of the Commonwealth of Australia under which the Commonwealth undertook very substantial obligations. Not the least of those obligations-this is a matter of law-was that the Commonwealth would not employ anyone from the Northern Territory Service without the approval of the Northern Land Council and traditional owners.

The razor gang has recommended the handing over of the administration of the park to the Northern Territory Administration. That decision was taken in isolation. It was taken without any reference at all to the Northern Land Council or to the traditional owners. The Public Service Board is now endeavouring to implement those recommedations. The net effect of that is simply this: If the Public Service Board is allowed to proceed in that way it will mean that the Commonwealth is not honouring its contractual obligations under the lease and the undertakings that have been made and signed as a legal agreement by the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service are not being honoured. I think it is very important that when a senior public servant enters into legal arrangements with any group in the community the Commonwealth stand behind both the spirit and the letter of those agreements.

What is now occurring is that the Director of National Parks, having been made party to legally binding leases and the terms of those leases, is now being obliged, by Public Service Board decisions to evade obligations which were undertaken clearly and willingly for and on behalf of the Commonwealth. Such action is bad enough if it occurs in a normal commercial relationship but it is even worse when it occurs when we are dealing with traditional Aboriginal land owners. They are entitled to believe that the Government, its public servants and the Minister will honour contracts and leases which have been freely entered into for and on behalf of the Commonwealth. I thank the House for its courtesy.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Australian Delegation to the Inter-Parliamentary Union Conferences in 1980.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Inter-Parliamentary Union dates back to 1889. It is an international organisation based on national groups established in the 'parliaments' of the member countries, of which in October 1980 there were some eighty-nine. The headquarters of the Inter-Parliamentary Union are in Geneva. The membership includes most countries of the West and, wait for it, the Soviet Union and the Eastern Bloc, Japan, the Third World, and newly-emergent countries. The aims of the Union are the promotion of personal contact between members of all parliaments, the advancement of the work of international peace and co-operation and the strengthening of parliamentary institutions. Perhaps the best shorthand description of the Inter-Parliamentary Union is that it is the parliamentary counterpart of the United Nations. The United Nations is the world-wide organisation of governments and commands resources and world attention accordingly. The Inter-Parliamentary Union is the world-wide organisation of parliaments and parliamentarians and while less well known is a significant world body which should receive the interest and support of all honourable members of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, some people would dismiss the Inter-Parliamentary Union as largely a talk-fest. In fact, the Union is widely regarded as a significant forum for the exchange of views in a number of areas and particularly for the exchange of views and some meeting of minds on the central matter of East-West relations-that is, relations between the super-powers and the central issues of the strategic balance, arms control and disarmament negotiations. As one instance, it is a matter of record that the Inter-Parliamentary Union made a notable contribution, springing from a resolution of the 59th Conference in Paris in September 1971, to the formulation and acceptance by governments of the Helsinki Agreements to facilitate the rapprochement and co-operation between European countries with different political and economic systems. Many of the Inter-Parliamentary Union suggestions were included in the Helsinki Final Act which was adopted in 1975. The Inter-Parliamentary Union has been active in its implementation since then.

I stress that sort of achievement as a positive result springing from the wide and divergent memberships of this Inter-Parliamentary, so-called, Union. As I put it in my Foreword to the report, this is the counterpoise so to speak, to the difficulties for many of us in approaching this organisation from a Western standpoint where there is a measure of unreality and incongruity about an organisation of 'parliaments' which, as I have said, includes most of the countries of the Eastern Bloc. Indeed, it includes just about all of them with the sort of competition that has been going on in recent years to recruit new members to the organisation supportive of their particular ideological standpoint. With the new admissions at the Manila spring meeting this year the membership is now over 90 countries. There is something unreal or incongruous from a Western standpoint about an organisation of 'parliaments' which includes all the countries of the Eastern Bloc as well as other states where there is no multi-party parliamentary democracy as we know it. Perhaps about 30 countries would have a democratically elected parliament and government, as we know it.

It is still-indeed, all the more so-important for Australia to participate in providing general support for the Western presence since the Soviet Union exploits the organisation to the full as an instrument of foreign policy and for the dissemination of its propaganda. I further state in my foreword that the Inter-Parliamentary Union is also a context for the furtherance of the so-called North-South dialogue, Third World issues. I say 'so called' because the 'North' means the West and Japan and not the also relatively rich Soviet Union and its allies. In this context Australia as a rich but commodity exporting country, and thus having interests in common with both developed and developing countries, has a key role to play. I take this opportunity of identifying myself with and supporting unreservedly the initiatives of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) and the Government in the North-South context.

I add only this comment, Mr Speaker: The interrelationship of East-West and North-South issues is starkly brought out when the two are debated together, as at the 1980 Inter-Parliamentary Union meetings. The massive spending on arms stands in stark, sombre and dramatic contrast to the want and poverty of more than two-thirds of the world's population. The United Nations, the Inter-Parliamentary Union and, more recently and authoritatively, the Brandt Commission and other authorities join in urging a massive increase in assistance to developing countries on humanitarian grounds, yes, but of course and equally compelling, because it is in our long term political and economic self interest.

As well as the consideration of such major world issues, the Inter-Parliamentary Union also makes a continuing contribution in more specific areas. The most important of these is its work in pursuit of the human rights of parliamentarians, and I particularly commend to members that part of the report dealing with that issue, at page 78 of this present printing.

I report to the Parliament that at the East Berlin meeting last September, I was honoured, and the then and previous Australian delegations and Australia were honoured, by my election to the 10 man Executive Committee of the Inter-Parliamentary Union. I also became Chairman of the 'Ten-plus' group within the Union-that is, the 'west European and other' group, which effectively is the Western caucus within the IPU-for the 12 month period to the next conference in Havana. In that capacity I was gratified, with your support and concurrence, Mr Speaker, to extend an invitation to the representatives of the 'Ten-plus' countries to hold their meeting here in Canberra last April prior to this year's IPU spring meeting in Manila. The occasion was counted as a considerable success-with the effect, among others, that the 'Ten-plus' co-ordinated effectively and managed to secure the election of all its candidates for committee positions, including taking one position from the Eastern bloc.

I express my thanks to all members of the delegation for their work and support, and in particular the deputy leader, the honourable Charles Jones, the member for Newcastle. Notwithstanding our difference of political persuasion I venture to say that we made a pretty good team, and over the three years of our leadership of the Australian IPU delegation ably assisted--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the end of Charlie.
—Ably assisted by the various members of the delegations from time to time we made the Australian presence strongly felt.
—I think the honourable member for Newcastle insists on a withdrawal.

—Mr Speaker, I refuse. I hope you do not put it to the test. I particularly appreciated his support and advice in the matter of my election to the Executive and also the conduct of my duties as chairman of the 10-plus because that involved a great deal of head counting and tactical election know-how of which he has considerable experience, gained, I would say, in a rather rougher context than the IPU. On behalf of all members of the delegation, I also express our appreciation for the very high standard of advice and assistance received from Miss Sue Boyd, the adviser to the delegation, and Mr H. C. Nicholls, the secretary. Miss Boyd is about to leave the job with the IPU delegation to take up a posting in New York. We wish her well and every success in that role.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that I thank the Parliament for the privilege of serving as leader of the Inter-Parliamentary Union delegation during the thirty-first Parliament. My term as leader expired at the election last October and I wish my successor, my colleague the honourable Ian Robinson, an equally rewarding term of office as he takes over for the term of the present Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon C.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-At this point I congratulate the leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Edwards) on his election as the Australian representative on the executive on the Inter-Parliamentary Union. It is a position which I believe the country, not the person, holds; at the same time the honourable member for Berowra did a good job as the leader of the delegation in the conduct of affairs of the IPU over the last three years. I believe it bears out the point that I have been making, both in the Parliament when reports have been dealt with and in the executive of the IPU, that there has to be some form of continuity of representation, at the IPU, both from the Government and from the Opposition, it should not just be a hit and miss arrangement. We should do what a lot of other countries are doing: They have almost permanent delegates there who establish credibility to represent their countries. The honourable member for Berowra has very rightly drawn attention to the fact that the IPU is the second largest international organisation of its type and, as far as parliamentary representation is concerned, it is the largest organisation of its type. Representatives from different countries meet, talk, debate, argue and put forward different points of view concerning the issues confronting the world today.

SPEECH.PARA: No longer do the delegates regard the meetings as a jaunt. If they go they should go prepared and should put forward a certain point of view. The Australian delegation is probably unique in the sense that the honourable member for Berowra and other members from the Government represent their party and we represent the Opposition in this place and we put forward our point of view on certain issues. There is nothing more positive than the case of the resolutions regarding East Timor which I moved expressing my point of view and the point of view of the party of which I am a member. As a result of putting that point of view-it may sound a little strange-the decolonisation bloc put me on the drafting committee. I believe I was instrumental in stirring up the Portuguese delegation to the point of openly and positively supporting the argument for the right of independence and self determination of the people of East Timor. The Government had a contrary point of view. This is what astounded the delegates. I spoke and put forward a positive point of view for the decolonisation and the right of self determination. The representative of the Government then put the Government's point of view. This is what they could not understand. I think one of the things that is lacking from the IPU is the right of members of one delegation to put forward contrary points of view. It is interesting to note that the United Nations is still putting pressure on Indonesia to grant the right of self determination to the people of Timor. That is in line with the point of view that I have been putting. I also note in the delegation's report to the United Nations on the Western Sahara Polisario Front that this is a matter in regard to which the leader of the delegation and I put forward different points of view. I draw the attention of the honourable member for Berowra to the fact that his Government is now supporting the Polisario Front in its right to self determination in the Western Sahara dispute.

This conference enables members of the same delegation attending the meeting to express differing points of view. I think it should be continued. I would hate like hell ever to think that this Parliament would restrict the right of an individual to put a certain point of view at the conference. I found the conferences most interesting. It afforded members the opportunity to talk to other people and hear other points of view. For example, the Irish delegation used to present a point of view on the situation in Northern Ireland and the British delegation used to defend what had been going on.

This type of matter is raised from time to time as a side issue. I asked that a matter about Socialist International be included in the report; I note that it was not. My party is a member of Socialist International, which used to have at every conference a dinner or a luncheon at which prominent members of Socialist International would be in attendance and in which a welcome would be extended, particularly by the home State, to all the visiting delegates. It is interesting to note the situation in the German Democratic Republic, as it calls itself, when permission was sought-I was one of the delegates who sought permission-to hold a meeting of Socialist International in the Parliament building in East Berlin in which the conference was being held. In all the other countries in which we had met these meetings had been allowed. Permission was refused on this occasion. In straight-out defiance of this refusal we met. Admittedly this meeting had to take place in a public place-in a tea room that was normally available to members. We let it be known loud and clear what we were going to do. We met there and talked about things concerning the various democratic socialist countries and unanimously carried a resolution condemning the actions of the South Korean Government in its persecution of Kim Dae Jung, the socialist Opposition leader in that country. These sorts of things go on when delegates are permitted to attend conferences such as the IPU and to mix with parliamentarians from other places. This gets results, as was shown in the case of Singapore and the persecution of people who claimed to be members of Parliament.

I support the contents of the report and again congratulate the leader of the delegation for his election to the executive. As he said, it was a team effort to achieve that. I thank you, Mr Speaker, for permitting the delegation to extend an invitation to the body known as the nine-plus-it is now the 10-plus-to hold its pre-spring meeting in Australia. Even though we have internal differences of opinion on minor matters, we are in fairly close agreement on the overall issues. It is important for a body such as the 10-plus to continue to meet. The delegates who attend such meetings have a job to do in the preparation and planning of such meetings. We know what happened on one occasion when the meeting did not take place. Quite frankly, we were a rabble until such time as the nine-plus got together and started to talk about tactics to counter the Russian bloc, which is the only way to describe it. The Russians certainly dominate it. Whatever they want is what the others fall in line with. I thank you, Mr Speaker, on behalf of the delegation, for extending the invitation to the meeting in Canberra. Admittedly, the previous delegation of which I was a member extended the invitation, but at least the meeting was held here this year.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Fraser Government's failure to develop a diamond marketing policy for Australia, particularly with respect to the Ashton Joint Venture.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One would have hoped that, with the proposing of such a serious topic, the Government would have had the decency to have it answered by a minister, notably the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony). I appreciate that he is Acting Prime Minister at the moment, but that should not deter him from meeting his responsibilities in the House and answering on a matter like this. Whenever such a matter was proposed by the right honourable gentleman when in Opposition he was always answered by the Minister for Minerals and Energy, Mr Connor. The discourtesy which is shown to the Opposition by the Government in this House is really beyond the pale when matters of ministerial accountability are in question. I will not stay for the reply of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) because I just do not regard any contribution he may make as being a serious representation of Government policy. I am at least in the position of being able to put the view of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has the potential of becoming the largest diamond producer in the world. The Ashton Joint Venture at Argyle will be the first in what may be a number of world ranking diamond projects. There are 50 other known kimberlite pipes in the same region of Western Australia. Ashton will be a significant new source of diamond supply in the world market. As such its size and potential is threatening to other world producers, such as South Africa, Zaire and the Soviet Union. The Oppenheimer group, which controls the diamond syndicate companies of De Beers and Anglo American, is particularly concerned at the emergence of a large low cost producer outside its sphere of influence. De Beers controls over 50 per cent of the world diamond trade and, until recently, controlled almost 80 per cent.

With Australia's newest mineral industry emerging as a potent world force almost at birth, the question must be asked: What is the Australian Government doing to develop a diamond marketing strategy? The simple answer is nothing. What is even more obvious is that the Acting Prime Minister cannot even come into the House and offer some explanation as to the Government's policy. The negligence of this Government in not involving itself in the marketing options of a new industry of this significance defies explanation. The Acting Prime Minister told the Parliament yesterday that he was not familiar with contractual terms currently being discussed between the Ashton joint venturers and De Beers and went on to say, in an answer to my colleague the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi), that the Government would leave it to the joint venture companies to maximise their returns through their own corporate strategies. He added as a rider that cognisance should be taken of national interest considerations.

What is obvious is that the Government has left this most significant discovery at Argyle and the marketing of its produce to the whim of individual companies and the caprice of the De Beers Central Selling Organisation, known as the CSO. One would have thought that the Commonwealth Government would seek to maximise the national wealth from diamonds in the same way as South Africa has with De Beers. But the Fraser Government has not even taken the trouble to gather vital information on the nature of the AK1 diamond pipe and the true market value of the diamonds therein. No survey of the pipe has been done by either the Western Australian Government or the Commonwealth Government. The Commonwealth Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics apparently lacks the wherewithal to evaluate the deposit.

Without an adequate information base on the deposit, and the world diamond market, the Commonwealth would be at a complete loss to resist a joint venture contractual marketing proposal, let alone propose some arrangement perceived to be more advantageous to Australia. The Ashton project is expected to come on stream in 1985 and contractual arrangements are now being considered. The De Beers Central Selling Organisation is believed to have offered a long term low price contract to the Ashton joint venturers which is to be concluded by October or November of this year. Such a contract hastily concluded in a government policy vacuum could have serious long term implications for the industry and shackle it to South Africa before it has had any opportunity to grow independently. The CSO looms large in any diamond marketing strategy for Australia. An intelligent, well-informed decision has to be made as to whether Australia should commit a substantial proportion of Ashton production to the CSO. Recently the world's largest producer, Zaire, has broken its marketing link with the CSO, as has Angola. The Soviet Union is also moving some of its diamond produce outside the CSO orbit.

At a time when the CSO is declining as a world diamond force, should Australia's fledgling diamond industry be enmeshed in its operations? That is pertinent. There is no doubt that the CSO offers stability, outlets and guaranteed prices if Australia joins the CSO, but it makes it very much stronger at a time when its own diamond reserves are declining. Such a decision would virtually commit Ashton's future to De Beers policy. This would be an imprudent course for Australia, though it may be possible to make an arrangement with the CSO which preserves Australian autonomy. The alternative is to take the Zaire course, but this would involve the establishment of a formidable Australian marketing force in the world, and one which would need to be established with expedition. An independent Australian marketing effort has access, competition and time frame problems which may inhibit Australian diamond development. No doubt De Beers would counter such a move with stiff competition designed to bring Australia quickly to its knees. This would be difficult given the low cost nature of our deposits when compared with the high and escalating costs of the African deposits.

The linkage question with the CSO is a fundamental decision which has to be made. The Acting Prime Minister made it obvious yesterday that neither he nor the Government have even considered this question let alone arrived at any determination. Associated with the CSO decision is the matter of a domestic cutting and polishing industry. The real profits in diamonds are in the processing rather than the mining.

There is no reason why Australia with an abundant indigenous source of diamond should not become one of the major cutting and polishing centres in the world. Australia is forever seeking processing opportunities related to minerals. Diamonds would provide a perfect opportunity. It would be a tragedy for Australia to emerge as a significant force in raw diamond supply and see the real profits of its produce taken offshore with foreign processing. It takes three to five years to train a gem cutter. Within a relatively short space of time Australia could have a significant processing industry. Does anyone seriously contend that the Fraser Government has considered this matter let alone arrived at a policy approach. Like everything else this will be left to market forces, even when the market in this case is manipulated by a monopoly.

What I have said so far relating to marketing policy presumes that everything is above board and that it would be a matter for decision by the joint venturers and the Commonwealth Government. Well everything in the Ashton project is far from above board. De Beers already have important links with the project. For a start Ashton Mining, which has 38.2 per cent of the project, is dominated by the Malaysian Government and De Beers. The Malaysian Government is itself vulnerable to De Beer policy by virtue of the fact that the CSO has established a large processing facility in Malaysia. There is no possible way that Ashton Mining will respond to anything other than De Beer policy. To reinforce the Opposition's contention that the Fraser Government is negligent in respect of the development issues surrounding Ashton, the Government granted Ashton Mining naturalising status in February. That is, the Government has given this company the status of Australian so that in future it may enjoy all the privileges of a majority-owned Australian company. The effective control aspect was completely ignored. This decision by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) was a travesty of the spirit and intent of the naturalising policy.

Currently 14,000 small Australian shareholders hold 40 per cent of the Ashton stock. Even with another 11 per cent of Ashton's shareholding in Australian hands how could the Government possibly believe that 14,000 small Australian shareholders could arrive at a boardroom policy which would predominate over that of De Beers and the Malaysian Government sitting at the board with a determined strategy and 49 per cent of the stock. What is the majority 2 per cent of the equity worth in terms of control when 14,000 Australian shareholders are unable to formulate and exercise a policy at board level? If the 51 per cent were in the hands of say, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd or CSR Ltd with a specific policy then it would be a different matter. But as things stand the Treasurer's decision to grant De Beers and Malaysian Mining naturalising status is a disgrace. How could anyone seriously expect these two interests to respond to the Australian national interest.

The little manoeuvre by Ashton Mining, with the Treasurer's compliance, allows a 60 per cent foreign-owned company to be regarded as 51 per cent Australian. This then allows the project to proceed with what is deemed to be the mandatory 51 per cent Australian equity. So much for Ashton Mining.

The dominant corporate force in the project is Conzinc Riotinto of Australia with a 56.8 per cent interest. It will also manage the project. CRA is a naturalising company which has, to date, met the spirit and the letter of its obligations to the Commonwealth Government in respect of its naturalising status, which includes an all Australian board. CRA is currently 58 per cent owned by Riotinto Zinc Corporation Ltd. It has been alleged that Oppenheimer interests have the largest holding of RTZ stock and as such would have a substantial influence over RTZ and in turn CRA. I have no doubt that the CRA board is motivated by the best interests of its shareholders and Australia. These interests may at times, though, be mutually exclusive. RTZ is still the major CRA shareholder. Nevertheless, one may reasonably expect that the spirit of the RTZ naturalising agreement with the Commonwealth Government will be complied with. One aspect of these agreements was the appointment of an all Australian board. The purpose and intent of having an all Australian board was that when a possible conflict of interest arose, the national sentiments of the Australians would take precedence over the majority RTZ shareholder interest. The Opposition would like to be assured that this position would obtain in relation to the Ashton project. It should also be understood that without naturalising status for CRA, the project on a second count, would fail to comply with the mandatory 51 per cent Australian equity requirement.

Another important element in the corporate arrangements of the project is the 5 per cent interest held by Northern Mining Corporation. This is an all Australian company without any De Beers connection. Northern has played a role beyond its small minority interest and has been in dispute with CRA and Ashton Mining over project development policy and the value and extent of the deposit. Northern is currently being taken over by an Alan Bond company, Endeavour Resources Ltd. Bond may wish to retain this strategic interest which, at this point, is the only all Australian window into the project. The current management of Northern wants its share of the production in kind so that it may sell or process its own diamonds. This would probably annoy Ashton and CRA and would not please De Beers. If Bond takes over Northern this policy could change. What is important is Bond's real interest in Northern. It may be to take a place in Australia's first diamond project. It is conceivable though that Endeavour is attempting to warehouse Northern equity for an eventual sale to CRA or a De Beers interest at a profit. A statement of Endeavour's intentions would be a welcome clearing of the air in this regard. Again, one would not expect the Government to be slightly interested. I doubt whether it has even considered it.

The Commonwealth Government is in a position to exercise substantial influence over the future course of diamond development policy not only through the foreign investment regulations but also through its trade powers. While a heavy handed approach to export questions would be inappropriate when viewed against the complex background of diamond marketing, it would be appropriate though for the Commonwealth to use its powers judiciously in respect to marketing questions. What is disturbing is that diamonds are not subject to Commonwealth export controls. Diamonds were removed from the schedule of minerals covered by the controls by specific legislation in 1976. As things stand the joint venturers have no need even to consult the Commonwealth Government on matters associated with the project other than foreign investment considerations which have already been approved. Given the likely impact of the venture on Australia, the significance of the deposit's wealth and the industry's potential for the nation, the Commonwealth must be in a position to play an active role in the scrutiny of pricing and marketing arrangements. Diamonds must again be subject to export controls. This would at least be a first step by the Government in seeking to rectify what has been a negligent disregard for the national interest in its failure to formulate and monitor a diamond development policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear the speech made by the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) on the matter of public importance. It is better to see him in his own paddock. He certainly went a little better on this subject than he did when he copied the speech made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) on the Budget. He seems to believe that I am incompetent to carry out this task. I am much more confident, having heard the honourable member's speech, of my ability to answer this matter which was, basically, a history of the venture. Furthermore, if the honourable gentleman decided to contact the Western Australian Government which, is his typically centralised manner he chooses to ignore, I am sure he could get all the answers to the very few questions that he raised.

SPEECH.PARA: As may be likely to happen on other occasions, the Opposition in this situation has brought this matter up too soon and has not gone very far into the issue. That is possibly some evidence of the vacuum in the Opposition's objective policy. It has had to rush round and scramble up this particular issue, suggesting that the Federal Government is not, at present, taking an interest in or having a policy on this matter. Yet, the honourable member for Blaxland was at pains to point out the limits to the Federal Government's power in this area. The Federal Government has limited powers. The honourable member for Blaxland knows it and we know it. We know also who has the powers at this moment. The State of Western Australia has the powers at this moment and it also has an Act of Parliament which allows it to have considerable influence on the results of this venture, as it has in many other ventures. I am not sure where the information that the honourable member for Blaxland presented came from, but of course, most of us have read almost exactly the same things in the newspapers. In fact, I thought the newspapers showed more concern than he did.

A simple solution to his personal concern would have been to do what I did this morning, at extremely short notice, and that was to talk to the Minister for Resources Development in Western Australia, Mr Peter Jones. One of the first things he chose to tell me was that he was there last Friday--

TALK.START.PARA: —Big deal.

—Yes, but it gives him some better idea of what is going on than someone who has run to the Parliamentary Library to get a bit of information in order to raise this so-called matter of public importance when we might have been dealing with some legislation of interest to the general community.
—Read the history and you will understand it.
—If you listen to me you might learn something from that point.
—Order! I ask honourable members not to interject. The honourable member for O'Connor will address himself to the matter before the House.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I received information from the Western Australian Minister for Resources Development, and I might add that he was quite happy for me to quote him. It is a pity that the honourable member for Blaxland does not want to listen to it; he is just walking out of the chamber. He thought that he should get it from a Federal Minister who is currently not involved in the issue at the level of negotiation which is normally the case in Australia under our Federal system. As I have said before, we well and truly know his attitude to the States' having to do anything at all. The State Minister told me that negotiations for an agreement are proceeding with the companies involved. He hopes that they will be completed by the end of the year-which differs from what the honourable member for Blaxland told us. He told us that our whole birthright would be signed away in October. Can honourable members imagine De Beers or any other international company bothering to commit itself-let us remember that these agreements are two-sided-before having any rights to mine under the Western Australian mining Act? The Minister told me that those negotiations will be completed and he told me something else which every honourable member in this chamber knows, that is, that the right to mine will be the subject of an Act of the State Parliament. So, the first opportunity that we, the Australians--
—You can rely on the Tories.

—Yes, we know you do not like State governments. We know you would sack them all.That is okay. Get your colleague from Western Australia to tell the people of Western Australia that Labor would prefer to do without their State Parliament.
—I look after the national interests.
—I am just telling you that the public interest will be served--
—Order! The honourable member will address the Chair.

—Well, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will tell you that the public interest will be served in the Western Australian Parliament and the Act will be debated there. But the State Minister also assures me that the basis of the negotiations at this stage is to include an arrangement that will lead to processing within Australia. The Western Australian Minister is doing that; and we, the Commonwealth, know that he is doing so. So why do we need to be told that we do not have a policy? The Minister went on to say that processing can mean just the mere sorting and grading of the stones, apparently a reasonably labour intensive activity; but of course, it could mean the cutting and polishing of the stones as referred to by the honourable member for Blaxland. The Minister also said that it is the intention of the Western Australian Government to see that these functions are also included. The Minister does not mind talking about De Beers. He recognises that the companies which are very immature in the area of diamond mining are talking to De Beers. He knows that De Beers is the central selling organisation. He knows that De Beers is actually based in London, but we have been told that it is all going to be tied to South Africa. However, we know of De Beers' connections in South Africa. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The State Government policy is to attempt to have the advantages without the disadvantages.

I understand from what he told me that this means that the State Government sees the impossibility of going out into the open world market without the advice of somebody who knows a lot more than we do, recognising that there are pass-on advantages to Australia in processing. If the Opposition is of the opinion that the Western Australian Government does not at all times attempt to maximise the return from its raw materials, it does not see the things that are happening. In fact, it is interesting to note that although that State Government is interested in alumina smelting, not too many members of the Opposition have much support for it. Fortunately, the diamond industry does not have some of the other requirements and problems of alumina smelting. The Western Australian Government is determined to include in its agreement the fact that there will be moves to maximise the returns to Australians.

Furthermore, the Western Australian Government, recognising its shortfall of knowledge-something the Opposition never seems to be disturbed about in its case-sent an officer to South Africa. He was sent not only to discover how things were done there, but also to discover how South Africa deals with its diamond processors and its diamond producers. Opposition members can laugh. I had a sign here the other day to hold up so that they would know when to laugh. But they ought to learn to laugh properly because their laugh is practised. Opposition members doubt what the Western Australian Government has done but have they discovered any of these things? No. Their spokesman has given us a little story about diamond mining, one which has been in the Press for the last fortnight. There was nothing in the speech of the honourable member for Blaxland that could not have been written in five lines. The Western Australian Government has done this sort of thing and it has had an internal report which it is considering in the light of the negotiations it is having. The Minister is also of the opinion that a massive furphy is being distributed about a lot of the circumstances which is not related to the welfare of Australians.

It is one of the normal practices in a sharemarket battle for a lot of statements to be made. At this time, insufficient credibility can be attached to those statements. It is not unusual in this place to find members of the Opposition complaining bitterly about company directors and others overstating the possibilities of their particular venture-they would have them hung if they possibly could-but because there is a degree of conservatism among the partners, members of the Opposition feel that there is something wrong because it suits them to on this occasion. The State Minister told me that he is keeping the Commonwealth informed and that, in his view, the Commonwealth has quite properly left the negotiations to the States at this time. I agree with him entirely. That is why there are no massive announcements coming out of this Parliament at this time on where we are heading. It is a State issue at this time. It is being handled by a very competent Minister in Peter Jones.

Let us look at some of the other issues. I have mentioned the role of the Commonwealth, in particular in regard to foreign investment. We had quite an interesting comment from the honourable member for Blaxland in that regard when he mentioned a lot of problems relating to the Ashton group. He said that that group owns 38.2 per cent of the joint venture and that Conzinc Riotinto of Australia-a company of which he apparently approves, because he said some nice things about it and its all-Australian board-has 56.8 per cent and is listed as the manager of the venture. In other words, at present a fully Australian board is the manager of the venture. What is so wrong about that? Let us consider diamonds anyway as we know all about them. We have control of export if we choose to use it. The honourable member for Blaxland has told us that we have no such control. At present we are not in the business of exporting diamonds. When the agreement which the Western Australian Government is negotiating, quite correctly and at the proper time, is reached what action this Government should take will be a lot clearer to it. We are all well and truly aware of how little time it would take us to reinstitute the necessary export control. It is ridiculous to say that what we do not need now is a failure to the Australian public.

I now refer to the De Beers organisation. There is an old statement about diamonds being a girl's best friend. If it were not for De Beers they would not be worth very much. It is no secret that the world has an over-supply of diamonds. They could be dug out at a more rapid rate. It has been pointed out that the Russians choose to sell diamonds through a scheme which must be completely anathema to their politics. They do so because they know that, if they do not, the price will fall because of over-supply. It is interesting to note what the De Beers organisation said in its 1980 report to its shareholders. I do not think it was trying to fool the Opposition. The report stated:

In the middle of 1980 the boom conditions experienced during the late 1970's came to an end. Since the end of 1980 the market in cutting centres has further weakened and it has become necessary for the CSO in accordance with established policy to reduce the offerings to the market substantially in order to maintain stability. Stocks of rough diamonds in the trade are not excessive but in the view of the large stocks of polished diamonds the CSO as I have mentioned has undertaken its traditional function of reducing the quantity of goods offered to its customers in order to assist the market to recover its balance.

Let us remember that De Beers is a selling cartel. This country knows a fair bit about buying cartels. Where might we be if CRA and other companies did not go to the big man first? Let me stress that there is no agreement. There will be no agreement. The first agreement will be with Western Australia. I am sure that our Minister and his Department know what is going on and that we will have the necessary controls when we need them. If the Opposition has some criticism, it should come up with a solution. That was completely absent in the words of the honourable member for Blaxland. God save us if he is the man who one day is in charge as he seems to think that all one has to do to be able to run a government is criticise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to reply in some detail to the comments of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) on this matter, but the utter silliness of the bulk of his speech defies reply. Suffice to say that, as a Western Australian member of parliament, I have observed discussion in the Western Australian Press and the Western Australian Parliament over the last six months. What has been absolutely evident throughout that discussion is that the Western Australian Government has demonstrated its complete incompetence to defend the interest of the Western Australian people, let alone the Australian people, in matters related to mining. The Grants Commission report has revealed that persistently there has been a pattern in Western Australian royalties payments way below what the Western Australian Government could reasonably be expected to obtain on behalf of its people. The honourable member for O'Connor now expects us to accept the bona fides of the Western Australian Minister for Mines who has perpetrated the bulk of this situation. The honourable member for O'Connor says: 'Do not worry. He has it all under control. He has visited the project. He therefore knows all about it and there are no problems. He sent a man to discuss with De Beers the problem of marketing. Therefore, he knows all about it.'

SPEECH.PARA: What sort of laughable institution does the honourable member for O'Connor think this is when he brings in this sort of nonsense as a serious argument? We must not be too surprised at this. The Minister for Trade and Recources (Mr Anthony) would not debate this matter because he is in ignorance of it. The honourable member for O'Connor is in ignornace of it as well. How can he possibly expect the Western Australian Government to be responsible for or to have any substantial influence on the marketing arrangements of this product when it goes overseas? It is properly a Commonwealth responsibility and it was exercised under the Whitlam Labor Government in consultation with the States. No consultation is being carried out in this case because the Commonwealth has abnegated its responsibility. It did so again yesterday when the Minister replied to a question by the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi).

The Government's failure to defend the national interest on mining ventures of major importance to the economic future of this country stands once more exposed. Its failure is based on a deliberate determination to remain in ignorance of the national interest. In this case the Government has on its hands probably the richest single diamond mine in the world, a project which has been under evaluation for some years now, the dimensions of which have been to a considerable degree known in mining circles. Yet when the honourable member for Hawker asked a pertinent question yesterday on marketing arrangements and their impact on the national interest the Minister was obliged to reveal ignorance and a determination that he would not investigate or interfere with the venturers' claims and marketing arrangements, despite what the honourable member for O'Connor might think of some future action on his part.

If one wanted to devise a sample case which justified everything the Labor Party has said about the requirements of effective minerals policy one could not go past this one. In the first instance the public revelation of the value of the Ashton Joint Venturer's Lake Argyle project has come as a result of the leaking of a document produced for the junior partner in the group, Northern Mining, which is the only part of the project wholly Australian owned. Judging by the article by Jan Roberts which appeared in the Age and which was repeated in the Daily News of yesterday, the commentaries of a number of Northern Mining employees reveal an effort by the company to defend our rights to a share of the world market commensurate with the significance of the project, to a price which ensures a return to the Australian community and to participate in the profitable secondary processing of the mineral-in this case through diamond cutting. The company does not argue its case because of big-heartedness but because it has a clear economic interest. Its circumstances indicate clearly that national capital and multinational capital are likely to have very differing interests in marketing arrangements. This is because multinational capital's interest in an enterprise is likely to be associated, as it is in this case, with a vertically integrated international operation with profit opportunities at all stages of the processing and marketing of the mineral. National capital, however, will not have such access and will therefore seek, firstly, the best possible price at the extractive stage and, secondly, processing opportunities locally and a say in international marketing arrangements. It has none of that automatically.

That is why Opposition members have said over and over again in this place that significant Australian components should be a feature of every resources project in this country. Yet at every stage this Government has thwarted the operation of the policy guidelines established during the Whitlam Government until they have come through in this case with totally ridiculous naturalisation methods that were amply dealt with by the member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) and commented upon pathetically by the honourable member for O'Connor. This Government has deliberately placed itself on the question of diamond marketing and mining in a position where it can be of no assistance to Northern Mining. It did this firstly in October 1976 by removing diamonds from the operation of export control arrangements established during our time. It did it secondly by permitting a situation in which the Bureau of Mineral Resources has no resources for or rights to an independent survey of the value of the field.

There is a pathetic little piece in the Jan Roberts article which relates the comments of a spokesman from the BMR pointing out that his Bureau was limited to newspaper reports and to whatever companies chose to tell it. The Australian public and the Australian Public Service, as a direct result of the anti-national policies of this Government are compelled to scrabble about like theives in the night for information on the national interest. This is not to say that Northern Mining's reluctance to be involved with the central selling organisation is necessarily the best policy. The honourable member for Blaxland did not suggest it was. With a project so new and with that organisation's capacity to damage hold-outs, co-operation might be the most useful means of defending our national interest. But it is the terms of co-operation which are important. Obviously Australia's bargaining power is very great. In the Age today it was pointed out that production costs at Argyle will be about $6 a carat versus De Beers' South African average of $32 a carat. Argyle kimberlite pipe one-AKI-has a capacity to yield, again on estimates which are constantly being valued upwards, around 25 million carats a year, 20 times as high as the average Southern African mine and three times higher than last year's South African production. This colossal competitive advantage is being frittered away by the failures of this Government which cannot define, let alone defend, the national interest.

If Northern Mining were assisted by the Government or if it were itself involved, certain features of the bargaining process would obviously have emerged. Firstly, there would have been an official counter to the efforts of other partners in the project to downgrade the value of the field. These partners have pointed out that in gemstone quality Ashton is somewhat lower than its South African equivalents. While the percentages are lower than the South African percentage at the quality end, the volumes of production at Argyle will be so huge as to render this irrelevant. In case, near gemstone quality is what is available in most jewellery stores, and around 40 per cent of the amount which would be produced from the field would be of that quality.

Secondly, there would be an insistence that the development of the field would be accompanied by a cutting industry in Australia. There is no reason why Perth should not be the centre for a cutting operation for the whole of Australia. We now face the ludicrous possibility, if we do not have that cutting industry, that we will have to continue to import the $54m-worth of cut diamonds we currently import despite the fact that these diamonds will now originate from Australia. The cut diamonds which come back into Australia will be many times the value of the raw product which goes out. Northern Mining, according to the article, would receive only $600,000 for the 60,000 carats of gems needed to supply the Australian market. The Central Selling Organisation would then be able to sell the stones back for $54m to the Australian trade. Thirdly, if the Government took an interest in bargaining with CSO or in establishing its own Australian-supported marketing operation, the project would now be offered a price for the product which is not 80 per cent below its real value, which, according to independent valuation, the CSO offer is. Fourthly, if the Government took an interest in bargaining we would be in a better position to beat down the monstrous commission which the CSO now insists upon.

The Government's position continues to leave the Australian population in ignorance of the possibilities of the venture. The Government's position continues to deny the possibility that the Australian population is going to benefit significantly from this project. The Government is worthy of considerable criticism on this matter. It is significant that it has sought not to answer this criticism in the House itself, but to put up two of its most junior members to do so. That is a disgrace and a discourtesy which was never shown the present Government when it was in Opposition by our side of the House and it is a discourtesy which we would not show it, were we to be in office again. But it would not be bringing forward matters of public importance on this subject because it would be shamed by the effectiveness of our capacity to defend the national interest with regard to this matter and would prefer to maintain silence in much the same way as the Minister has maintained silence on this matter in the House today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) said in this House yesterday, we acknowledge one fact which the Opposition has brought forward; that is, the Argyle discovery is a major one by world standards and has a very large production potential. However, I emphasise, in talking about the future marketing of diamonds, that no decision has yet been made by the Ashton Joint Venture even to proceed with commercial production. But it is considered that production at the rate of some 25 million carats a year will certainly make it the world's largest source of natural diamonds. Most of the production, of course, is expected to be of industrial quality, but with a significant proportion of higher value gem diamonds.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I should provide to the House some of the history of this joint venture. In 1977 a large group of kimberlite pipes was defined at Allendale in the Kimberley region of Western Australia. A sampling plant was commissioned in August 1978 and this began scout sampling of all the pipes that had been discovered at that time. Further work was carried out in 1979 and, of course, is continuing. In September 1979 the Argyle project was discovered south of Lake Argyle in the west Kimberleys. A kimberlite pipe was located and a series of alluvial diamond deposits was delineated, extending downstream from the pipe along the course of Smoke Creek. The diamond pipe we are talking about is some 45 hectares in surface area. Diamonds have been recovered in stream gravels along Smoke Creek up to 30 kilometres from the pipe. Evaluation of the Smoke Creek alluvial deposits resumed following the wet season in February 1980. However, work on this pipe did not resume again until last September when the Western Australian Government gave its approval to the Ashton Joint Venture for work to proceed on all of its tenements accompanying the Argyle project.

The future development of the Argyle Joint Venture will consist of spending some $35m in regional exploration in the Kimberley region and in the evaluation of all diamond prospects in this area. Exploration, therefore, is still continuing. Also, evaluation of the pipe will require the drilling program to continue in order to further geological and metallurgical data. Engineering studies have commenced to make recommendations on the method of sampling the Argyle project, including the provision of plant, equipment and ancillary services. Of course, sociological and environmental studies are also under way.

I think this background is very important because this matter of public importance has come forward this morning as a result of articles by journalists in the Age, in the Sydney Morning Herald and in other newspapers throughout Australia. The Opposition has based all of its arguments on leaked documents and newspaper reports. It is nothing more than a desire to batter the resources industry and its development in this country. The Parliament should clearly understand the circumstnces surrounding the leaked documents. All honourable members are aware that Northern Mining Corporation is presently in a take-over position and it is completely understandable that it would be defending itself. Northern Mining is a small company and there is a history of differences of opinion between the various partners in this joint venture. Of course, this is common with a resource of this magnitude. For example, Northern Mining itself has estimated the deposit at some 160 million tonnes and this estimate is no doubt based on its own intelligence and on an intelligent analysis. However, CRA Ltd estimates the known-I emphasise 'known'-deposits as being in the order of 100 million tonnes. This indicates a difference of opinion on valuation of the stones and the size of the resource body.

It is therefore necessary, I believe, to make the House aware of the responsible attitude that these joint venture partners have taken in reporting the progress and the extension of this deposit. Discussions were held with the Melbourne Stock Exchange on the principles of reporting and these were agreed to by both parties. Details of progress in this deposit are released every quarter. The reporting of the details has not been embellished and this conservative approach is obviously being criticised by the Opposition today. In a project such as this, accuracy is important. Every honourable member should agree that this is essential, particularly with such a glamorous and flamboyant resource. I doubt whether any of the resource or exploration projects in this country have every supplied such detailed information to the public. It is also typical that CRA's chairman, who is one of Australia's most respected businessmen, has clearly indicated a responsible role in Australian resource development. This nation is fortunate that the project is destined to be one the world's largest diamond projects. But we have to recognise that it is in the embryo stage. It is still operating under an exploration licence from the Western Australian Government and another permit will be needed even to commence. In fact, an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review indicated the facts which were given to this House by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). The article states:
The Western Australian Government is seeking a commitment from the Ashton joint venture that a diamond polishing and cutting industry will eventually be established in the State.
That is exactly opposite to the views put forward by the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley). The article continues:
However, it recognised that this was not practicable in the short term, according to the Minister for Resource Development, Mr Peter Jones.
He said the negotiations for an agreement between the joint venture and the State Government over the Argyle diamond deposit were expected to be completed by the end of the year.
These would cover royalties, infrastructure, processing and timing of the operation.
Mr Jones confirmed that the task of proving the extent of the diamond deposit would take some time and that the product would not move into a higher stage of production for a couple of years.

Much has been said today by the Opposition about the influence of the De Beers company's international operation in this project. I think we should, for a moment, look at the criticism that the joint venture party is going into a market operation with De Beers and that De Beers is extending its influence on the joint venture. I believe this shows a distorted insight, both by the reporter who wrote the article and the Opposition, into the world marketing situation of diamonds. This is a damaging allegation and is so typical of many that come from the other side in relation to our resource projects. Again, it is based on hearsay and leaked documents.

Surely it is natural that a company which mines diamonds and which is endeavouring to form marketing operations for diamonds in Australia will talk to De Beers, the world's largest diamond selling organisation. But it is also talking to many of the other companies involved. The honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) attempted to mislead this House by stating that De Beers has a very major shareholding in the joint venture. My understanding is that De Beers has less than a 3 per cent holding in this venture, and this can hardly be termed a substantial holding. It is also a fact that the joint venture partners have spoken with not only De Beers but also General Electric-a major world producer of synthetic and industrial diamonds. The partners have also looked at the Zale Corporation, which is the world's largest marketer of diamonds through its chain of retail stores.

From the Government's point of view I emphasise that it is not necessary at this time to develop a marketing policy. But the Government does have a clear policy in relation to minerals. Our policy is to ensure that there is a reasonable return for exports and that the development of projects takes place in the national interest. Therefore this matter of public importance raised today by the Opposition is an exercise in futility. It displays an ignorance of this particular venture, and I believe it should be totally disregarded by this Parliament. The process of evaluating a resource is a long exercise and the marketing aspects particularly as they relate to diamonds will involve discussions with hundreds of companies throughout the world.

This Government will look carefully at whether a diamond marketing policy will include further processing, such as sorting and cutting, on the basis of its economic viability. The question of deciding the best form of marketing to adopt in these circumstances is clearly complicated and difficult. It is essentially a decision to be made on the basis of the commercial judgments of the companies conerned.
