DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Second Reading
Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Mr Moore:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill, the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1 to 9) and the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) as they are associated measures? Separate questions will, of course, be put at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —These sales tax Bills give effect to three sets of decisions relating to sales tax that were announced in the Budget. Those three sets of decisions were: Firstly, to raise by 2 1/2 per cent the rates of sales tax on items previously taxed; secondly, to eliminate various alleged anomalies and inconsistencies in relation to sales tax; and, thirdly, to apply sales tax at the rate of 2 1/2 per cent to a whole range of items which were previously exempt from such tax. I wish to deal in more detail with what is proposed in the legislation. The first of those three sets of decisions is to raise the rate of sales tax by 2 1/2 per cent. At present there are three sets of sales tax. Prior to the Budget announcement the rates were 2 1/2 per cent, 15 per cent and 27 1/2 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to raise by 2 1/2 per cent the existing rate of 2 1/2 per cent means, of course, that there will be a doubling of sales tax on items in that category. When we talk about a 2 1/2 per cent increase it should be born in mind that we are in effect talking of a doubling of the tax on all these items. The items involved in this category are everyday items such as furniture, crockery, glassware, cutlery, washing machines, vacuum cleaners, radiators, toasters, kettles, brooms, garbage cans, floor coverings, blinds, bedding, light fittings and candles. They are clearly items which are present in every household and which are important in people's daily expenditure patterns. Therefore an increase in the tax on those items is something which affects every person in the community. I think it is perhaps interesting to note also in this regard that, as everyone is aware, we have already had an increase in interest rates over the last year and a quarter. The cost of buying a home has increased because of that significant increase in interest rates.

This legislation in respect of the set of decisions applies sales tax to building materials, which increases the cost of building a home. The increase in sales tax on furniture and the other items I have just mentioned means that it costs far more to furnish a home, so home buyers are being hit in every possible way. The second rate of sales tax was previously 15 per cent. That is being raised to 17 1/2 per cent-an increase of some 17 per cent in the amount of tax payable. That means that the cost of a car, which is the main item in this category will be significantly increased. In broad terms, apart from motor cars, the items that are covered by this category are: Commercial motor vehicles, soft drinks, stationery, potable spirits, boats and yachts. There are many other items but they are the main items listed.

The third category was previously taxed at 27 1/2 per cent. This increases to 30 per cent-a rise of 9 per cent in the amount of tax payable. The items affected here are jewellery, field glasses, fountain and ball point pens, watches, clocks-apart from alarm clocks-furs, hair oils, cosmetics, body creams, shaving goods, hair brushes and combs, cameras and films, radios, tape recorders, records and television sets. These items are all taxed at a high rate because at some time in the past they were regarded as luxuries. I find it difficult to conceive of shaving goods and combs and brushes as luxuries and many people would dispute today that a radio or television set was a luxury. Nevertheless they are taxed as such and the rate of tax now increases from 27 1/2 per cent to 30 per cent.

I refer now to the second category of decisions relating to the elimination of various alleged anomalies and inconsistencies. There are 34 of these items altogether, of which 29 represent increases in tax either by increasing the existing rates or by applying tax to previously exempt items. These increases are quite substantial. For instance, on television picture tubes the tax is increased from zero to 30 per cent, which will mean a great increase in the cost of television sets. The tax on manufactured pet food, which I understand now also includes fresh pet foods, will go from zero to 17 1/2 per cent; the tax on car safety belts and windscreens will go from zero to 17 1/2 per cent; alarm clocks will go from 15 per cent to 30 per cent, household insecticides from zero to 17 1/2 per cent and so on. The tax increases are quite considerable and will have more than a minor impact on the expenditure patterns of people and on their living standards.

There are some reductions in bringing about the elimination of the so-called anomalies and inconsistencies. I should mention that there are some reductions in tax or eliminations of tax. They are mainly on items which are quite inconsequential, such as coffee whiteners and parts of movable toilet pans. In effect, we are looking at an array of increases under the disguise of eliminating anomalies. This considerably increases tax on a wide range of goods, some of which are particularly important. For example, I refer to the decision to tax colour television picture tubes which were previously exempt. It was the case that the tax on a television set applied to the whole of the set except for the tubes. The picture tube is a highly important part of a television set and the application of a 30 per cent tax instead of a zero tax to the tube means that the cost of a television set, as I understand it, will increase in the order of $80 or more. Altogether this so-called elimination of anomalies and inconsistencies will add $117m to tax revenue this year and $142m in a full year. In our view, the Government is achieving a broadening of the tax base under the guise of tidying up the legislation.

The third category of goods subject to tax covers those goods which were previously exempt but which are now being taxed at 2 1/2 per cent. All that was mentioned in the Budget was the broad categories of items which would be so taxable. The broad categories mentioned were clothing, footwear, drapery, soft furnishings, manchester, et cetera, building materials, books, magazines, newspapers, packaging and wrapping materials and tools and a range of other goods, not including food, medicine or wine. When we see what is being taxed we find that although what was said indicates a fairly broad range of goods in fact, many items are now to be subject to tax which one would not, on the face of it, think would be subject to tax under those headings. This will now be the case.

The legislation was brought in less than 48 hours ago by the Government to apply the tax to these previously exempt items. There was nothing in the second reading speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to throw any light on the matter I am about to raise but if one goes back to the legislation and to the schedule of previously exempt items which are now to have their exemption removed, one finds that these kinds of items are being covered: Books including leaflets, periodicals, magazines and even printed music. It also includes maps and road and tourist maps. We also find that greaseproof paper, vegetable parchment paper and wax paper are to be taxed. Under the heading of 'building materials' all of the expected items are there-bricks, plaster, wallpaper and builders' hardware. The heading covers also nails and tacks, nuts and bolts, paints and all of the other normal building items. It also includes cooking stoves and ranges which were previously tax free but which will now be taxed at 2 1/2 per cent. It includes electrical fittings and accessories such as chandeliers and pendants-even light globes come under the heading of 'building materials'. These items are all taxable at 2 1/2 per cent. Included also are baths, shower screens, toilets and hot water services. It is a very broad interpretation of what comes under the heading of 'building materials'. We also find that paper bags, rubber bands and sticky tape are to be subject to tax, which is really getting down to pretty minor items. Garden tools are also to be taxed.

Under the heading 'clothing' we find that not only all the obvious clothing is to be taxed, but also baby napkins and like items for babies. Also to be taxed are aprons, sanitary napkins and like items. It is a very broad interpretation of what is meant by 'clothing'. Without going through the list of thousands of items we find that we are facing a very substantial broadening of the tax base. It is not as though the Government is just simply extending the tax to a few additional categories. In effect, it is extending sales tax to all goods except for three categories-food, medicine and wine. In effect, those are the only goods which are now to be free of sales tax.

The effect of these measures will be to raise altogether some $550m this year or $892m in a full year. This represents an increase in sales tax this year of 39 per cent and, therefore, a considerable increase in indirect taxation and in total tax revenue. As has been made absolutely clear by statements outside this House, the Opposition is implacably opposed to these measures. It is opposed to them because they represent a repudiation of a pledge made only five months ago not to broaden the indirect tax base, they will have an adverse effect on the living standards of Australian families, they will affect the equity of the tax system in a quite regressive way and they will most certainly add to the inflation rate. Therefore, the measures are totally the opposite to the Government's alleged policy of fighting inflation.

In regard to the first of those reasons for opposing these measures, I note that on 12 March this year the Treasurer announced that after reviewing the possibility of broadening the indirect tax base either by a value added tax, retail sales tax or by extending the wholesale sales tax, the Government had decided not to undertake any such measures. That was a clear and major statement from the Treasurer on 12 March in this House on taxation. A little over five months later the Government is, in fact, considerably broadening the indirect tax base. This is the complete opposite of what it said at that time. If it was not appropriate five months ago to undertake this considerable broadening of the indirect tax base and to increase the incidence of indirect taxation generally, why is it now appropriate? We have been given no explanation for this at all.

All the Treasurer has been able to say is that he had something much more horrific in mind in conducting the investigation into broadening the indirect tax base late last year and early this year. He wanted to raise indirect taxes-he made this clear in his statement on 12 March-by $3,000m. Now he says that because he is only raising them by a little under $1,000m the same arguments do not apply-that is, the arguments which he used in March of this year to say that the Government would not be going ahead with the idea of extending indirect taxation. The main reason he did not proceed last March was because of the inflationary impact; at least, that was the publicly given reason. There may be other reasons, but the reason he gave to this House was that to increase indirect taxes in the way he was proposing would have been too inflationary to bear. He estimated that a $3,000m increase in indirect taxes would increase the inflation rate by 6 per cent. Broadly speaking, he reached that calculation by saying that a $500m increase in indirect taxes increases the consumer price index directly and indirectly by one per cent.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later hour this day.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill-by leave-presented by Mr Newman, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Earlier today I tabled the Remuneration Tribunal's 1981 Review which was presented to me on 18 June 1981. The Government has accepted the Tribunal's report on judges' remuneration and the following determinations: Allowances for members, Ministers and office-holders of the Parliament, and remuneration payable to holders of offices in the First Division of the Australian Public Service and holders of public offices. The Government accepts the merit in the Tribunal's decisions with regard to the increases in salaries for Ministers, members and office-holders in Parliament.

The decisions recognised the real decline in Parliamentary salaries that have already occurred in comparison with the wages earned by the average Australian. It is important to note that between March 1975 and December 1980 average weekly earnings rose by 84 per cent while the salaries of members of the Federal Parliament rose by 50 per cent. It should be remembered that members of parliament did not automatically receive the cost of living increases which flowed to most wage and salary earners as a result of national wage case decisions. It is also significant to look at the restraint that has already been exercised by the Government on its own Ministerial salaries in the interests of setting a national example.

Salary increases recommended for Ministers by an independent inquiry in 1971 were not implemented until 1973. Increases recommended by the Remuneration Tribunal in 1974 were not implemented. Increases in Ministerial salaries recommended in 1975, 1978 and 1979 were not implemented. In 1978 the Tribunal recommended that Ministers' salaries be increased by 4.9 per cent in line with national wage increases over the previous 12 months, but the Government did not accept this recommendation and no increases were given. In 1979 the Tribunal recommended increases of 9.1 per cent but the Government approved a rise of 7.3 per cent.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Government believes that the inflationary threats posed by excessive wage increases are so serious that an example of restraint must once again be set. Thus, as a lead to the rest of the community the Government has decided that the salary rise recommended by the Remuneration Tribunal for all senators, members, office-holders and Ministers will not be taken at once, but spread over two years. I express the hope that the community will take full note of this example being set by the Government and the Parliament.

The Remuneration and Allowances Amendment Bill gives effect to these views where action is required to implement or modify the Tribunal's decisions. Part II provides that members and office-holders of the Parliament will receive in 1981-82 salary or additional salary increases amounting to half those determined by the Tribunal. The rates which appear in the Bill reflect the total amounts which will be received in 1981-82. Part III deals with the salaries of Ministers and provides for the sum appropriated under the Ministers of State Act to be increased to provide for half the increases in the Tribunal's report. The Tribunal's report on the remuneration of judges is implemented by Part IV of the Act. Finally, Part V provides that the power of disallowances in the Remuneration Tribunals Act will not apply to the Tribunal's 1981 determinations, including those proposed to be modified by this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting, I was making the point that the impact of these sales tax measures would be to add considerably to inflation, and that on the basis of the calculations given by the Treasurer in his taxation statement on 12 March the impact would be in the order of 2 per cent. In that statement of 12 March, the Treasurer said that a one per cent increase in the consumer price index would occur for an increase in revenue from sales from indirect taxes of some $500m. I shall turn to his statement at that time. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: As a general rule, each additional $500m raised through indirect taxes results in direct and indirect additions to the consumer price index of almost 1 per cent. Furthermore, there are additional flow-on consequences for the consumer price index through the wage system which are hard to quantify.

So he therefore was quoting at least one per cent, and maybe more. Now is he saying that the inflationary impact of sales tax rises of almost $1,000m-that is, about one-third of what he was talking about in March of this year-would be only 0.75 per cent. Clearly, there is a great inconsistency between what he is saying now and what he was saying then. The only way that that can be explained at all, in my view, is that he is talking about the impact of those sales tax measures on the consumer price index for 1981-82 as against 1980-81. Of course, for only half that year we had the impact of the measures whereby previously exempt items are to be taxed. It would seem to us that the real figure is in the order of two per cent, and maybe even more with the flow-on introduced to wages, as he said. This, of course, is an extremely important point. These increases in sales tax will not be some minor factor; they will have a notable impact on the inflation rate.

What the Treasurer seems to be saying is that, although the inflation impact in March of this year was something which concerned him, inflation now does not concern him that much. One would ask: 'Has there been some great change in the level of inflation since March of this year?' Of course there has not. There has been a slight reduction in the CPI over that time, but the forecasts are for a notable increase at least in the next year. One reason for that notable increase is the measures now before the House. One must ask: 'Whatever happened to the so-called ''inflation first'' policy?' If the policy is to fight inflation-that is what the Government keeps saying is its policy-why is it introducing measures such as this one which clearly add directly to inflation? On the basis of the Treasurer's own figures, these measures will add approximately 2 per cent to the inflation rate. How is this possibly fighting inflation? What it is in fact is the continuance of a process which defies reason but which has been pursued by the Government during its time in office, that is, the process of fighting inflation by increasing prices. This is perhaps one of the more blatant examples of it, but there are many examples in the earlier Budgets of the Fraser Government.

We are concerned about the inflationary impact of these measures and the reason why we oppose them is important. We think it is absurd to be adding directly to the inflation rate in this way. It obviously not only will add to the inflation rate directly but also will feed the inflationary expectations about which the Treasurer says he is concerned, more than any other factor because it adds to the inflation rate. That in itself is a major cause of increased inflationary expectations, and certainly outweighs any reduction in inflationary expectations which may come from reducing the deficit by the increased revenue which comes from measures such as this. I think the Government and the Treasurer are totally misled in believing that by undertaking measures like this they are acting in some anti-inflationary way. It is quite obvious, on the face of the measures, that they are inflationary, and by their impact on inflationary expectations they certainly add to the inflation rate in the future. I also note what the Treasurer said in March of this year when he said that he would not broaden the incidence of indirect taxation. At that time he said quite unambiguously that any move to widen indirect taxes should be accompanied by reduced income tax. In his statement of 12 March 1981 he said:

Throughout its consideration of this issue, the Government remained firmly of the view that if a shift towards greater emphasis on indirect taxation were to occur, it should be accompanied by a noticeable reduction in personal income tax.

Where are the reductions in personal income tax? Despite this firm view of the Government in March of this year that any widening of the impact of indirect taxation should be accompanied by compensating reductions in income tax, we have the opposite. Instead of a firm pledge to reduce income tax, we now have a firm commitment to increase it, along with the increases in indirect taxation. Of course, there can be no denying that this Budget includes a substantial increase in the incidence of income tax. Pay-as-you-earn taxpayers will pay 22 per cent more tax this year, although the estimated increase in the wages bill is 15 1/2 per cent. That clearly spells out an increase in the incidence of income tax for wage and salary earners-the majority of income tax payers.

It is quite clear that this firm promise of March of this year that if at any future time there were to be some expansion of the incidence of indirect taxation it would be accompanied by reduced income tax has been totally broken. Indeed, not only has it been broken in the sense that there are no income tax cuts but also, in fact, there have been considerable income tax increases. That, of course, is a further reason for the Opposition strongly to oppose these measures. We also oppose them because what the Government is doing now clearly represents the not so thin edge of the wedge to a further expansion of indirect tax at some future time. In particular, with the new category of 2 1/2 per cent-that is, the items which were previously exempt but which are now taxable at 2 1/2 per cent-it would be very easy to raise these rates to the 5 per cent level, doubtless claiming that this was necessary to eliminate an anomaly, as the Government has done in respect of other items in this year's Budget. It is highly likely, therefore, that this is just the first step towards an even further extension of the indirect taxation that the Treasurer and the Treasury clearly desire. I note in this regard that the previously exempt items now to be taxed were all suggested by the Treasury in Taxation Paper No. 5 of 1974 and, of course, were not adopted by the then Labor Government, but they are now being adopted by this Government. It was also suggested then that the rates could be raised as another means of extending indirect taxation. That has also been done in this Budget. The Treasury also suggested in that paper that we could have a tax on services. That has not been done at this time. Clearly, this could be a future step in the process of increasing indirect taxes on which this Government now seems to have embarked.

Doubtless the Government will claim that this is not its intention. But the Opposition is not the only body which believes that the Government's intention is to go much further than it has to the present stage in extending the impact of indirect taxation. The morning after the Budget was delivered last week the Australian Financial Review had an editorial which spoke of the sales tax move as 'a major step towards a broadening of the tax base'. The editorial went on to state:
But of course the future of the new sales taxes is quite predictable. Over time they will creep up, while the much more noticeable income taxes will when electorally convenient, be reduced.
But the sales tax on a broader base is now a fait accompli. It will not be nearly as difficult once it is in operation to extend it to nearly all the categories of retailing.

Clearly, it is a wider perception than just that of the Opposition that this is the not so thin edge of the wedge for a much more significant extension of indirect taxation. As we made clear when the Treasurer made his statement in March of this year, we deplore any attempt to increase the incidence of indirect taxation. This is partly because of its inflationary impact, which I have spoken of, and because it undeniably increases the inequity of the tax system. Obviously, that inequity arises because of the way in which tax is levied. It applies in a way which has no regard for the capacity of individuals to pay. Instead of being a progressive tax, as income tax is, it is a regressive tax; that is, the tax applies at the same amount regardless of income and therefore bears more heavily as a proportion of income on those persons with lower incomes. It is regressive rather than progressive taxation, not only having no regard for the capacity of people to pay but also bearing on people in reverse of their capacity to pay. We oppose any extension of the incidence of indirect taxation. We have been consistent about that in the past with other indirect tax measures and similarly we oppose these measures because of what is involved in that regard.

In regard to the matter of the inequity of indirect taxation, I point to a couple of surveys which bear out what I am saying in this regard. Firstly, the household expenditure survey of 1976 conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics-if one updates the tables contained in that survey-clearly shows that households on lower incomes spend a greater proportion of their incomes than do their higher income counterparts. Therefore, if one taxes most of their expenditure it will weigh more heavily on them than on higher paid persons. Households on lower and middle incomes spend a greater proportion of their incomes on housing, fuel and power, food, household equipment and operation, and medical care-areas which are hard hit by the Commonwealth Government's charges and indirect taxes and by State charges. These State charges are likely to be increased in forthcoming budgets.

In 1976 Mr Neil Warren of the University of New South Wales looked at the incidence of all federal indirect taxes on different income levels for households. This study showed a declining trend as income rises. These finding have been updated by the increase in average weekly earnings since that time. The results show that a household with an income around average weekly earnings-that is, about $320 a week-pays 10.2 per cent of that income in indirect taxes, compared to 7.1 per cent for a household with an income double average weekly earnings and 14.9 per cent for a household earning less than $4,000. What comes clearly from that analysis of the impact of indirect taxation on households with differing incomes is that for lower income households those indirect taxes weigh far more heavily. This is not simply a matter of assertion; it is a matter of detailed, empirical analysis by Mr Neil Warren of the University of New South Wales. I believe that in those circumstances there can be no denying whatever that a move towards more indirect taxation, as is involved in these measures, means a move to a more regressive tax system and that if the Government persists in this direction clearly it will be forcing the lower income section of the community to bear a greater and greater proportion of the total taxation burden.

We oppose these measures also because of their overall effect on family living standards. As we have said over the past week or so outside this House and, I think, inside it, the impact will be in the order of $4 a week for a family. That calculation comes simply from dividing the total annual tax revenue by the number of people in Australia, which gives a total tax levy per person of a little over $60 a year-that is, more than $1 a week. For a family of four that means an amount of about $4 a week. In fact, it comes to about $4.70. Because part of the sales tax burden will bear on mining companies and some other bodies which will not be able to pass the cost on to consumers, we can just round that figure off to about $4. This is probably a very generous rounding-off. It would seem to us that there will be an increase of at least $4 a week for a family of four. I would like to know how the Treasurer gets a figure of about $1.50 to $2, which is the figure that he keeps using. It seems to us to be a figure which is totally unjustifiable on the basis of the amount of revenue which he says his tax will raise-almost $900m in a full year. That must mean a burden per head of population over $1 a week. Clearly, that will impinge on family living standards to a significant degree. It is not some minor element, as the Treasurer tries to make out.

Also, of course, in looking at that effect we are looking at the impact of the tax revenue. We are not there looking at the total impact on consumers which will more than likely be greater than the tax revenue because wholesalers will add the tax to their price. But the retailer will then place mark-ups on the price from the wholesaler which will include the wholesale increased tax. So the mark-up by the retailer to the consumer will mean that where there is a 2 1/2 per cent rise we will more than likely see an increase well above that. Those increases are likely to mean that for an increase of 2 1/2 per cent with a 20 per cent mark-up, one will see a 3 per cent effective tax rate. For a 50 per cent mark-up it will be 3.75 per cent rather than 2 1/2 per cent as the Treasurer suggests.

For all of the reasons I have given we are strongly and implacably opposed to these measures. In asserting that opposition we are being totally consistent with the view which we have taken in the past in respect of indirect taxation measures in general. Also we say that we have a right, as an opposition, to oppose tax measures. That is in no way inconsistent with the statement which we have made many times that we do not believe that the Opposition ought to block Supply. This is not blocking Supply. We are not suggesting a blockage of the Appropriation Bills and therefore putting the Government in jeopardy. All that we are saying is that there ought to be a blockage of these tax Bills because they are not in the best interest of this country. It is consistent with the fact that we have opposed various tax Bills in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Mr G.O'H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) has given, as is usual, an objective and moderate summing-up of the economic situation revolving around these sales tax Bills. I want to do as he has done and that is touch on the generalities before I speak on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill, the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1 to 9) and the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A). I will do this very briefly. What intrigues me is the sort of credibility gap that is left once we have listened carefully to the speeches by the honourable member for Gellibrand or, indeed, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden).

SPEECH.PARA: The community knows and understands very well that the Opposition, in government, has a role of higher expenditure than the current Government, although it tries, from time to time, to reverse the argument. It does not take a lot of horse sense to know that, if one adds up the costs of many of the Australian Labor Party's bills, we need more revenue to finance them. Yet, what do we see? The Opposition has been against the razor gang reports by and large. It has been against the health package which the Government has brought down and which has been the biggest single saving on government expenditure of this Budget. It objects to the run down that this Government is pleased to have been able to take a part in by taking account of redundancy in trying to cut back on the number of civil servants that perform their functions for the community properly and well. Now it objects to the sales tax measures. So, there is an enormous credibility gap over what the Opposition will do under similar situations. I repeat that, in government, it would need more revenue than this Government to finance it schemes. Yet it objects to every cutback in government expenditure that the Fraser Government is bringing about to try to achieve a better balance on behalf of the consumers and the people of Australia. I think that point needs to be taken into account.

The honourable member for Gellibrand says he opposes these Bills. He looks on them as being regressive legislation. That is a simplistic argument and one that can be readily believed out in the consumer marketplace. This is not necessarily true at all. Really what these sales tax Bills do is to put a higher tax on people who spend up. Whether they come from one section of society or another they really are the losers. But there is another side to it. If one looks at the overall Budget strategy and sees that there is a downward thrust of some form of expenditure, particularly on luxuries, then, indeed, it does not even necessarily become highly inflationary. Certainly, there is a check on the bare direct figures in an indirect fashion.

It is my view-I have no doubt that it is the Government's view; I certainly support it-that by broadening the base of taxation in this sense we will relieve pressure on direct taxation measures that are currently running, as I remember the figure, at around 52 per cent-or a little less, I think-of total government receipts. I hope that the action, coupled with the Government's attempt to control this sort of extravagant expenditure, which in many instances it can be, will make it possible to continue to increase its policy of cutting back on direct taxation, that is, on income tax as it affects ordinary people in the community. If it is able to do that, that will give tremendous encouragement to those people to get off whatever it is they sit on, and invent and perform jobs that one perceives, every now and again, people are doing within the atmosphere of the community generally. I can think of dozens of jobs in the community, some of them owing their basis to the Community Youth Support Scheme, where people from that base have found imaginative ways of earning themselves a living and frequently starting up their own small industries. The Government hopes these policies will enable more people to do that-not less-and that more people will look after their own future identities and future progress in life, and not find it necessary to depend on the Government for every implication of their daily lives.

I have noticed in a series of documents lately the full six-year program put out by President Reagan of the United States. Of course, it is a document of considerable impact on the American community. The mere fact that the program adds to its impact over a period of two or three years and continues to six years is obviously a matter that must be carefully looked at by the Government. I have noticed Press reports fearing that there will be a burgeoning or a blow-out of the United States of America deficit, given the current changing circumstances of the state of its economy. That may or may not be correct. What a foolish government it would be in Australia if it did not take that sort of reform, as I see it, into account and judge what is happening as a result of it. I think that, contrary to the honourable member for Gellibrand asking about taxation cuts, the proper way for the Government to act would be to see what would happen in relation to those enormous tax cuts that President Reagan has brought down and try to learn from the early years of their implementation. No doubt what I can say is that in the life of the Parliament I am confident that-if the honourable member for Gellibrand is patient-all will be revealed. I hope it is.

I hope that the lesson that the Government can learn from the American experiment will be such that it finds itself in a position of lower interest rates and lower inflation from which it can start from a proper base to bring about some of the reforms already in place in America. That is as it may be, but I do not detract from the fact that the sales tax Bills which are before us now are obviously part of any reform of the taxation system from the point of view of where I sit. I think it is an important part. Later in my speech I will certainly touch on one or two anomalies as I see them, because there has never been a package of Bills as complicated as this. There are one or two matters that deserve study in the future. I will touch particularly on the anomalies clause.

Might I just get back to where I should have been in the first place and remind the House that the Bills can really be divided into three categories as has been stated by the Treasurer (Mr Howard). The first relates to the 2 1/2 per cent increase on goods currently subject to sales tax. The second relates to an increase in scope or a broadening of the base of sales tax. The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill is the anomalies Bill to which I intend to refer in a little more depth later. In these general remarks I ought to state how lucky my electorate, South Australia, and indeed other States, where the wine industry has a lesser impact that it does in my own State, must feel now that wine has been put with foods and medicines in the items that will be exempt. I do not suppose that anyone who argued that there should be no tax on the wine industry would have any idea of the extent of that exemption and its value in relation to other goods. I think the wine industry would be very foolish if it did not absorb the lesson of that particular differentiation. The wine industry must be counted extraordinarily lucky indeed that in this Budget it has escaped the net of sales tax. I add that if there were an argument favouring the introduction of a tax on wine-I am sure the argument would be lost on many honourable members in this House-it would also have to be remembered that since the Whitlam Government brought down changes to the standard valuation under section 31A of the Income Tax Assessment Act and introduced section 31B, the wine industry as such has been paying off the sum of, as I remember it, $22.5m. Whereas many people thought that after 6 1/2 years that payment would have been complete, the fact is that many firms have not yet completed that payment and are paying company tax plus up to 10 per cent extra in tax. On that basis, those firms are the most highly taxed in Australia today. So there is some justification for the wine industry escaping this tax. I suppose one could argue-I certainly did-that an awful shakeout in the industry is currently going on. It is a very vertically integrated industry insofar as the raw material producer has no other real outlet for his raw material. That shakeout is going on right throughout the various stages of the industry with no profitability of any consequence.

TALK.START.PARA: —God you talk some nonsense.
—I know the way in which the honourable member for Port Adelaide argues, but in justice to him I will not repeat his argument.
—I have given up drinking. That is how bad it was.

—I thought that the honourable member had been a teetotaller for most of his life. What I am saying is that there is no profitability throughout the various levels of the wine industry today. I suppose there must have been a persuasive argument that influenced the Government-that if firms are going broke under the present shakeout proceedings, why introduce a tax on the industry thereby ensuring that the Government is blamed for something that is already occurring? Of course, the great love for quality wines of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is renowned. I have no doubt that that in itself and statements he may have made from time to time have had an impact on this decision.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to what I was saying a while ago. The wine industry would be very stupid if it were not extraordinarily grateful for the position it is now in. It must be a tremendous relief to the industry considering the other commodities which currently come under the net of these sales tax Bills. I was also interested in that element of the speech of the honourable member for Gellibrand in which he questioned the consistency of the remarks made by the Treasurer earlier in the year in the autumn session. Let us be quite fair: We have before us a smallish Bill affecting revenue to the extent of about $800m. What the Treasurer was patently saying at that time was that the Government had no intention of moving into a total retail turnover tax-a tax on goods and services and a package which, it is well acknowledged, would have raised revenue amounting to more than $3,000m. Let us face it; there is really no comparison between those two statements.

But what excites me much more is the fact that the Labor Opposition has said from time to time, and I gather one other party has also said it in another place, that the Government did not have a mandate, through its policy speech at the last election, to introduce sales tax. That statement raises thousands of anomalies. But let us just follow through the case of the wine industry which I know best. The first attempt at taxing it was by Scullin in 1929. He made no reference to such a tax in his policy speech. If honourable members want to see the record of the Melbourne Argus at that time on this tax, they are welcome to it. I have a copy here. Bury, as Treasurer, also brought down an excise on wine. Was it announced in a policy speech? Of course it was not. It had no relation to a policy speech, nor did that Government have a mandate for it. When the Whitlam Government came to office in 1976, did it really make a policy speech statement to the effect that it was going to remove section 31A from the Income Tax Assessment Act? Of course it did not. More latterly, in terms of this Government's action, it is quite true that there was nothing in its policy speech to forecast this matter. The whole history of this nation is studded with revenue raising moves that are not mentioned in policy speeches. So it is gigantic humbug for the Opposition to try that one on through the Press as it is currently doing.

My friend, the Deputy Government Whip, has asked whether I could save a little time for other honourable members who wish to make a contribution to this debate; so I will move very quickly to the anomalies section itself. That section comprises Bills Nos. 1 to 9 which deal with anomalies, exemptions and inconsistencies. The Government has of course, a big problem when it tries to remedy an anomaly because so often an attempt to resolve an anomaly results in a worse one arising in its place. I will touch on an example of that in a few minutes. I wish to comment, as I am sure other honourable members participating in this debate will no doubt wish to, on the matter that affects my electorate the most-that is, the matter of farmers' trucks and contractors' trucks, which have been brought into the 17 1/2 per cent tax category. Due to an anomaly which previously existed, they did not attract sales tax at this level. I think it is proper to go back in history which, of course, only members as venerable as me are capable of doing-there are some rare exceptions-and look at the time when this tax exemption status was given to trucks. It was brought in at a time when export grain returns were very low and when many cereal farmers were experiencing a high level of non-profitability in their enterprises. It was apparent to almost everybody that of all the enterprises of that kind the most inefficient were the labour intensive, small grain producing farms in Australia. It was equally obvious that the productivity of those farms could be improved by increasing the size of the farms but more particularly by increasing mechanisation. It was felt that an improvement in this very consequential area of export earning income in those days-in spite of the low prices received by farmers-could be brought about by proper and more efficient use of mechanised measures. So the Government of the day acted by introducing those exemptions. One of the most productive and most efficient industries throughout the length and breadth of the land is the whole bulk handling side of the grain industry as it exists today. But in the wake of the exemptions came all the anomalies in the world.

Successive government wondered why an exemption was given in the case of a wheat or grain farm but not a livestock farm. In turn, the contractors who contracted their big trucks for profit and were not rural producers in the true sense of the word also became used to claiming successfully for exemption of sale tax on the vehicles they purchased. So, from the point of view of my electorate, I was naturally unhappy that the Government had to uncover that anomaly. But there is a lot of logic in the Government's move. Why should some of the people I have mentioned receive exempt status for purchases of large trucks when others cannot? The whole thing either had to be extended even further or the anomaly had to be patched up. I do not see anything wrong with the Government's logic in this respect. If a government is trying to produce a domestic surplus of $1,500m, in my view that sort of action is perfectly justified. I, as a Government member, will of course stand up in the bush and elsewhere for the wisdom of that decision.

I have time for only just one other example. I think the Government is creating another anomaly by trying to do away with one. I refer to a very small industry, but a growing one, which produces glace fruits. It is mostly South Australian based except for the glace side of the pineapple industry in Queensland. It deals with seven major varieties of fruits. I will not run through them. That small industry has a 40 per cent export component which is increasing. Its competition is crystallised fruit which is brought in entirely from France. Crystallised fruit has attracted a 15 per cent sales tax in the past. The competitive position has been altered materially so that both products now attract sales tax of 17 1/2 per cent. So, to that point, one might ask: 'Where is the anomaly?' The anomaly is that glace fruits were removed from the fruit category to the confectionery category in spite of the fact that a very quick process retains the structure of the fruit and the fruit sugar-fructose. One must compare glace fruit with the French produced crystallised fruit. That fruit is soaked in a sugar solution for a fortnight. Both the fibre and the sugar are broken down and replaced by beet or sugar cane sugar. The final analysis of the crystallised fruit is 80 per cent sugar, not 52 per cent fruit and fruit sugar. There is an important difference. I believe the Treasurer intends to check out my contentions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another South Australian industry closed down.

—The honourable member should tell me about the wine industry. That would keep him quiet for a while. I hope that the Government will have a careful look at the small glace fruit industry. If my contentions are correct I believe that a correction should be made on another occasion.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation indicates the Government's decision to move in the longer term from dependence on direct taxation for revenue to a much greater dependence on indirect taxation. Of course we ought to put that into context. Since 1975, the Government has been sharply increasing indirect taxes. Prior to the current move to impose a much wider range of sales taxes across the board, the Government gained a very large part of its total revenue from taxes on petrol. Over the past five or six years, the Government will have collected $10 billion in tax on petrol alone. In the current year, it will collect $3,357m, a very significant proportion, perhaps nine per cent, of total revenue. The movement towards indirect taxation in the form of the petrol tax does not have a very long future. I believe that in this legislation the Government is anticipating the fact that revenue from the tax on oil will decline and it is looking for another form of taxation which perhaps will not be recognised by the general public in a direct way in the sense that an increase in income tax might be recognised.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have before us is very much the thin end of the wedge. The Government is building up sales taxes as an increasingly important proportion of its total revenue. I think it is important to say that because this Government does not proceed, on the whole, on a rational basis in any sense but narrow political sense. It is not engaged in any kind of overall program of tax reform. These sales tax proposals cannot be described as a tax reform package. A few months ago, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) floated the idea of a value-added tax. There were debates and discussions about that. At the time he argued about the need for a different mix in taxation. Of course, when the debate got under way the Treasurer and the Government retreated. In this Budget sales taxes were dramatically increased as part of a move which is very much in line with the move that the Treasurer was contemplating some months ago.

It is important to emphasise that this is not part of any overall program of policy reform. Whilst the Asprey Committee, for example, recommended the introduction of VAT and canvassed the possibility of increases in sales taxes, it did so within the context of a number of proposals which would have led to sweeping reforms in the tax system if they had been adopted. The Committee saw the need to look at the question of equity in consumer taxes, and in an overall program of reform, to provide for a system of tax credits for lower income families to compensate for the obvious inequitable character of an increase in sales taxes. It also recognised the need at the other end of the scale to introduce capital and capital gains taxes to assist in providing a level of equity to the overall system of taxation. I do not think it would be possible for the Treasurer to argue that what he is about is in any sense an equitable system of taxation. Yet equity is one of the fundamental principles, though not the only principle, by which a system of taxation ought to be judged.

No doubt the measures which have been introduced by the Government will result in a further sharp increase in the degree of inequity which is being built into the taxation system as a whole. The increases in sales tax will collect another $150 to $200 a head from the Australian population, a very sharp increase in the total burden of taxation. This is being done without compensating effect to cushion the impact of those changes on lower income families. Alongside these proposals there is nothing from the Government in terms of either capital taxes or the resource rent taxes so strongly favoured by the Treasury. Nor on the other side is the Government concerned to bring about any dramatic change in the social security system along the lines of a negative income or a guaranteed minimum income as has been canvassed, for example, by Professor Henderson in the poverty inquiry. Furthermore, the imposition of indirect taxation in this case and in the earlier cases I mentioned seems to run directly counter to the Government's professed strategy. The Government is introdcing taxation which must be inflationary. In the Government's own policies it hardly seems to be concerned about inflationary impacts. Inflation has been built into the system as a result of its oil pricing and taxation policies, the health insurance changes this year, and now the imposition of a heavy indirect tax.

I think we can say quite confidently that, with these sales tax measures alone, another one per cent will be added to the consumer price index. We can look at examples of where this sales tax is going to fall. As the shadow Treasurer has indicated, the impact will be very much on the ordinary family. For example, as a result of sales taxes imposed on building materials, $500 or $600 is likely to be added to the price of a house costing in the range of $35,000. It is a very severe impost in a situation where, because of the rise in interest rates, it is becoming increasingly difficult for ordinary people to purchase their own homes. The Government says that it is on about home ownership. When we look at the Government's record we see that it is on about reducing the opportunities of people to own their own homes.

We could also look at the impact of sales tax on transport. We are talking about very basic areas of people's expenditure-housing and transport. As a result of the increased imposition contained in these measures, the prices of cars are likely to rise considerably. For example, a Holden Gemini will cost $116 more, a 6-cylinder Commodore will cost $168 more and a Datsun Bluebird will cost $130 more. At a time when the vehicle industry is not exactly in a very healthy condition we find that the Government is moving to make it more difficult for people to purchase cars. I would have thought we ought to be stimulating the market, if anything, and not depressing it at a time when there is so much uncertainty about the future of the industry.

We can look at increases in sales tax on a whole range of consumer goods, which I will come back to in a moment. These increases will represent a massive difference to the cost of living for the normal family. It has been estimated that they will cost a four-person family an additional $245. These unfair increases will swallow up any increases in family allowances, which, of course, are not being provided for what is regarded as the average family in Australia-a man, his wife and two children. They have to be looked at in the context of a Budget which will allow income tax to rise by 21 per cent-well above the expected rate of increase in incomes this year. This is also happening in the context of a government which, through its changes to medical insurance, will add $10 a week to the costs for the average Australian family.

It has been said, but it needs to be said again, that this Government is entirely insensitive to the effects of its policies on ordinary families. The principal impact of these changes, it cannot be emphasised enough, is not going to hit the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) or those people that the Government parties represent. It is going to hit ordinary people living in the suburbs of the cities and in the provincial centres of this country. I am talking about doubling, from 2 1/2 per cent to 5 per cent, the sales tax on basic furnishing items, such as crockery, glassware, cutlery, washing machines, vacuum cleaners, radiators, light fittings, candles and so on. These increases mean that those people who are trying to get themselves established in a most difficult economic climate are having an additional impost placed on them. The increases will affect their capacity to get a vehicle, which is no longer a luxury but an abolute necessity for people living in the suburbs of the great cities. There will be increases in the prices of a whole range of items covering cosmetics, shaving creams and hair oils. The cost of television tubes is to go up by perhaps $70-perhaps more-as a result of the imposition of increased sales tax.

Of course, the public is not aware of all these increases because the Government, in its announcements, did not place very much emphasis on the Schedules to the Bills, on the lists of items, and on the comprehensiveness of the imposts which are now being placed on so many of the basic consumer items which ordinary people need. There are some basic points which need to be made. This Government has no interest at all in equity. The Government is not interested in providing support for low income families-quite the reverse. The Government bears down on people on lower incomes. It is not interested in equity. It is not interested in providing any kind of effective tax in relation to wealth. The Government, which professes to be concerned about the housing and building industry, has taken, by these measures, a massive swipe at the building industry, which is already being crippled by very high interest rates. It has, through these measures, added significantly to the price of a family home. It has raised the cost of purchasing and running the family car. It is making basic necessities more expensive.

Again the Government appears to have quite ignored the employment implications of its decisions. The impact of increasing sales taxes on clothing, footwear and other basic consumer items means in reality that there will be considerable difficulty in maintaining employment in those areas, and certainly the costs will be passed on to ordinary consumers, because we are talking about items for which the price is inelastic. These decisions, in my view, show a cynical disregard for the employment prospects of thousands of Australians. The moves have to be placed within the context of the Government's determination to bear down in every way on manufacturing industry in this country. It is not simply that matters are being referred to the Industries Assistance Commission and that levels of protection will almost certainly be reduced. It there is a chance to have a go at manufacturing industry, this Government is prepared to take it; and these sales tax measures are an example of that.

The Government, in its obsession with resource-based development, has allowed capital inflows to occur at a massive rate without any control over those flows to ensure that they go to the development of new industry. On the other hand, the Government, by these measures, is showing no great sympathy for the state of existing industry. The imposition of sales taxes, as the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) has indicated, is essentially unfair. They, along with other measures that the Government has taken, redistribute the burden unequally. At a time when we have a severely contractionary Budget, we have these measures which are likely to prove contractionary within the context of the overall economy.

The Government is in fact signalling a long term change in the taxation mix, but once again it has not had the honesty to say that that is what it is really about. It has not really set the changes within the context of overall reform of the taxation system. It has simply slipped in these changes in a way which means that their impact is hidden and will unfold in future years so that we can expect to see sales tax used in a way in which historically it has never previously been used in Australia.

I believe this question of sales tax represents once again the priorities of this Government. Its priorities are to reduce the living standards of ordinary Australian families and to redistribute negatively. Its priority is certainly not taxation reform. It is certainly not on about reducing the taxation burden on ordinary families. It is a cynical government which uses taxation by stealth to ensure that people have as little opportunity as possible to protest against its policies. Policy is, in fact, this Government's enemy. It rules by instinct, and its instinct always is to operate in a way which protects the interests of its supporters and ignores the interests of the overwhelming majority of Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was an interesting contribution from the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe). He seemed to conflict directly with the supposedly alternative Budget of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden)-that rerun of the 1976 alternative Budget. The honourable member for Batman said that the Government was interested only in attacking industry whereas the Leader of the Opposition said only the other night that the Government was not interested in people but was interested only in industry. I wish members of the Opposition would make up their minds about what they really believe.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills are to implement three Government decisions outlined in the Budget. The first group of Bills is to increase by 2 1/2 per cent the existing rates of sales tax as they apply to sales taxable items. The new rates of sales tax will be effective as from Budget night. The second group of Bills is to implement the Budget decision to correct a number of anomalies and inconsistencies in the sales tax law. This will mean that a number of items previously sales tax exempt will now be taxed at the rate equal to that applied to other light goods in their class. It will also mean that some goods will now be exempt from sales tax. This is consistent with the exemption applied to other like goods in their class. I shall deal later with one of those items in this category. Finally, the third set of Bills relates to the imposition of a 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on a number of items previously not subject to sales tax.

The Treasurer (Mr Howard), when announcing the new sales taxes, said that there is advantage in some change in the mix of direct and indirect taxes to increase the potential for desirable reductions in direct taxes and particularly personal income tax as economic and budgetary conditions permit. Honourable members will recall that the Government has on two occasions reviewed the nature and source of the Commonwealth Government's revenue, particularly as it relates to the composition of taxation as between direct and indirect taxes. On both occasions, for a number of reasons, the Government did not decide to introduce a new broadly based indirect form of taxation. Whilst these new sales tax initiatives involve a slight shift in emphasis they do not constitute a new, broadly based tax because major areas such as the service industries are not subject to these new or increased tax rates. However, it is a small step towards reducing our dependence on personal tax as a source of revenue and relying a little more heavily on indirect tax whilst maintaining the tax free status of basic food items.

If we look to the proportions of revenue raised by personal income tax, company tax, customs, excise and sales tax and the crude oil levy we see that over the years the proportion of the Commonwealth Government's revenue raised from personal income tax increased from 34 per cent in 1958-59 to a peak of nearly 57 per cent in 1977-78. Personal income tax now provides more than half the total tax revenue for the Commonwealth Budget. Over the same period customs, excise and sales tax as a proportion of the total Budget have fallen from around 40 per cent to just over 20 per cent. Clearly, we now rely on income tax as the major source of our revenue and indirect taxes make a much smaller contribution to our total income. As time goes on this reliance on personal income tax is likely to increase because the income from one of the forms of indirect tax, that is the crude oil levy, will directly decline in future years as Australia uses up its old oil resources and becomes more dependent on the more recent oil discoveries which are not subject to the crude oil levy.

Therefore, whilst our overall tax burden is lower than the average of the industrialised world and whilst our level of personal tax is lower than the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average, over time we have become more reliant on personal income tax and less reliant on indirect taxes. Also our indirect taxation tends to be concentrated on a limited number of items unlike, for example, most European countries. In my view there are a number of advantages in redressing this shift toward a greater reliance on personal income tax. Also, bearing in mind as I have said that revenue from the crude oil levy is likely to grow less rapidly in the years ahead, this would have further aggravated the imbalance. I therefore welcome the Government's initiative to increase our reliance on indirect taxation rather than direct taxation and also to spread the base of that indirect taxation in order to include goods which were not previously taxed.

The arguments for a change in emphasis in our tax raising mechanisms are numerous. Firstly, personal income tax, being an extremely visible form of taxation, can become a disincentive for people to increase their work effort and income if the tax rate is such that they believe their marginal return is not worth the effort. I am firmly of the view that lower, rather than higher, income tax rates will increase the incentive for people to earn extra income and therefore increase our standard of living through increased production and increased productivity. Secondly, indirect taxation has the advantage of being somewhat harder to evade and avoid than personal income tax. Of course the disadvantage is that it is likely to contribute to an increase in the consumer price index. However, as the Treasurer has mentioned, the increase in the CPI, and so the inflationary impact of the imposition of these taxes, is likely to be small.

It could also be argued that a heavy reliance on indirect taxation such as sales tax can be regressive depending on the rate of tax and the items which are included in the tax base. Clearly, this current change will not result in a heavy reliance on sales tax. I believe one would be hard put to sustain this argument in the present circumstances. Having explained that I believe the Government's initiative in undertaking this move to increase indirect taxation is a good one as it constitutes a small step to redress what I believe is becoming a fundamental imbalance in the source of Commonwealth revenue, the question then arises as to why the Government did not reduce income tax at the same time as it increased sales tax.

The revenue which is expected to be raised from these sales tax moves is, in this financial year, around $553m. That revenue could have been used to increase the domestic surplus, as has been done in the Budget or for personal income tax deductions. For example, that money would have enabled us to increase the tax threshold by about $250. That is a reduction in tax of about $4.80 a week for the ordinary taxpayer. The Government decided against this course and instead will use the money to reduce the amount the Government would otherwise have had to borrow. The Government believes the Australian community will be best served by a reduction in the Government's borrowing requirements, and this move seeks to take the steam out of interest rate increases. Last financial year the Commonwealth, State and local governmens borrowed in excess of $4,000m. The amount to be borrowed this year can be reduced by a domestic surplus, such as predicted in this Budget, and thereby interest rates will be reduced below what they would otherwise be.

The question then for the Treasurer was whether to use the sales tax revenue for tax reductions or to try to take the steam out of interest rate increases by using the revenue to lower our loan requirements. On my calculations a one per cent increase in interest rates on a $30,000 home loan would more than wipe out the $4.80 tax benefit which could have arisen if the sales tax revenue had been used to reduce income taxes. Therefore, if the Government had used the sales tax revenue to reduce income tax rather than try to reduce interest rates the general Australian public could well have been worse off because the tax benefit may have been absorbed by increased interest rate payments. The Government has taken the sound course of bringing pressure to bear on the interest rate problem, and this will benefit all Australians. Clearly once interest rates are reduced and become more stable the Government will be in a better position to reduce income taxes and so move towards the restoration of a reasonable balance in our reliance on indirect and direct sources of taxation.

I now refer to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill which alters the sales tax classification of certain goods. Over time a number of anomalies have become evident in the sales tax treatment of a number of goods, and this Bill seeks to remedy some of those. One particular anomaly which seriously affected my electorate relates to the timber industry. I first raised this matter with the Treasurer in 1978. As far as I am aware, all equipment used in felling and removing timber from the forest to the roadside is tax exempt, except log forwarders. When introducing this Bill the Treasurer stated:

The expansion of logging of softwood forests has led to the development of specialised equipment called log forwarders, to haul the felled logs from the felling point in the forest to roadside pick-up points.

I am delighted that the Government has accepted that in the interests of equity and consistency a sales tax exemption will now be provided for log forwarders. The sales tax involves between $10,000 and $20,000 per log forwarder and it may well be more now, depending on the price of log forwarders. A number of these pieces of equipment are in use in the pine forests in the south-east of South Australia, serving the mills in the Mount Gambier, Millicent, Nangwarry, Kalangadoo, Mount Burr, Penola and other areas. The Government has now removed the restriction placed by the imposition of this tax on the use of this technogically advanced equipment. I am sure that not only the people using the log forwarders but also the whole of the timber industry will benefit from this rational decision. I might add that I also welcome the Government's decision to exempt from sales tax protective clothing of a kind used for sport or recreation such as helmets, guards, gloves and mittens.

One area on which I believe the Government must keep a close eye is the administration of the collection of the new taxes. We must continually review the administrative procedures in order to ensure that we minimise the inconvenience to the public and especially to small businesses, which in some cases will have to administer the collection or the exemption claims arising from the imposition of these new taxes. That matter must be the subject of continual review to ensure that the burden, especially that imposed on the small businessman, is not unreasonable. I conclude by supporting the Bills and welcoming the Government's initiative in moving away from an even greater reliance on personal income tax as the major source of Government revenue.

The paper went on to state that personal consumption and services areas which are not presently taxed could be looked at with the purpose of taxing possibilities. What we see, therefore, in these measures which are covered in the legislation before us at present is that they largely follow the suggestions put forward by the 1974 Treasury Paper, which incidently were not proceeded with by the Government of the day-a Labor Government. The Department of the Treasury and the Treasurer obviously are concerned only with measures which will increase income without giving any consideration to the effect they have on the Australian community. What these increases mean is that the Government is seeking to balance its Budget by taxing the Australian community a further $811m this financial year. These increases will mean that a typical family will pay out between $3.50 and $4 a week more for their basic weekly requirements because of the impost of additional sales tax. For those families with a number of children going to school, it will mean even higher increases because of the clothing content involved.

What we have is yet another one of the Government's broken promises. The Treasurer stated on 12 March this year, when he announced the Government's decision not to proceed with the introduction of a new broadly based indirect tax, that the Government was anxious to 'minimise the inflationary consequences of collecting additional revenue' and that it did not wish to 'move towards greater reliance on indirect tax without providing a noticeable offset in personal tax reductions'. Quite contrary to these promises, taxpayers will now be slugged with an extra $892m increase in sales tax in a full year which, the Government admits, will add at least 0.75 per cent to the inflation rate. Increased sales taxes are completely reprehensible as they hit hardest at those on the lowest incomes. Many articles essential to the family budget will be hit. Sales tax on furniture, floor coverings, whitegoods, crockery and bedding is to be doubled, from 2 1/2 per cent to 5 per cent. Not only will increased interest rates mean a higher cost of buying one's home but also will it now be even more expensive to furnsih it and live in it. Clothing, building materials, shoes, books and newspapers will all be subject to the new 2 1/2 per cent tax, with the tax on school books costing parents an extra $6m a year. The increased family allowances for large families will quickly be eaten up by the higher cost of keeping children in clothes and shoes. The Housing Industry Association estimates that the tax on building materials is likely to add $1,000 to the cost of building and furnishing a new home. The National Roads and Motorists Association has calculated that the cost of a new 6-cylinder Holden Commodore will rise by $178 and the cost of a 4-cylinder Datsun will rise by $150. Even the oil to run the car will cost 17.5 per cent more. The net result on the family budget of all these increases will be over $4 a week, as I have said. This will have a disastrous impact on family living standards which have already been battered by rising interest rates and more expensive health costs since the last election. Added to the increase in income tax of $11 a week for a family with a breadwinner on average weekly earnings, this means a massive tax increase of $15 a week.

As an indirect tax, these sales tax increases will hurt those families on lower incomes. Whether one earns $10,000 or $40,000 a year, the same costs will need to be borne on items essential to family living. Rather than increasing indirect taxes, the Government should be reducing them so as to ease the pressure on lower income groups in our community. This year increases in sales tax will give the Government a further $892m in a full year. I believe that this legislation is only the beginning, with future years bringing further increases, including increases in the food and services areas. As personal consumption expenditure on food is almost double that of the clothing and manchester area and as servicing expenditure is similar to the clothing area, we can get some idea of the additional sales tax revenue which could be raised by the Government in future years.

The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) stated just a few moments ago that 26 per cent of the household expenditure of lower income groups is spent on food. We can see, therefore, the effect that possible further sales tax increases would have on those people in the lower income bracket, which includes many millions of our fellow Australians. The sales tax scheme is one whereby the Government obtains additional wealth by stealth. The present legislation is another broken promise by the Government. The Government has no electoral mandate for these matters. For that reason and because the Australian Labor Party has a policy to reduce indirect taxation owing to its inequitable sharing amongst high, middle and low income earners, the Opposition opposes the legislation.
