DEBATE.TITLE: DEFENCE FORCE RETIREMENT AND DEATH BENEFITS AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Killen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read for a second time.

The main purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the amendments to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act forecast in the statement I made to the Parliament on 14 May this year. It may assist honourable members in their understanding of the problems that are to be resolved if I were briefly to explain again the essential background.

For many years, contributions and retirement benefits payable under the Defence Force scheme have been calculated by reference to the rate of salary payable in respect of the substantive rank held by members. Additional salary paid on the basis of a higher acting or temporary rank has been disregarded for Defence Force retirement benefits and Defence Force retirement and death benefits purposes mainly because of the transitory nature of the acting and temporary rank arrangements.

In May 1980, the Federal Court of Australia decided, however, that the intended link between 'rank' as defined in the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act and the annual rates of pay regulations made under that Act had not been properly established. Accordingly, as the legislation now stands, acting and temporary rank rates of pay are to be taken into account for both contributions and benefits purposes in respect of all service rendered since the commencement of the scheme on 1 October 1972.

I would emphasise that the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority has no discretion in this matter. It is obliged by the law as it now stands to take contributions on the basis of acting or temporary rank. There is no discretion available, and I would hope that those people who are interested in or affected by the amendments would understand that. As a consequence, a relatively small number of beneficiaries, estimated to be of the order of 550, are entitled to higher retirement benefits; and a very large number of both pensioners and serving members are required to pay additional contributions without any corresponding increase in benefits. I wish to emphasise that. They would have to pay their contributions but there would be no corresponding benefit flowing to them.

I turn now, to the practical effects of the Bill before the Parliament. First, it restores to the scheme, with effect from 14 May 1981, the original intention that a member's contributions and retirement benefits be calculated on the basis of the annual rate of pay applicable to substantive rank held by the member during service. Second, it makes special provision for all those persons who during the currency of the present scheme have held acting or temporary rank, in the way I go on to explain.

Pensioners or beneficiaries entitled to additional pension benefits will be paid these benefits in full, including any available commutation amounts, from the date of their retirement. As from 14 May 1981 however, their pensions will be adjusted by reverting to what they would have been if calculated according to the substantive rank held on retirement and taking account of any additional commutation lump sums received.

The pensioners to whom I have just referred, that is those in receipt of or entitled to an additional benefit, will be required to pay additional contributions based on their acting or temporary rank rate of pay but only in respect of that period of acting or temporary rank service that immediately preceded their retirement. All additional contributions that would otherwise be payable in respect of acting or temporary rank are waived. These are the beneficiaries of whom I have spoken who would be obliged to pay contributions on their acting or temporary ranks and yet would not receive any corresponding benefit. In other words, only persons who retired or died while holding acting or temporary rank and who qualify for higher levels of pension benefits are liable to pay additional contributions to the limited extent that I have indicated. Currently serving members will not be disadvantaged by having to pay higher contributions in future because of their temporary higher rank status.

The other amendments which I have taken the opportunity to include in the Bill, involve the rationalisation of the provisions relating to pensioners who re-enter the Defence Force. They are designed principally to cut down the high costs of additional pension and commutation benefits that so frequently become payable to pensioners who re-enter the scheme for relatively brief periods. In summary, they provide that only pensioners who re-enter on an appointment or engagement for a period of not less than one year shall again become contributors to the scheme. On their second or subsequent retirement they will be entitled to appropriate pension increments for their additional service but be excluded from further access to the commutation provisions. They will no longer be required, however, to repay portion of their commutation proceeds during their period of additional service. Pensioners who re-enter for brief periods of less than one year will not again become contributing members, nor will their retirement pensions be cancelled on re-entry as is currently the case. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Scholes) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of this Bill is to introduce into the Customs Act 1901 new provisions for the valuation of imported goods for Customs duty purposes. These new provisions are designed to give effect to the agreement on implementation of Article VII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, GATT. The Government decided in May 1980 to adopt this agreement on a free-on-board basis, FOB, so as to exclude the costs of overseas freight and insurance from the Customs value. This decision took into account the views of State governments, industry associations and other interested groups within the community.

Australia's present system of Customs valuation is based upon the Brussels Definition of Value, BDV. This compares each actual transaction with an ideal transaction establishing an entirely open market value in an arm's length situation. The major difference between the GATT valuation and the BDV valuation is that the GATT valuation is a positive valuation system using the actual prices and charges for imported goods.

I will now take a few moments to describe the methods by which a Customs value will be arrived at under the terms of the provisions in clause 8 of the Bill. For the purposes of the Customs Tariff Act 1966, the value of imported goods is defined by section 156 as the Customs value of the goods. Section 157 sets out six methods, that are to be applied in sequence, for arriving at the Customs value. I expect that the first of these methods will be the method most commonly used. This involves the ascertainment of the transaction value of the goods which is determined in accordance with section 159.

The starting point for this method will be the FOB price of goods when sold in a relevant transaction prior to their arrival in Australia. The terms 'price' and 'relevant transaction' are defined in section 154. Before it forms the basis for the assessment of the transaction value, the price may be adjusted, if necessary, in accordance with sub-section 154 (2). Further adjustments may also be necessary under section 159.

The second and third methods are based on the transaction values of goods which are, respectively, identical or similar to the goods to be valued. Section 155 provides the basis for identifying identical or similar goods. Section 160 sets out the adjustments that may, if necessary, be made to the values of the identical or similar goods for the purposes of valuing the relevant imported goods.

The fourth method is based on the deductive value of the goods ascertained in accordance with section 161. This method takes as its starting point the price of the imported goods, or of identical or similar goods, when sold in Australia. Deductions are then made, as necessary, to take account of elements reflected in the price because of the transportation of the goods to Australia and their marketing in Australia. The fifth method requires the assessment of the computed value of the goods which is to be calculated in accordance with section 161A. This method is based on the costs of production of the goods, adjusted to take account of the costs and profits that usually would have been reflected in sales of those goods when sold FOB for export to Australia. If all the methods I have referred to fail to establish a value for Customs purposes, sub-section 157 (8) will allow the Comptroller-General to determine the value. In making such a determination the Comptroller-General will be limited by the provisions of sub-section 157 (9).

Section 158 explains the circumstances in which a method of valuation cannot be used. Importantly, a method cannot be used if there is a lack of sufficient reliable information for its use. The first method cannot be used in certain cases, particularly where the relationship between the parties to the transaction influenced the price of the goods. Section 161C confers a right on the owners of imported goods to be informed of the basis on which their goods were valued. Finally, secton 161D provides that the Comptroller-General may review any valuation made by a Customs officer and confirm, vary or replace that valuation with another valuation.

The adoption of the GATT valuation will bring Australia into line with the valuation system practised by other major trading partners such as the United States of America, Japan and the European Economic Community. The Government expects that it will not have widespread consequences for levels of tariff protection now provided to Australian industry. Reference to the Industries Assistance Commission will however be considered during the first year after introduction of the system if any significant variations in customs duty appear to affect adversely Australian industry or importers. The Commission has already been asked to include in all future reports recommendations as to the appropriate levels of assistance under the new system. The new system is also expected to make customs valuation more predictable for importers. It has the support of most main organisations involved in the importation of goods as well as organisations representing local manufacturers.

The other amendments contained in this Bill are of a formal nature. In particular, clauses 6 and 7 propose amendments to section 151 of the Customs Act to delete redundant provisions following the elimination of British preferential tariff margins in the Customs Tariff Act 1966. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Young) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was interrupted we heard a brief outline of the consequences of the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill and the Television Stations Fees Licence Bill from the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins). As he rightly said, these are non-contentious Bills. He explained how, although there will be an increase in revenue from the changes in the design of collecting revenue for the licensing of radio and television stations, a fairer system will be worked out. It will result in a number of radio and television stations in Australia paying lower licence fees than they presently pay. In fact, fees will actually be reduced for 120 of the 130 radio stations. I understand that for 20 of the 50 commercial television stations in Australia licence fees will also be reduced. I think they are fairly significant figures.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Fremantle pointed out that it was always one of the cries of the industry that having a television station licence or a radio station licence was certainly a licence to print money. It is true that that has changed in some degree. If we look at the way radio and television are going in Australia at the moment we find that in certain cases, especially in the case of radio broadcasting, the exact opposite is true. At the moment commercial radio stations in Australia are receiving less revenue from the total advertising cake than possibly they have ever previously received. I believe that this year, for the first time in Australia, outdoor advertising, billboard advertising, will take a greater percentage of the total amount of money spent on advertising in Australia than will radio.

It is important that support be given to the radio organisation in Australia. Commercial radio has served this country very well over the years. It is a tremendous means of communication, especially in outback areas. Obviously we cannot have the situation, which unfortunately has tended to develop in recent years, in which some licencees are even thinking of handing back their radio licences. That situation obviously can be alleviated by the terms of the legislation before the House today.

The honourable member for Fremantle pointed out that these fees represent about 4 per cent additional taxation revenue for the Government. He said that that was probably a good thing because of the controlled and regulated nature of the industry and because of the fact that there were some good profits to be made in some areas of radio and television. I would not argue against that aspect. In fact for many of the metropolitan television stations profits have never been higher. In the case of major metropolitan television stations it is not unusual to hear of turnovers in excess of $200m a year. I understand that one of the top stations in Australia this year made a net profit of about $50m. Those sorts of figures are certainly records, and that 4 per cent can be a contribution towards the betterment of radio and television in this country.

One aspect that could well be looked at by the Parliament is just how we could improve, without too much regulation, some aspects of television in Australia. I suppose that one area-it was raised by the honourable member for Fremantle-which causes very great concern throughout the nation is children's television programs. The Australian Children's Television Foundation has been established and it is doing some work, but I feel that the commercial networks have great difficulties in being able to produce top standard children's television programs. In fact they have great difficulties in finding out exactly what children want to watch on television. I suppose it is all very well for us to ask television networks to spend very big sums of money on devising children's television programs, but frankly they are not much good to anybody if they are not going to be watched. That in fact has been the experience in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Simon Townsend's program is a good one.
—I never have the opportunity to watch Simon Townsend.
—You should watch it.
—It probably is a good program.
—It is for your age group.

The Australian Children's Television Foundation, in a limited sense, is undertaking some of that research, but we could well get the networks together to invest rather large sums of money to physically undertake a most exhaustive survey on how we are going to get young people to watch educational programs-programs that will be of some very real benefit to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Then there is the problem, as I mentioned earlier, of the high cost of making good quality children's television programs. In one of my early speeches in this House I suggested that there could be a system whereby the major commercial television networks and even the Australian Broadcasting Commission would have the opportunity of making contributions to a pool where experimental television could be undertaken with the aim of trying to produce some sort of program that would be accepted by the Australian viewing public, especially young people, and, most importantly, to look at the prospect of exporting those children's television programs. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before dinner, Federal Government assistance in television and the related areas of film and radio has not been as good as it should have been. SPEECH.PARA: I sincerely hope therefore that the comprehensive report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, which was commissioned by this Government and which is a complete review of the ABC will be studied very closely by the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) and the Government. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

In spite of a promise to provide a translator station in that area no definite progress has been made. In fact, the last commitment from the Minister was that the translator would be built in 1981-82 when funds were made available. The Bills going through the House tonight will provide an extra $10m for the Government coffers and I hope that the commitment made by the Minister that this translator would be built when funds were made available will be honoured. I believe the people in that area will be looking to see that some of the funds which are to be collected under this legislation will be used for that purpose.

This promise has not yet been fulfilled in spite of the publicity, prior to the last election, of the previous Minister and the former member for the area who turned up to be photographed turning the sod for the commencement of construction of the translator. The previous Minister was full of promises and very short on action. It is to be hoped that the present Minister for Communications will perform in a more positive manner towards these country people now that funds are being made available through the radio and television licence Bills.

In conclusion, I wish to make a few remarks in support of regional television. The fear of losing national advertising revenue is a genuine worry to many provincial television executives. This is not surprising. Station GVL8 in the Latrobe Valley earned 75 per cent of its total advertising revenue from national advertising in the last year and 25 per cent from local advertising. There has been an increase in local advertising of some 4 per cent since 1978-79. The last figures available from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal show that since the change in that area took place local advertising has increased. Television is a capital intensive industry where high returns are necessary to be able to pay taxes and dividends and to have a reasonable amount of money left over to re-invest in the business. However, high returns on revenue and shareholders' funds does not necessarily mean that regional television stations could stand a change, such as networking, which would destroy them overnight. I urge the Government to move warily on issues such as the satellite system, networking, cable television and other new developments. The Australian Labor Party believes in a strong commercial sector and supports the Bills, particularly as they represent a step in the right direction with a move to a progressive scale of licence fees.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: — Just prior to the adjournment of the House last evening I drew attention to the increasing burden of total individual taxation which was being placed on the shoulders of pay-as-you-earn taxpayers. I mentioned that during the last 16 years, between 1965-66 and 1981-82, the contribution to total individual taxation paid by pay-as-you-earn taxpayers had increased from 67 per cent to 82.7 per cent. At the same time the contribution made by non-pay-as-you-earn individual taxpayers declined from 33 per cent to 17.3 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter has been of considerable, continuing and increasing concern to the Opposition. We are particularly concerned by the fact that this adjustment in the burden of total taxation should have been occurring. The position is that if non-wage and salary earners in 1981-82 were to pay the same proportion of total tax as they paid in 1965-66 they would be paying an additional $3,278m. That is, they would be paying almost twice as much as they are going to pay. Of course, this $3,278m is revenue which is required by the Government for Government purposes and it has to be made up. If it is not being paid by this section of taxpayers, quite clearly it is being paid by wage and salary earners in their pay deductions.

I suppose a number of reasons could be advanced for this situation. One of them is, perhaps, that since 1965-66 there has been a decrease in the proportion of non-wage and salary earners and, therefore, the proportion of tax which they have paid has declined for that reason. In fact, that is not the reason. The proportion of that group of taxpayers was shown in the recent census to be 13.8 per cent. In the 1966 census it was shown to be 14.5 per cent, so the situation is not explained by a decreasing proportion. It could perhaps be explained by a decrease in the proportion of total income being earned by non-pay-as-you-earn taxpayers. In fact, the evidence proves that that explanation is not correct. One reason remains. That is that this particular group of taxpayers has found it possible to engage in tax avoidance schemes which have made it possible for them to reduce their taxation every year, and in the current year to the extent of $3,278m. The Budget provides for tax losses in the current financial year due to tax avoidance schemes by non-pay-as-you-earn taxpayers to the extent of $220m and for companies to the extent of $80m. But not one cent has been provided in the Budget Papers for possible tax avoidance by wage and salary earners, because that facility simply is not available to them.

Just as a final indication of the way in which the burden of taxation is increasingly being passed on to the shoulders of those people least able to pay tax, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which shows the tax rates which have been applied since 1977-78 until this year when the tax scales were compressed into three separate levels and the tax rates which would have applied had full tax indexation been applied by this Government as it undertook to do. If the Government had done that the tax threshold this year, instead of being $4,195, would have been $5,356.

TALK.START.PARA: —One point raised by the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) certainly needs to be commented on. I refer to the curious approach by the Australian Labor Party to the question of tax avoidance. I do not want to dwell on it too much except to say that there has never been a government in Australia's history that has done more to prevent tax avoidance, that has brought in more legislation, that has closed off more tax avoidance schemes and that has saved more revenue than the present Government. It is intriguing that the Labor Government, whose main contribution to preventing tax avoidance was to say that it planned to do something-which it found itself incompetent to do and which eventually was tidied up by this Government-achieved very little except to introduce a set of schemes which totally inhibited investment in the mining sector in Australia. Apart from that, it has an abysmal record on tax avoidance. For it to maintain this phoney criticism of this Government, which has taken so many positive steps to ensure that the tax burden is more equitably shared around Australia, seems to me to be a typical piece of hypocrisy along the lines that we have heard so far in this Budget debate.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another style of hypocrisy in the criticism of this Budget. I refer to the persistent allegation that this Government, which is committed to the concept of small government, which has dramatically reduced the level of rise in government spending, is somehow a secret big government. We have heard members of the Opposition talking about the massive increase in the six Budgets that this Government introduced-an alleged massive increase in Budget revenues. I must admit that I am picking on the Sydney Morning Herald again, but even that newspaper, which I once held in very high esteem in terms of its capacity to editorialise intelligently, is taking a similar line-or perhaps in view of the intellect of members of the Opposition, they got the idea from the Sydney Morning Herald. For example, the Sydney Morning Herald in its editorial of Wednesday, 19 August, the day after the Budget was presented, argued that the Government had done very little to cut back the size of the public sector and said that the Government's own spending was going up. To dramatise that, to prove that this Government is a big government, it then dealt with the question of the receipts of the Government.

This seems to me to underline the massive confusion that exists in the minds of the Opposition and some commentators. Because this Government has certainly increased its revenues over the last six Budgets by a considerable amount, it is accused of being a big Government. What these commentators failed to recognise-I am glad that the honourable member for Hunter lists himself among that group-is that the bulk of the Government's increased revenue has been required to make up the massive gap between expenditure and revenue that was opened up during the Whitlam years. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The statistics I have just incorporated and those that I incorporated in the debate on the sales tax Bills this afternoon show a very significant trend. They show that under the three Whitlam Budgets there was a spending rise in real terms-that is, after taking account of inflation-of $4.7 billion, but an increase in revenue in that time of only $2.6 billion. In other words, there was a $2.1 billion gap between what was raised and what was spent. When the Fraser Government came into power it had to close that gap. That has involved the disastrous situation with which this Government has been lumbered-the cost of closing the gap that was opened up by the previous Government. Let us dramatise the figures. The total increase in spending in six Budgets of the present Government in real terms is $1.5 billion. That is one third of the increased spending of the previous Government in only three Budgets. It is just fascinating, and I am astounded that both the Sydney Morning Herald and the Opposition are incapable of grasping the simple fact that spending under the Whitlam Government in three Budgets alone increased at a rate that was treble the total rise under six Budgets of the present Government.
—Treble!

—Treble! I thank the honourable member for his interjection. It is absolutely unbelievable that the present Opposition which was in government at that time should maintain this nonsense that the present Government is a dreadful, onerous and oppressive government when it has had to pick up that bill which was left for it. I was a massive bill. Let me show the House and the people of Australia how big that bill has been and what the impact has been on this Government. The three Whitlam Budgets increased by only $2.6 billion the total revenues of the Commonwealth, although its spending went up by $4.7 billion. As a result of that the present Government has had to increase its revenue by $4.5 billion in real terms, whereas it increased its spending by only $1.5 billion. In other words, to close the enormous gap, to fill the dreadful hole into which this economy was quietly sinking, the present Government has had to increase its revenue by three times the amount that it has been able to increase its own spending. In other words, it has had all the criticism for increasing its revenue and none of the credit for increasing its spending from those people who, of course, benefit from the spending.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the realities. The Whitlam Government received all the credit for handing out $4.7 billion when it raised only $2.6 billion. The Fraser Government has received all the criticism for having to close that gap, having to raise $4.5 billion, while it has increased its spending by only $1.5 billion over six Budgets. It seems astounding that credit is not given where it is certainly due for a magnificent and successful attempt by this Government to close this dreadful gap from which the Australian economy was bleeding to death. When we look at what this Budget has achieved we see that we have been able to have that tight sort of economic control at a time when we have been able, nonetheless, to increase the number of people in jobs by 330,000 in two years. As I said this afternoon, that is the biggest 2-year increase in the number of people at work in Australia's history. We have been able to do this despite the fact that we have held our taxation rates at levels far below the average in most industrialised countries. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.

—That is the sort of interjection I would expect from the Opposition, which cannot possibly face the reality of what the official statistics show. The only way the Opposition can counter the points I am making is to pretend that the statistics are phoney. They are official OECD statistics. The other statistics I have produced are from the Parliamentary Library. If members of the Opposition want to denigrate the Parliamentary Library and accuse it of dishonesty, it is fine by me. If the Opposition is serious in trying to counter what I am trying to say, it might be useful if it did something positive, rather than sneer at official statistics which were not provided by this Government. Let us look at the statistics. If the Opposition can deny the import of these statistics, let it try later. Let us look at the simple question of revenue from taxes as a proportion of gross domestic product for the OECD countries. One will see that Australia's revenue from taxes in 1978 is listed as totalling 28.8 per cent of gross domestic product. Let us compare that with countries such as Canada with 31 per cent, France with 39 per cent, Germany with almost 38 per cent and the Netherlands with 46 per cent.
—What was it under Whitlam?
—That is typical of the sort of interjection one would expect from the Opposition. The Whitlam Government spent money that it did not have. That it why we have this enormous tax bill and that is why-
—That was like you when you were in the stock brokers.

—I would expect that kind of interjection from the honourable member for Port Adelaide because that is the level of the objection of the Australian Labor Party to the serious points I am making about the economy. It seems to me that the only weapon that the Labor Party has is the weapon of insults, offensive interjections and personal attack. It does not have the capacity to criticise the realities of what the figures show. When the Labor Party can raise its standards, as it attempted unsuccessfully to do at the last election, and debate the issues of this Budget, instead of whingeing about little things, instead of appealing to the base elements, and instead of terrorising the people of Australia by claiming that this is an horrific Budget when it is not, and when the Labor Party can raise its standards above personal abuse, we might get a decent debate in this House on the Budget.
—They never will.

—I agree with the honourable member for Wentworth, they never will. Certainly, they never have in the period I have been a member of this House. I was endeavouring to say that the Netherlands has a percentage of total tax to gross domestic product of 47. In Sweden-that socialist heaven-taxes are 53.5 per cent of gross domestic product, as against 28.8 per cent in Australia. Britain's figure is 34.5 per cent and that for the United States is 30.2 per cent. The OECD average is 35.8 per cent. For honourable members opposite to complain about the tax level in Australia is absurd. It seems to me that, by international comparisons, we have a pretty sound tale to tell. We have a record which, I think, is reasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us see whether the latest increase in taxes on goods is something that is improper, indecent, obscene or anything else that the Opposition wants to pretend it is. According to the OECD survey, Australia was one of the lowest countries in the world in terms of the gross domestic product accounted for by taxes on goods and services. The figure was about 9 per cent, compared to 12 per cent for France, 12 per cent for the Netherlands, 12.7 per cent for Sweden and the OECD average of 10 1/4 per cent. One can see that so far we have lagged behind the rest of the world in the indirect taxes area. It seems to me that the switch that is now taking place in a small way has a great deal of merit in terms of international comparison and in terms of equity. An interesting point which members of the Opposition do not seem to recognise is that the average wage earner in Australia spends something like 40 per cent-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker-
—Does the honourable member wish to raise a point of order?
—Indeed, and it is a genuine one. I am interested in the figures that the honourable member for Macarthur has just quoted for indirect taxes in the OECD.
—The honourable member will explain his point of order.
—I would like those figures to be clarified.
—The honourable member knows that that is not a point of order.

—The Opposition is seeking to waste my time because the points I am making effectively demolish the rubbish that has been maintained in this debate by the Opposition. I turn to the switch to a small degree of indirect taxation revenue, having established quite clearly that indirect taxes as a proportion of total gross domestic product in Australia have been far below the rest of the world. I have said that in terms of equity there is a fair case for maintaining the switch in the way it has been done in Australia. The average wage earner, the average householder, spends something like 40 per cent of his income on items which are subject to these new taxes. In other words, 40 per cent of his income will attract this 2 1/2 per cent increase. But for the lower income earners, something like only 25 per cent of their salary will be subject to taxation of this kind because, as I said this afternoon, they have a higher propensity to consume food.
—What about the pensioners and the unemployed?

—The pensioners have a fully indexed pension which takes fully into account the rises in indirect taxes, which basically affect the rich far more than the poor. However, because this Government introduced full indexation of their income, pensioners will receive, in fact, a full indexation benefit although the bulk of their spending, something like 75 per cent of it, will not be directed towards items on which indirect taxes will be increased in this Budget. So let us nail this question of equity. The fact is that pensioners, who will not have to pay any indirect tax on their food, will receive the benefit of full indexation on all the items on which they do not spend anything more than approximately 25 per cent of their incomes.
—You said that this afternoon. That is exactly what you said this afternoon.

—Exactly. I said it this afternoon, and I am endeavouring to reinforce it. Let us look and see where the Government is spending this money. Where have the big increases been? It seems to me that when the Government is attacked for increasing its spending we should look at issues such as social security. The pensioners are the people who have received the biggest increase in government spending since this Government has been in office. The biggest rise in our spending has been in the area of social security-in real terms an increase of $1.3 billion or 30 per cent since this Government has been in office. Certainly, defence expenditure has shown a rise, and a rise which I am certain has been appreciated by the members of the defence forces in my electorate, for example. The morale of members of the defence forces deteriorated rapidly under the previous Government which reduced their share of government spending to approximately 8.5 per cent. It is now back up to 10.1 per cent. The Government intends to continue to increase that share. I certainly take the view-I believe all members on this side take this view-that that impact on defence morale of the savage manner in which the defence forces were treated under the previous Government has left a scar which is only now beginning to heal with the increase in defence funding. It seems to me that when we see that spending on social security is by far the biggest area of advance in this Budget, we recognise-
—Not so.

—Someone says: 'Not so'. I am comparing this with the last Hayden Budget. I would have thought that might have been an amusing point from which to begin. Certainly, it would raise some hollow laughs opposite. The big increase in social security has been brought about by the recognition by this Government that automatic indexation of incomes for pensioners should take place. It seems to me that the only inhibiting factors in maintaining this Budget, in selling this Budget to the people and in getting rid of the deliberate confusion being created by people opposite that there will be a disaster in this Budget, are some little items which are very important to the people involved but which are not significant in terms of total revenues. The Government is well aware of the fact that I believe it to be a mistake that the Government did not index the pensioner health benefits card. I am also disappointed that something could not have been done about interest rates on home loans, although I recognise the risks involved in that.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite all the criticism from the Opposition about the disaster this Budget will bring upon the nation, I remind members of the Opposition that this is the sort of thing they said about the last two Budgets. It is what they said last year when we had a 3 per cent increase in real spending and more than a 3 per cent increase in household disposable income. The same forecasts are in the Budget Papers for the current year because the increase in indirect taxes this year will be less than the increase in indirect taxes last year. Not one member of the Opposition has had the honesty or the integrity to concede that point. The impact on spending of this Budget in terms of increased indirect taxes will be less than it was last year, and yet despite those rises last year our national spending went up by more than 3 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an atrocious Budget, and the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) knows it. The only thing we can say about his speech is that we will give him marks for loyalty but nothing for matter. Let us put it very clearly: If there were an election tomorrow he would be annihilated in the seat of Macarthur, because the Government has done nothing but redistribute the resources of the people it represents to organisations usually belonging to foreigners. It is significant that a fair segment of the honourable member's speech related to countries other than Australia. Let us look at the facts where this Government is concerned. At page 87 of the Budget Papers the Government clearly admits that at least 2.3 million people are in poverty, because it refers to this estimated number of holders of health cards. The Government admits that itself. This is the sixth Fraser Budget. We will say it is the sixth poverty Budget. It is a Budget that has budgeted for a $1,500m surplus-a surplus which will be extracted from the people's pockets and which will not be given back to them. I will table figures later which clearly will show that in the six Budgets the Government has done nothing but redistribute money from the poor to those who do not need it. That applies right across the board, whether one is talking about social services, health, education, housing or whatever. Every State Premier is against the Government. We in the Opposition have been inundated with telexes from the Government's own supporters-the employers-wondering what in the name of fortune the Government will do about their industry, which the Government has referred back to the Industries Assistance Commission to consider the question of protection. We have been inundated with telexes from those who are interested in the newspaper or publishing industry, saying that this is the only Western democracy to tax information. Where is the Government's support? Is it not about time we tested the Government by asking: 'Where is your mandate?'

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at this matter in detail. The poverty line, as far as the Government is concerned for a family with two children is $200. At least three million Australians fall below that line. So what sort of an economy has the Government created in its six Budgets? Why make excuses all the time, saying that there is a reason for your doing this. Let us look at the Government's history over the period since 1975, when all those promises, whether they related to health schemes, indexation, pensions or whatever, were never kept. These people we are talking about are disadvantaged. The Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty clearly showed that for an Australian family of four to survive it would need $227 a week, and most Australians agree with that. When the McMahon Government commissioned the first inquiry into poverty in Australia, 1.3 million Australians were living below the poverty line. There are now 3 million Australians living below that poverty line-an increase of 1.7 million. In regard to the Government's cover up, Professor Henderson said:
This Government is guilty of trying to suppress the evidence. Obviously it doesn't want the real facts to come out.

Nor should it expect the facts to come out unless we have debate in the Parliament and clearly show the situation. Let me remind all honourable members that if someone is poor, he is disadvantaged. If one is the child of a poor family one is even more disadvantaged because one has to compete with others who are not so disadvantaged. That can apply to health schemes. If one is a child of a poor family one is not as healthy and does not get the same care. It is more likely that one will be hospitalised and suffer from infectious diseases, malnutrition or whatever. The opportunity of having an upper occupation in life is denied one. Statistics clearly show that a poor child has one-seventh of a chance of attending university. There is plenty of evidence of that. If honourable members look at the report of the Karmel Interim Committee for the Australian Schools Commission, which we commissioned when we were in government they will see that it clearly showed that two-thirds of positions in universities were given to the top elite because of the occupational back-up of the parents. All these disadvantaged persons' problems are permanent and are increasing in Australia, whether they be in regard to health, education or housing, or the problems of just being poor. These facts can be verified by any medical authority, any university or any commission of inquiry. What is it that the Government can say is fair and reasonable? In our view, it has no right to penalise the poor parents but in the mind of any Australian it is not justified in penalising the children of the poor, which is what this Government is doing.

Let us look at the facts in regard to wealth distribution in this country. A report given to the University of Sydney showed that 10 per cent of people owned 60 per cent of the wealth and the richest 2,000 people in Australia owned as much as the poorest 2.25 million people. That has never been denied by the Department of the Treasury, and that is information which surely must interest any government because its tax gathering is not limited only to income; it is related to all other aspects of getting income and benefits for all Australians. The Government's duty and obligation is to redistribute those resources back to those people in need. It should give equal opportunities to every Australian to guarantee that this is a strong democracy. Wealth should be shared by those who create it. When we look at our history we see that a small group is getting the benefit and that the great majority of people are bearing more of the burden.

Statistics reveal that 10 per cent of the adult population receive 92 per cent of interest, dividends and rent. One can see that there is a great disparity between what is happening and what should be happening. None of these figures, none of these instances, appear in the Budget columns or get one mention in the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard). One can wade through the jargon that is given as economic theory in the Budget Speech. But we must realise that the Treasurer cannot even understand his own words. I want to draw these facts to the attention of Australians. They live with these problems and they understand them. They expect the Government to understand them also and to bring in a Budget that is mindful to the situation.

Tax collections and Budget allocations are important mechanisms in creating a just society, particularly for the poor, the socially disadvantaged and all vulnerable groups. The whole idea of justice and equality in our democracy is to guarantee that there is a redistribution of wealth in those terms. It has not been done in the six Budgets since 1975. We have to turn back to the eighteenth century to see what has happened. In our system the benefits which accrue to wage and salary earners are not just simply in the form of money wages. Let us make this very clear. There has to be provision by governments in respect of health, housing, recreation, transport, communication, education and social security. In other words, there is another factor, which we will call a social wage, on top of a money wage. In the last six major Budgets, including the last Budget, the Government consistently and savagely cut that social wage. The cumulative cuts amount to $26 billion. At the same time the increased tax take from wage and salary earners, that is, from both non-indexation of taxes and the imposition of new taxes, amounts to $21 billion. There we have it.

Taking both the increased tax grab and the reduction in the benefits of the social wage, almost $47 billion has been extracted from the living standards of Australian people. There has been a $47 billion rip off of wage and salary earners in six Budgets. Accordingly, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard three tables numbered 1, 2 and 3. I have shown them to the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) and he has agreed to their incorporation in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. In six Budgets over six years this Government has extracted over $162 billion in taxes and $90 billion in income tax-most of it from those who pay as they earn, as has been said before by my colleagues. In 1975-76 PAYE tax was 41.7 per cent of total tax collections. This year it has climbed to 45 per cent. What is the converse situation? Company tax was 15 per cent in 1975-76. It has now fallen to 13.7 per cent and profits are rising much faster than wages. This year alone PAYE tax is up 22 per cent while wages have risen only 13 1/2 per cent and company tax has risen only 10.1 per cent. Last year profits rose by 18.2 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: In six Budgets this Government has redistributed more income than any Government in Australian history. The direction of this redistribution has been towards increasing inequality, not just for the poor but for most Australians whether they be in the lower or middle income groups. It should come as no surprise to anyone that this Government holds the record for the greatest budgetary contribution to increasing inequality of any government since the Bruce-Page Government. Yet the Government has not rested on that record. It will now force a similar policy on all State governments. The much vaunted new federalism was supposed to give greater autonomy to the States but it is has done nothing of the sort. New federalism has involved a combination of untruths about what funds are available to the States and then the cutting of those funds.

At the same time the Government is cutting not only its social wage contributions but also the social wage in respect of State Governments. Let me give an example. On 4 May at the Premiers Conference the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced the cancellation of the existing tax sharing formula under which the States got 39.87 per cent of income tax collections. Instead the Government did away with the formula and the States got a 9 per cent increase in the tax sharing funds. They should have got a 15 per cent increase to match the provisions of the previous formula. What does this mean, for example, to New South Wales? In that instance it means that New South Wales gets $143m less from taxes, the taxes which its own people pay. We should bear in mind also the increased sales taxes which will be imposed and which will net over $800m. An amount of $300m will be extracted from the people of New South Wales in sales tax. Is it any wonder that the Government parties will be annihilated in the forthcoming State election? The Commonwealth Government has robbed all State Governments but it has been severely savage on New South Wales.

Let us have a look at some other factors as they apply to New South Wales. The Government in New South Wales was encouraged as a result of a letter from the Prime Minister to accelerate electricity development. So the New South Wales Government applied to get $171m from the Loan Council. That was refused. Again we see a savage attack on New South Wales after it was asked to do something about development in relation to electricity. I understand that the Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales was down here urging the Fraser Government to carry out this sort of policy. I understand that he wants the Prime Minister to campaign for him in the forthcoming election campaign. I suggest that they both remain on sick leave; it is the only chance they have of even getting 10 per cent of the votes. Would anyone in New South Wales want to vote for a Government that does this to the people in that State?

We should look at some other matters in respect of the Federal Government. In the last six Budgets the Federal Government has cut real net payments to New South Wales for housing from $177m to $13.5m. Why has it done that? It is only shifting the responsibility and the burden on to State governments. Let us look at health. I ask the Minister for Health who is at the table whether it is a fact that he has done away with the health agreement. The Budget says so. The Government has a new commitment but the commitment is nowhere near what it was before. I have advice from the New South Wales Government setting out details in the health area. The cuts amount to $100m because the Government will not share the cost burden any more. The Government has said also that it will guarantee that New South Wales imposes higher hospital charges. The Government says in respect of outpatients that hospitals will charge $15 and that it will take from its grant 60 per cent of the fees that are expected to be collected in respect of outpatients. The additional burden for New South Wales in that respect is another $100m.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that is not true.

—It is true. I will show the Minister the figures. The Minister is an honourable man and he would know himself that hospital charges are being increased. He knows that he is going to take from those grants. He knows that the States cannot afford to do this. I am prepared to discuss the matter with him at a later time. The figures I referred to were supplied by New South Wales. In total New South Wales, because of this Government's Budget, is $570m worse off in all fields. How can any Liberal Party member from New South Wales continue to support that situation?

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has done very well. It has boasted that it has increased jobs by 140,000. But most of these jobs, according to research done by the University of New South Wales, are part time. What does part time work do for a person? It means that a person gets poor working conditions, faces short term hiring, no occupational choice, no superannuation, shift work, family disruption and little opportunity if he or she is sick. The Government says that it has done something. Figures clearly show that unemployment in this country totals about 850,000, two and a half times the official figure. The Government knows in relation to the health card which it has been talking about that three million people will be dependent in that area. That is an indictment of its own programs. So as we go through the whole aspect of this Budget and look at the imposition of sales tax we ask ourselves: 'What will it do?' It will extract another $550m from the Australian taxpayer to build up a surplus over three years so that perhaps the Government can give a tax rebate. Is that not what this Government is about? It is taking from Australians who can ill afford it.

Let us talk about the morality of this sales tax. I am amazed at the Australian Democrats in the Senate who say that they have to obtain legal advice in relation to this matter. I must say their legal advice was pretty poor. It has been very clear for some time-the Government is expert at it-that we can always reject a sales tax Bill. I am amazed to hear Senator Mason saying that the Senate will send us a message, but if we do not accept the message they will pass the Bill. I tell him that the Australian Labor Party will not do that. We will oppose the Bill. Fancy anyone worth his salt standing up and saying that he will send us a message but if we do not agree with it that will be all right. I would give them a message. The message ought to be given to the worthy Senator Chipp who, I might add, was a beneficiary of the withholding of Supply in 1975. He even got a short term Cabinet post. He seems to have had a double take as to what the propriety is in this area. Let me make it very clear. We can oppose tax Bills. We have made it clear that we will not reject the annual Appropriation but we can talk about taxes as everybody has done. We are talking about people, their entitlements and what the Government is doing to the families in Australia.

I come to housing quickly because my time is running out. Interest rates have added $55 a month to repayments on a $30,000 loan. Total repayments on that loan have increased by $17,000. In addition, the average family now has to pay 46 per cent of its income in rent. What is happening to our great society? Let us have a look at what foreigners think. They are coming in with their money hand over fist, buying up rural properties and everything they can, because the inflow is not for our benefit but usually to take over existing corporations. It is usually to make advantages for them. So the Treasurer boasts that he thinks this will help us. Help us! My God, from the point of view of what has happened in the last year, 75 per cent of the $6 billion was invested for speculation and takeovers. The figures now show that in the coming year as much as 30c of every dollar saved by Australians will be mobilised by foreign investors to buy more of Australia's resources and assets. They are coming in to take our money and buy our assets. What nation worthy of the name will allow its assets to be sold to foreign investors? When will the Government wake up and see that it cannot transfer our heritage to somebody else? We have the talent, the ability, the integrity and the national spirit to develop our country and we have the money. The quick answer for us is to invite the Government to go to the polls on this Budget. We will give it a chance, because we will reject its sales tax Bills. If it does go to the polls we predict that it will be annihilated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Samuel Beckett's play Waiting for Godot has been described as a play in which nothing happens twice. The same statement could well apply to the package of anti-Budget arguments being delivered to us by the Opposition. Yesterday the Sydney Morning Herald described the speech by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) in this debate as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: From the little we heard, the Opposition's policies don't add up to much.

Since Tuesday night we have heard a succession of Australian Labor Party speakers pour forth so much doom and despair that I wonder if the chief architect of the Australian Labor Party's current arguments is not Samuel Beckett himself. I make no apology for linking the Opposition's arguments with the theatre of the absurd. The two fit together well. The reason is simple. The Australian Labor Party's despair about the economy is so far removed from reality that it is laughable.

Quite the contrary to what the Australian Labor Party would have us believe, the economy is looking good. Fact one is that inflation is down to 8.8 per cent. Fact two is that unemployment is at its lowest level for four years. Fact three is that private investment is up by 20 per cent. This Budget is aimed at improving this pattern of economic success achieved by the Government. It is a Budget that points to continued economic growth in the forthcoming year.

The reduction of the Budget deficit by almost $1,000m, to $146m, should ease the pressures on interest rates and make more funds available to home buyers and others in the community without, at the same time, fuelling inflation. The sensible approach of this Budget will produce lasting success in the economy. On this side of the House we are intelligent enough to realise that one cannot legislate improvements in the economy. One cannot legislate against unemployment or inflation, or legislate for economic growth. But one can create the right conditions in which such improvements can take place. One can create a stable economy for development to take place.

In my electorate, the Northern Territory, the prospect of future development is particularly welcome. Since self-government in 1978 the Budget of the Northern Territory Government has grown from $350m to $756m this year. This reflects not only the transfer of State-like functions from the Commonwealth to the Northern Territory, but also the rapid economic growth in the Territory which has taken place under the Everingham Country-Liberal Party Government. This Federal Budget contains a continuing high level of commitment to the Northern Territory. Members will be aware that the basic framework for financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory is set out in a memorandum of understanding agreed to between the two governments in 1978. Under the terms of that memorandum, the Commonwealth will provide the Northern Territory with $618.9m this year. This is a generous contribution representing $4,765 per capita in the Northern Territory for State-type services.

It is worth while pointing out that over the period 1978 to 1981 the revenue raised by the Northern Territory Government has increased from $60m per annum to $130m per annum. This doubling of the local revenue base has occurred without imposing burdens on local taxpayers except in this year's Northern Territory Budget, which levied a tobacco tax and made other minor adjustments. In recent times and since the memorandum of understanding was negotiated, the Northern Territory Government has had extra functions transferred to it such as regulating uranium mining for which additional funding is necessary and may require close attention to detailed settlement of adequate funding.

Significantly, additional Commonwealth expenditure on its own department such as the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Department of Social Security, the Department of Defence, the Department of Transport and Telecom Australia and on capital works projects also provide an important boost to the economy. Furthermore, these specific Budget items will enhance the development of the Northern Territory and alleviate some of the disabilities of living in an isolated area. For all the Labor Party's screaming one would think that the Government is doing nothing about helping Australia's needy through social security. This Federal Budget will increase social welfare spending by 14.7 per cent or $1,265m.

TALK.START.PARA: —By how much?

—By $1,265m. This means that for every dollar of tax collected 47c goes towards social security payments. In the Northern Territory, some 5,948 families will take advantage of the new provisions for family allowances. Throughout the year I have received a number of complaints about unemployment benefit being paid to the spouse of a person on strike. I am pleased the Government is taking action to halt this situation. I am concerned, though, about the problems of those receiving income security payments in the Northern Territory . Additional assistance in the form of zone allowance does exist for ordinary taxpayers. However, people receiving unemployment benefit, pensions and other social security payments receive no such entitlements which recognise the factors of isolation. I ask that the Government consider some extra form of relief for those on social security payments to counterbalance this discrimination. It is a sad fact of the Northern Territory lifestyle that often aged people are forced to leave for southern States for no other reason than the expense of living in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned before that this is a Budget of development with major implications in the Northern Territory. As honourable members are aware, the most exciting new development in the Northern Territory is the emergence and maturity of the uranium industry. It is pleasing to note that $16m has been allocated for the Alligator Rivers region. With the Australian Labor Party opposed to uranium mining on the one hand and continually apologising to the Northern Territory electorate on the other for its anti-uranium stance, it could not hope to match the high priority which the Fraser Government gives the uranium industry. Of the $16m set aside for the uranium province, $9.9m has been made as a contribution towards Jabiru township, specifically for a hospital, police station and housing. In addition, the Office of the Supervising Scientist has been given $4.2m to monitor uranium mining operations. The National Parks and Wildlife Service has $2.4m to run Kakadu National Park. Coupled with the 25 per cent increase in the Northern Territory Government's Budget allocation for the Territory Parks and Wildlife Commission which has a budget of $15.9m, I hope that the Commission will assume a greater role in the administration and management of Kakadu National Park and, in fact, take over functions from the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service.

Tourism in the Territory is rapidly expanding. It is the second largest industry after mining. The scope for further investment in tourism is unlimited. Finance for Uluru National Park and the provision of $13.4m for national roads, some of which will go towards the first tourist developmental road at Ayers Rock, will provide an important impetus for this industry. Similarly, the massive increase in funding for employment programs comes at an opportune moment in Northern Territory development. Because of a small population base and its isolation, the Northern Territory has had considerable difficulty in attracting skilled workers to the major resource projects. The 31 per cent rise in the allocation for national manpower training programs should go part of the way to providing skilled labour for development. I point out however that the success of these resource projects and, inevitably, the development of the Territory depends on a stable community being created with the development of a stable work force. It is no secret that an effective way of doing this without imposing undue costs on the private sector and eventually on the consumer is by providing some form of tax concession. At the moment this is done by offering a zone allowance tax rebate. With the view to providing consistent and stable development, the level of the zone allowance should be substantial throughout the Territory, including the service port of Darwin.

As we have all experienced, growth is fraught with pains. In the case of the Northern Territory this is housing. The Northern Territory Government in its own Budget this year has been innovative in trying to encourage home ownership and housing development but it is neither possible nor proper for government to meet all housing needs. I challenge the traditional sources of housing finance, banks and building societies to make more of their funds available for home finance in the Northern Territory. The security and the need are both obvious.

TALK.START.PARA: —What interest rates do you suggest?

—It is a matter of getting money, not interest rates. The Labor Party policy would certainly mean that the money would dry up. I turn briefly to communications. With the generous Budget allocation for the Australian Broadcasting Commission, Territorians are expecting an improvement in services. The Australian Broadcasting Commission has provided an excellent service to isolated areas over the years which commercial enterprises have not found viable. However, I indicate to this House the concern of many people in remote parts of Australia, most of whom cannot listen to this debate tonight, who are worried that the additional services will be diverted to where they are least needed, that is, to the metropolitan areas at the expense of rural areas. The report of the Dix Committee into the ABC placed high priority on the provision of a second network for ABC radio in regional and outback areas. It argued that 'it offers the best means of redressing the imbalance of ABC radio services between metropolitan and outback areas'.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most pleasing aspects of this Budget is generous funding for Aboriginals and Aboriginal organisations. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs has received substantial increases as has the Aboriginal Development Commission. Funds have been made available for Aboriginal employment, housing and health schemes. Not only is the Government trying to alleviate the problems which are affecting Aboriginals but also, through such organisations as the Aboriginal Development Commission, it is promoting Aboriginal advancement, self-reliance and cultural and commercial freedom. It is an encouraging sign that 75 per cent of the funds at the disposal of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs for advancement programs will go to Aboriginal managed organisations. In the Northern Territory the Department is allocating no fewer than 42 grants to organisations for Aboriginal improvement.

My final comment on this Budget of development relates to the continued provision for the Alice to Darwin railway, a project which is symbolic of the excitement and faith in the Northern Territory. One of my constituents summed up the Budget today when she said: 'It's exciting to see things getting done'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The wife of the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Tambling) must be very loyal. Now that the Australian Democrats have made up their minds-it has caused them great consternation-this will be the Government's third last Budget. If everybody on this side of the House shared my view it might be the Government's last Budget. I believe that the Australian Labor Party should play politics in Australia in the same rotten fashion in which they are played by the Government. The Senate has the power, as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) told us last Tuesday week, to block the Budget. This Budget being as reprehensible as it is, to use the Prime Minister's words of 1975, the Senate should use its powers to block it. The people should be asked to vote on whether they want a Budget of this nature.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier in the debate someone said that it is not relevant to talk about whether matters related to the Budget were raised in the Prime Minister's policy speech of 1980. He said that this is the 1981 Budget and we should forget all about the 1980 policy speech. This is the third time that the Prime Minister has pulled the stunt of saying one thing at the election and doing another straight after. I believe that the people of Australia should adopt the term used by the Returned Services League 'Lest we forget'. If the Democrats are now going to water on their earlier statement that they would knock back the sales tax measures this Government can live at ease for another three years. All its measures will be passed because of the weak kneed messages that will be sent back from the Senate as a result of the stand of the Democrats. The Government can go on shaping its Budgets as it has done this time and force its policies on the Australian people.

What the Government will not do is present a Budget of this nature in 1983. This Budget is designed to allow the Government to give back to the voters in 1983 some of the taxes it is grabbing in 1981 and 1982. Nothing could be clearer than that. I do not believe the Government is doing anything at all to try to hide the motivation of this Budget. It will take money from people in 1981 and 1982, give a little back in 1983 in order to survive and take it again in 1984. That is the way this Government has operated since it was elected in 1975 and obviously it is the way it will continue after this year.

Under this Government the problems that have been caused and the injustices that have been created are as much acts of deliberate policy as they are the result of incompetence. It has hidden behind the excuse that its policies and the burdens that have gone with them are economic necessities. The Prime Minister's assumption that what he wanted was what the rest of Australia wanted evaporated with the reaction to his comment that 'life was not meant to be easy'. Since then he has adopted the false rhetoric of fighting inflation first and promising that economic recovery is on its way. We have been told of the prospect of a consumer-led recovery, an investment-led recovery and an overseas-led recovery. All of these have amounted to nothing and now we are supposed to sit and wait for a resources-led recovery. If the Government is allowed to continue with its present foreign investment and development policies, most people will not enjoy many of the benefits of this either.

Now the long lead times of resources projects are being used by the Government as a further excuse for not coming to grips with unemployment. The Government has dumped the unemployed. It has not just walked away from them; it has hounded and stigmatised them in a sickening media campaign to neutralise unemployment as an election issue. As time has worn on, the ranking of Government Ministers for employment has slid about as far as it can go, as has the Government's financial commitment to the unemployed. In this Budget the Community Youth Support Scheme has been abolished. This action has ignored the fact that the average period of unemployment for 15 to 19 year-year-olds in this country which is going through a so-called boom is 26 weeks.

The Government's policies are often contradictory. It has said that fighting inflation is its first priority but it has fuelled inflation with its oil pricing policy and its sales tax increases. We have heard about the benefits of small government, but taxes have not been reduced. The burdens must be spread across a smaller tax base. Under the Prime Minister that burden is increasingly put on the wage earner. The estimate of average weekly earnings, to which the Government prefers to refer, is the seasonally adjusted estimate of average earnings before tax of all male civilian employees in Australia, including the highest paid as well as the lowest paid. For the March quarter of 1981 that estimate is $283.90 a week or about $14,700 a year. A similarly calculated estimate of the average weekly earnings of adult male full time employees, excluding managerial and executive staff, is $245.50 a week or about $12,700 a year. According to the latest Budget figures, 75 per cent of individuals have annual incomes of under $15,000. But about half earn less than $11,000 a year and almost 40 per cent of wage earners receive less than $10,000 a year. The biggest group earns between $9,000 and $10,000 a year. These are the people the Prime Minister is putting the screws on. The 0.26 per cent of the individuals who earn more than $50,000 a year are the ones he is looking after.

It is sickening to the people of Australia to witness Government members like the Treasurer (Mr Howard) of this country being interviewed on television telling the people of Australia that he can understand the problems of the average person who earns $300 a week. Let me repeat: Seventy-five per cent of wage earners receive less than $15,000 a year or $300 a week. About half of the wage earners receive less than $11,000 a year and 40 per cent receive less than $10,000 a year. The Treasurer does not know what people earn. How can he understand the hardships that are being forced on the people through measures like this Budget?

The Government's double standards for the community are nowhere more evident than they are in the field of taxation. Despite the Prime Minister's mention of the benefits of tax indexation in his policy speech last year, only seven months later the Government announced that it had made its last indexation adjustment and that any future adjustments would be made on a discretionary basis having regard to economic conditions. This means that from now on the Government can rely on inflation to make its tax increases. The real value of deductions for dependants will decline and increases in wages will mean higher average tax rates. These burdens will fall disproportionately heavily upon those on lower incomes. For example, if we use the Government's prediction of a 13.5 per cent increase in the average wage across the board, a person currently earning $8,000 a year would have an increase in his tax bill this year of 57 per cent. If a person on $8,000 a year receives a 13 per cent wage increase, as predicted by the Treasurer in his Budget, his tax bill in the next financial year will go up by 57 per cent. The tax bill of a person earning $14,500 a year will go up by 21 1/2 per cent, and a person currently earning $50,000 will have an increase in his tax bill of 17.8 per cent. That is the way in which the Government intends to raise the additional revenue it requires this financial year.

In recent years company taxation revenue increases have barely kept pace with inflation, while increases in revenue from personal income tax have far exceeded inflation. The Government's failure to redress the growing imbalance of the burden between corporate taxes and personal income taxes is nowhere more evident than in the area of resources. Honourable members on this side of the House have frequently argued for a resource rental tax. We are not talking about punitive taxes to discourage investment. We are talking about ensuring that an adequate share of the benefits derived from the nation's mineral wealth is distributed amongst the people. The day that Australia considered itself a nation poorly endowed with mineral resources ended in the early 1960s with the lifting of the iron ore export embargo.

To go on talking for another 20 years about the need to ensure that companies should be able to extract every ounce of profit from every tonne of ore because of the risks of exploration is to divorce oneself from some modern realities. There are enough examples of mining companies having been given leases over ore bodies which they took no part at all in finding. In many cases the exploration was carried out by the Government-owned Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics. In other cases there has been a substantial body of geological knowledge about an area and the ore body has already been well defined. Examples can be found at Weipa and on the New South Wales coal fields. Should the companies given the right to exploit such resources also be given the right to extract super-normal profits? In our opinion they should not. I think most people in the community are sceptical that capital intensive resource-based industries will provide the number of jobs we require directly or indirectly to alleviate the present social and economic situation. If the Government maintains its present position we will continue to see a group of foreign companies extracting super-normal profits from our resources while the Government continues to tax the wage earner beyond his capacity to pay.

Tax is not the only issue in relation to the mining industry coming out of this year's Budget. Last year the Government set a target range for the growth in the money supply of between 9 per cent and 11 per cent. The flow of foreign capital into this country was so great that towards the end of the financial year it was realised that the growth in the money supply would reach almost 13 per cent. The Government for the last six years has believed that the remedy for inflation is a harsh monetary policy-in plain English, to impose credit squeezes. The more foreign investment, the greater the growth in the money supply, the more pressure the Government has brought to bear on interest rates. The fact that the Government's policies are brutal, wasteful, inefficient and wrong does not alter the fact-the Government's approach to monetary policy and foreign investment has meant that Australians have had to bear all the burdens of the credit squeeze. This has affected households, small businesses, rural industry and manufacturing. Foreign investment has, therefore, received preferential treatment at the expense of the Australian community.

We have seen another example of the Government's attitude toward foreign investment in the last month with its decision to ask Shell to offer 25 per cent of its local interest to Australian investors. The Government has not made clear what it has in mind for Shell. Adequate Australian equity is 51 per cent so that there can be effective local control, not silent partner status, as well as a better participation in earnings. Without the Government's issuing a timetable by which this should be achieved, it appears that the request to Shell is inadequate and probably motivated by a desire to solve what the Government might see as a serious public relations problem. Alternatively it could be a shameless exploitation of nationalising status which will allow Shell to take out 100 per cent equity in local projects without our knowing when it is ever going to achieve 50 per cent local equity.

I turn to the Treasurer's $892m bonanza.
