The Treasurer's promise of 12 March of this year in announcing the Government's decision not to proceed with the introduction of a new broadly based tax has now been broken. He said that the Government was anxious to minimise the inflationary consequences of collecting additional revenue and that it did not want to move towards greater reliance on indirect tax without providing a noticeable offset in personal tax reductions. The Prime Minister also must have forgotten to mention these new sales taxes to the Australian electors before the last election. This means that in a full year $892m in additional sales tax will come out of the pockets of Australians on virtually every item that they buy. The Government admits that this will add 0.75 per cent to inflation. This should be contrasted with the $12m in a full year which will be taken from our coal exports and which will add nothing to inflation.

This sales tax increase, combined with the Government's utilisation of fiscal drag to maximise its take of personal income tax, probably makes this year's Budget the most regressive in living memory in terms of the distribution of income. It is obvious that people on or below the average wage will spend a greater proportion of their income on items that attract sales tax. The blow is even greater for homemakers. Sales tax on furniture, floor coverings and whitegoods has doubled, going from 2.5 per cent to 5 per cent. They are all major expense items and they are necessities in setting up a home. This is another unnecessary burden which this Government has heaped on top of rising interest rates.

The Prime Minister and the Treasurer think it is politically more palatable to justify the recent interest rate increases by referring to the inflationary potential of wage increases rather than admit that it is a result of their own reaction to the blowout in the money supply caused by the high inflow of foreign capital which they have sought. The continuing issue is whether the latest round of interest rate increases will prove to be high enough. If the finance market can only see higher rates ahead, there will be pressure on the Government to raise interest rates still further so that it can maintain its present monetary policies. The impact of high interest rates on manufacturing is serious enough. It has pushed up the costs of overdrafts and new capital and has worsened the cost structure of companies as they require refinancing. This will obviously flow through to the consumer price index and affect the competitiveness of local industry. But its impact on home owners is devastating.

The people worst affected are those who purchased their homes three to five years ago when interest rates were substantially lower than they are now. Steeply rising housing costs had forced home buyers to the limit of their borrowing capacity, usually on second but sometimes third mortgages at punitive interest rates. They considered themselves lucky if they could even bridge the deposit gap. First it was unemployment that caused people to lose their homes; now people with jobs just cannot keep up with the rising interest rates. If honourable members take a drive around any relatively new suburb they will find mortgage sale signs on well kept properties that are three to five years old. These increasing interest burdens have coincided with a more expensive phase of life when these people have started families. This is a time when their reasonable expectation would have been that the proportion of their income devoted to mortgage repayments would have started to decline. It is not the 1960s; these people cannot find a second job or work overtime to make up the difference.

In the last couple of years interest rates have increased by 2 percentage points. This is the exact opposite of the Prime Minister's promise in 1977 that interest rates would drop by 2 percentage points. The conclusion that the Government's policies give priority to foreign investment over home ownership is inescapable. In the present cirsumstances, with skyrocketing housing and rental costs in our largest capital cities, there is a backlog of persons who might have been expected to purchase homes over the last few years. They have suffered a diminished standard of living because of the present economic climate and are forced to continue to seek rental accommodation. In this environment we find that lengthy waiting lists exist for public rental housing and low income home ownership loans. Waiting periods are generally expressed as a number of years. Worse than this, there has been a dramatic increase in homelessness, including young people, much of which involves a need for permanent low price accommodation.

In response, the Government has chosen to cut allocations for welfare housing by more than $20m. Welfare housing advances to the States and Territories have been cut from $285m to $262m. However, this includes $12m for Aboriginal housing, which was previously administered by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. This means that the allocation has been cut to $250m. This represents a decrease of more than 20 per cent in real terms. Instead, a $2m allocation for the start of a program of crisis accommodation for families in distress has been announced. It is obvious that it is the Government that is creating the crisis in housing.

To complete the picture of the Prime Minister's policy of creeping misery, I will make a few observations about the Government's record on social security. While pensions and adult unemployment benefits have been indexed, a vast proportion of people seeking emergency relief from various agencies are recipients of social security payments. This is because their level of payment is inadequate to meet even basic needs. Many families are having to use emergency relief as an ongoing way of life to supplement pensions and benefits. It should be noted that pensions are diminishing in relation to community income movements. Last year the pension was 23 per cent of average weekly earnings. In 1981-82, after this Budget, it will fall to 22 per cent. The fact that the unemployment benefit is $11.60 a week less than the pension must be seen in the light that 78,000 people in this country have been unemployed for more than a year and that an additional 55,000 people have been unemployed for between six months and a year.

Unemployment benefit for 18-year-olds again has not been indexed. Many young people who left home in the country to come to the cities to look for work are now living well below the poverty line. There can be no doubt that this Budget would have been rejected by the people if the Prime Minister had gone ahead with his threat to take it to the people. I wish that the Australian Democrats had stuck with us on this issue. They promised, according to Senator Chipp, that they would 'keep the bastards honest'. The bastards in this place happen to be the Government and the Democrats should have voted with the Australian Labor Party so that we would have an election in 1981 when the Prime Minister was doing the things that he intends to do all the time, not making the false problems that he makes at election time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Budgets, as the Opposition has been at pains to tell us, are about people. They are about the welfare of people, and the welfare of people is strongly influenced by Budget decisions. The choice that exists for a Government as to how it influences that welfare is, to me, the dilemma of today's politics. This Budget and the speeches about it have demonstrated the vast divergence in viewpoint between the Government, the deliverer of the Budget, and the Opposition with its alternative strategy. Both claim to have the welfare of the population at heart. The Budget before us, at least to a degree, accepts as a major strategy that Australians are resourceful, hard-working and willing to make their own way in the world. It creates conditions for people to succeed by their personal enterprise. It seeks in many directions to remove government from the lives of Australians and to leave them to their own decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's alternative, as presented by its leader and re-rendered by its supporters with practically no variation, offers us Government at every turn. When one summarises the Opposition's package it might appear that this is not so. It has pitched its bid particularly high. The Opposition, as in its previous expedition into government, sees the time is right: The coffers have been regenerated by the innovative and yet conservative policies of this government and the country, like a well run business, can stand five years of mismanagement again before it becomes obvious to an electorate blinded by handouts. How would the Opposition do this? I will refer to what it has said. It would abandon the proposed sales tax so that the money could go to consumer spending.

Only a month ago consumers of Australia walked the streets with money in their pockets because the cohorts of the Opposition, the Transport Workers Union of Australia, removed the means of delivery. People had money but nothing to buy. What did the Opposition do then to encourage consumer spending? I have been told that there is no real shortage of money in Poland, but in Poland, whether one is rich or poor, one goes without. Money under bad government is worthless. Consumer spending is created by public confidence, not depreciating bits of paper called money. Member's of a Labor government would give us across-the-board cuts in income tax to the tune of 22 per cent, further dipping their fingers into the till to distribute more money to buy the same quantity of goods at high prices. They know that it did not work last time when they spread money around like flies, but then who expects to be right a second time?

At the same time members of the Australian Labor Party would address themselves to the nasties. They would introduce a resource rent tax and drop the $500m investment allowance to ensure a redirection of resources back from the buoyant corporate sector into public programs of assistance to the individual. Although they do not bother to make it public, for good measure they would also introduce a wealth tax. They will deny that but anyone who has heard their leader speak on the subject, as I have on a talk-back show, has little difficulty reading between the words and recognising the total personal commitment of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) to that course. What are those public programs of assistance to the individual? Members of the Labor Party choose to identify one of these as universal health insurance. Insurance indicates to me a user-pay principle. Does the great benefit of their system lie purely in economy of scale-are we to have just one huge insurance system-or is the word 'insurance' in socialist terms used to tell us that the insurer will be the Government? The insurer will be those people who, by their personal effort, pay taxes.

I have always wondered why socialist governments see so much benefit to the public in providing free health services. The greatest contributor to health and well being is food. Why not commence with a universal feeding scheme? Why ask people to pay for food? I am sure that if they were given the choice between free food and free medicine most Australians would take the food. The Leader of the Opposition in his new-found role as Australia's leader could, as his first daily task, write out our menus. The misfortune is that the utterances of the Opposition are still pitched at convincing the Australian public that there is such a thing as a free lunch. What does the Opposition offer its friends who pay for the election costs; at least, what are the written promises? Is there to be a complete overhaul of the arbitration system and the abolishment of the Industrial Relations Bureau? I do not deny the need to overhaul the arbitration system in the formal sense but, when that promise is coupled with the abolishment of the IRB, it clearly shows the intention in this regard.

The Opposition's present shadow Minister for Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), personally supervised the castration of the present Conciliation and Arbitration Act when, as a pay-off for left wing support, he defeated the penal provisions. Does he propose to replace the Act with hypnosis? What sort of legislation does he propose will operate without teeth? This Government has found the key to industrial peace. The howls of the protected industries, which we have heard in the past couple of days, are the proof. Where now does the motor industry stand in priority for a 35-hour working week? The message of this Budget is that workers and manufacturers should get together so that they can make more money, sell goods more cheaply and give other people more money to spend. That is true consumer spending-a dollar that goes further.

We will not legislate our way out of industrial strife. The Leader of the Opposition accused us of persisting with a callous indifference to people's security, livelihood, homes, spending power and future. In 1974-75, under Labor, Australia and Australians had no future. The Commonwealth and industry of a country takes varying periods to dissipate. The most recent example of galloping dissipation appears to be Sweden; that is, if one can believe an article contained in the Economist of London as it was published in the Australian on Monday. The Australian headline was entitled 'Swedish economy freezes over as government spending soars'. Sweden had an outstanding economy which then turned to socialism. The article stated:
Sweden's social conscience has become a millstone.
Total public spending (including transfer payments) now takes two-thirds of gross domestic product and the public sector provides one job in three.
Its deficit, equivalent to 4 per cent of GDP last year, stops politicians making the tax cuts the country needs.
That just might be the message to people who are talking about inflationary budgets and tax cuts. The article continued:
And Sweden's swollen government spending is making most of the country's other problems worse.
During the 1970s, Sweden's public sector increased its share of GDP by a half and its share of total jobs doubled.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder they call you a hurricane lantern. You are not very bright but you hang about.
—The honourable member is getting worried. Would he like me to stop in case he learns something?
—Order! I invite the honourable member for O'Connor to ignore the interjections and address the Chair.
—What letter are you quoting from?
—I am not stating my own opinions now. I am stating some facts. This is not a letter. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: The public sector's total deficit rose from 1,400 million crowns ($230 million) in 1978 to 20,000 million crowns in 1980. The forecast for 1981 is 30,000 million crowns.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are crowns?

—If the honourable member is too ignorant to know what a crown is in terms of money he should not ask me. I am not here to teach him a lesson. I do not share his ignorance. The article went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: On every count, Sweden's State-run activities are now hitting the people hard.
Public spending has helped fuel inflation, both directly and through the way it has increased the rigidities of the economy.
Sweden now has one of the highest inflation rates in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) at 14 per cent. Wages are partly inflation-linked.
The OECD, in its annual report on Sweden just published says it expects inflation to come down over the next year. That may be a vain hope.
Later the report stated:
Government borrowing flooding the country's financial market is one reason why Sweden's corporate sector is so thinly capitalised.
Does that not ring a bell? I go on to refer to a couple of other paragraphs. The first states:
True, unemployment at 2 per cent in 1980 has stayed very low by OECD standards.
And, let us admit, by Australian standards. It continued:
The number has been kept down by 'labor market measures' that find public sector jobs for the potentially unemployed.
That is reminiscent of the RED Scheme. The next paragraph states:
Private employers have been partly crowded out of the labor market, says the OECD. Public enterprises now set wage levels for the productive sectors and will drive some companies in them bust.
Of course, that would be a pretty attractive proposition, I would imagine, to certain people here tonight. The article went on to state:
Swedish exporters lost market shares. These losses have not been recouped, even though labor cost competitiveness is back to 1973 levels.
One could continue on with that tale of woe, yet people on the other side of this House tell us that this is the way to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sweden has been socialist for 40 years.

—Yes. I made that point earlier in the piece. I said that it takes various periods to dissipate wealth. Nevertheless, the English have also dissipated theirs. It took them 200, or probably 300, years of colonialism to collect it and it has taken the present socialistic arrangements a very short time to destroy it.
—Margaret will love you.
—Margaret is going all right. She is just telling the English people the truth.
—Your history is about as good as your driving.

—Do not worry about that. When I see a tree I can run into it. Let me return for a moment to this Government's proposal to broaden its indirect tax base through sales tax. As a member representing a country electorate I will always have a concern that country people who generally pay higher prices could pay more. Nevertheless, I am aware from experience that few wholesalers operate in remote areas. As the present sales tax is applied at wholesale level, it is therefore not applied to the freight cost that is incurred ex-warehouse in the metropolitan area.
—That is not true.

—I hold a sales tax certificate and the honourable member does not so he should not tell me that he knows a lot about it. Of course it is true. Sales tax is applied at the wholesale level. The invoice that accompanies the goods when they are delivered has the sales tax marked on it and it is not charged on any further amount. The honourable member should check his records. In other places I happen to be a remote area wholesaler and that is exactly what happens in those circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition refers to this tax as wealth by stealth. The wholesale tax does not appear on a consumer account in many cases. Personally, I wish it did. I believe that a government should make its taxes obvious and answer for them. But at least we call it a tax. We call it sales tax. The Leader of the Opposition called for a mild deficit. Of course, when the Labor Party was last the government of Australia it operated almost eternally in deficit-in fact, in a very large deficit. What name can we give a deficit other than a tax by stealth? We can call it an expenditure and a commitment for future generations. The deficits of the Whitlam years have measured heavily on the tax burden of present day Australians. If I can expand on that statement: We need only a simple analogy of someone getting a $20,000 personal loan with no repayments for 12 months. That person will live very well for that 12 months and then the trouble will start. Anybody who is fortunate enough, as a government is, to borrow money at one per cent and to tell somebody else how much he will borrow, can very easily become the irresponsible individual in the community and spend beyond the community's ability.

Much has been said of the plight of the home owner and his mortgage interest rates. The institution of home ownership within Australia is, I think, one of our great pillars. I hope that all steps will be taken to maintain it. Nevertheless, to hear some of the more colorful members of the Opposition bemoan the home owner's fate raises some humour with me when I consider the basic attitude of the Opposition to the individual owning anything. I wonder why it is suddenly so sympathetic to home owners. This Budget not only removes the Federal Government from the domestic loan market but also creates a situation whereby, as the predicted surplus materialises, the Government can, if it chooses, go back into the market and buy back its securities, thus introducing the funds it believes the economy can handle and further reducing interest rate pressure.

My previous political experience was in local government. I know well the burden that the present day wealth tax called rates-household rates-imposes on home owners. I imagine that Australian home owners today pay in excess of $1 billion in rates and charges of that nature on their land. The funds allocated in this Budget for a direct expenditure on local government are a direct subsidy to ratepayers. Local government has only the rate as a flexible source of income. In my experience Federal Government grants represented from 20 per cent to 300 per cent of the rate revenue of various local authorities in Western Australia. This grant could otherwise be recouped only by increased rates. I congratulate the Government for continuing its policy of supporting local government by allowing it a direct proportion of income tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor started that.
—Do not tell me who started it. The Labor Government started it with a lousy $40m.
—That was Labor policy.

—The Labor Government's policy was all right, provided that one went cap in hand to a mob of people in Canberra and begged for one's money. There were no untied grants from the opposite lot. They lose control. The result is double edged. The money goes to grass roots government, to the people who know best where to spend it and who ensure that the funds go as far as possible. The grant guarantees delivery of grass roots services which could otherwise be provided only by land owners.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, let me refer to overseas investment. The Opposition still lives with the belief that Australia is an economic island. It chooses to blame capital inflow for all our economic ills. It ignores entirely the prosperity that such investment can bring. It proposes controls, similar no doubt to those it proposed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Reagan has put capital inflows on.

—Do not tell me about Reagan. We are in Australia. The Labor Party would impose controls similar, no doubt, to those it imposed previously-controls which, if associated with the other economic measures it espouses, would guarantee the same result as the last one when there was not a slowing down of capital inflow, but a reversal of capital inflow. To use the words of the honourable member for Wills when he wore another hat: 'Capital will go on strike'. No one knows better than he the effect of a strike. Capital needs labour but labour cannot survive without capital. Labour cannot survive on money created by government because only money created by resources and hard work has any value.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Mr Duffy) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Health Care Services-Australian Motor Industry-Budget-Zone Allowances-Department of Employment and Youth Affairs-Department of Social Security: Social Workers-Community Youth Support Scheme-Spelling Reform

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Thomson) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter in regard to the fifth change to health insurance in as many years. From next week this Government will bring into being a system which will bring enormous hardship and worry to thousands of economically disadvantaged Australians. The following question needs to be asked: Who are these people and who will get the so-called health card treatment? There are three groups of such people. One group constitutes those pensioners with medical cards. No doubt we are finding from constituent work in the community that many pensioners do not qualify for a pensioner medical card or for a health care card. The card is also available to migrants and refugees in their first six months in Australia and to people receiving unemployment or special benefits if their income, other than their benefit, is less than $40 a week if they are single or $68 a week if they are married. Also eligible are people on low incomes who, if they are single earn less than $96 a week or, if they are married, $160 a week, plus $20 for each child. For instance, a married couple with two children could earn $200 a week and with five children, $260 a week.

SPEECH.PARA: In the advertising that has gone on in the last two or three weeks, in full page advertisements in newspapers right across Australia, very little has been spent on informing people of their rights to the health care card. People should check whether they are qualified for the card before they take out insurance because many of the insurance funds are forgetting to tell the people of their rights. How do people go about getting a card? This is where the difficulty arises for some three million Australians who will be depending on these cards. If they are eligible, the first thing they should do is contact their local Department of Social Security office, but if they happen to live in an electorate such as mine-the electorate of McMillan out in the country-they find that they have only one office. My electorate is big enough to entitle me as a parliamentarian to an extra back bench allowance. A great service is provided by this Government in that my electorate has one Department of Social Security office.

We also have a situation in which officers from the Department of Social Security main office travel to another town in the electorate, Warragul, on Tuesdays which means that people can go to that office for advice. Other parts of the electorate depend on officers coming from Dandenong to a town called Wonthaggi which has a similar service but only on a fortnightly basis. There is another problem which arises for people in the electorate. Disadvantaged people are those people who do not have sufficient funds. They are declared disadvantaged because they are economically disadvantaged. They cannot get around the electorate easily; so they have to rely on the mail service in order to get their pensioner health benefit cards. We have people telling us that very few cards at this stage have been issued.

These people will face certain problems. Firstly, they have to produce identification. So they have to produce a birth certificate or a marriage certificate. It cannot be a copy; it must be the original. Secondly, they can apply for a form in order to get their card. When they have the form they then have to show the Government their pay slips for the previous four weeks. All this has to be done because we are creating a second class service for a large proportion of the Australian people. If these people are lucky enough to receive a card, it will be lodged for six months. If there is a change in their total income, overtime over any four week period or a pay rise comes through in the system, they are obliged to notify the Department of Social Security and their eligibility may cease. In most cases it will cease. They then have to go through the whole procedure again making application through the mail as no services are provided by this Government. Services are just not available to work this new health care scheme. Many economically disadvantaged people are being treated as second rate Australian citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often that I get really upset about something. I have been trying to promote reasonable and rational debate over a very serious issue that faces the Government over the next few weeks; that is the question of the future of the Australian motor industry. To a degree that effort to promote reasonable and sensible debate has been successful. I have spent many days over the last two or three months visiting motor plants and I intend to continue this over the coming week or two before the decision is made, discussing with the manufacturers-both of automobiles and of parts-their problems and the problems of their work force and the direction in which this important industry should go in the future. I thought we were having a reasonable discussion about problems shared jointly by all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning the debate was debased in a most unsatisfactory way by the insertion of a joint advertisement in the Australian Press by the managing director of General Motors-Holden's Ltd and Mr Len Townsend the Federal Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation. This advertisement-I presume jointly funded by General Motors and this union-was put in most of the Australian newspapers and brings the debate on this issue back to the kind of primitive level of a few years ago in regard to textiles and a number of other industries. A fear compaign of the most stupid sort is obviously intended by this advertisement. I will quote some of the words used in the advertisement. It states:

The future of the Australian motor vehicle industry is under government review. There are critics of the industry who are suggesting policies that would destroy it. They are recommending that protection for Australian vehicle manufacturing be dropped. Imported vehicles would then flood Australia, destroying local industry. Without adequate quotas and import tariffs, well over 200,000 jobs in vehicle manufacturing and related industries would be lost.

Who 'they are'-those who are recommending that protection for Australian vehicle manufacturing be dropped-I do not know. The most far reaching recommedation I have seen in this area is that of the Industries Assistance Commission which suggests that after 1984-which, after all, is three years away-the present level of protection for fully imported vehicles be raised from 57 1/2 per cent to 60 per cent and that the protection be reduced gradually over five years to 35 per cent, or double the average rate of protection for manufacturing industry in Australia. Mr Chapman of General Motors and Mr Townsend of the Vehicle Builders Union say that 'they', whoever they are, are recommending that protection for the Australian vehicle industry be dropped. That is a lie. It is not true. This is totally misleading advertising. At the beginning of the text, the advertisement states:
372,000 are unemployed today.
I do not dispute that.
Add 200,000 more. That's over 1/2 million people unemployed.
If vehicle manufacturing ceases, it is argued that the unemployed would find work in the mining and service industries.

The suggestion is that if one adds a straight 200,000 people to the present 372,000 people who are unemployed that will total half a million unemployed if the IAC recommendations are accepted by the Government. That is sheer nonsense. No economic analyst and no observer of the industry is saying that in Australia today. This advertisement is totally and utterly misleading and it is downright fraudulent. It attempts to reduce a sensible debate to a nonsense. Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to protest to the House in the strongest possible terms against debasing an important national argument by this sort of absolute bilge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two claims made by the coalition parties prior to the 1975 election and prior to elections subsequently have been that they would form a government which was committed to small government and that they would form a government which was committed to low tax. The claim has been repeated and apparently the assumption is that if the claim is repeated often enough a sufficiently large proportion of the Australian people will come to accept it.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal very briefly with the two claims mentioned. In relation to small government, probably the most appropriate measure to determine the extent to which any government becomes involved in the economic affairs of the nation is the proportion of the total gross domestic product which is absorbed by total Budget receipts. During the last Budget of the Labor Government-that was the Budget for the year 1975-76-total Budget receipts absorbed 25.1 per cent of the gross domestic product. In this current Budget this Government has arranged for the absorption of 27.5 per cent of the gross domestic product as total Budget receipts, the highest percentage ever recorded if the history of this Commonwealth.

If the proportion of gross domestic product going to Budget receipts in 1981-82 had remained equal to the proportion that applied in 1975-76, for this current financial year the private sector in Australia would have been left with an additional $3,556m. As a result of this Budget that will be taken from them. I repeat: The best single measure of the extent to which the Government participates in the economic affairs of the nation is the proportion of the total gross domestic product which is absorbed by Budget receipts, and those figures indicate not only that it has grown since the Government came to office but also that the percentage is the highest it has ever been.

The other claim that has been made is that this is a low tax government. Surely the figures which would justify or refute a claim of this kind would be the proportion of the total gross domestic product which is absorbed by total taxation revenue. Despite the claim that has been made that the Labor Government was a high tax government, the fact remains that in 1975-76, the year of the last Budget for which we were responsible, the proportion of total tax revenue which was absorbed by the Federal Government was 23.2 per cent. For the current financial year the percentage has increased to 25.5 per cent. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) attempted earlier today to manipulate these figures by referring to the Budget deficit in 1975-76 and suggesting that the proportion of total gross domestic product in that year was greater than it was. I remind honourable members of the fact that in 1975-76, although 23.2 per cent of the gross domestic product was absorbed by total tax revenue, that included a national health scheme which meant that every family in Australia, in terms of today's values, was better off to the extent of about $12 a week. If the same proportion of gross domestic product going to taxes in 1975-76 had remained applicable to 1981-82, for the current financial year income earners throughout the whole of Australia would have been left with an additional $3,420m in their pockets. This is the government which suggests that people should be given the opportunity to determine the way in which they will spend their income. This is precisely the government which has denied them that opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak tonight in full support of the proposition put during the adjournment debate last night by the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) on the subject of zone allowances. I speak for the same reasons as the honourable member for Kennedy and for the reason that I have made representations over many years to the treasurers of this Government. These representations were to ensure that on any change of the zone allowance, equity was returned to those living in the inhospitable climatic parts of our continent where, besides the droughts, dust, floods and flies, costs of production and costs of living have escalated, and living standards have diminished in comparison with those in the city.

SPEECH.PARA: This is why the majority report is so disappointing. After a year of anticipation, since the report on zone allowances was commissioned, the expectations of those who have been responsible for the devolution of our industries and who develop our basic resources, have been crumpled and completely disregarded. Their report is basically worthless. It is not worthless because their conclusions and recommendations do not agree with what I felt would have been the result, but worthless because, upon the collection of so much evidence and in the face of so many obvious facts in the majority report, this evidence and these facts were not used. For instance, in acknowledging that zone allowances were introduced in 1945 and that geographical boundaries were then set, one might have inquired as to whether they were politically or practically set to achieve a purpose.

Paragraphs 2.10 and 2.11 on page 3 of the report make assumptions and are unable to determine how boundaries were arrived at at the time of introduction. If the boundaries were practically set the development of industries and the spread of population since 1945 must, of necessity, have called for some alteration to boundaries one way or the other. But the majority found that there should be no re-alignment of existing boundaries. I find this utterly incredible. The fact that a third category has now been included, disregarding boundaries of any type whatsoever, and setting the criterion of a distance of 250 kilometres from a town with a population of 2,500 or more, is in conflict with the geographic boundaries concept that originally was introduced. So the majority report recommendation is neither one thing nor the other.

The base values retained in zones A and B have remained unchanged since 1958-59 except for the rebate conversion in 1975. There was no effort whatsoever to quantify the real value of the allowance or rebate. It is incomprehensible to suggest that, in an economy thrashed by inflation in the 1970s, with intervening booms and busts, those values have not been affected in any way except for the suggestion that urbanised areas with a population in excess of 25,000 should be downgraded. Obviously, the majority report is superficial and shallow. On the other hand, Mr Slater has tried to do something with the evidence and facts, and in what would not have been an exercise in ease he made a determined effort to bring forward constructive recommendations. I congratulate him on his effort. I note that at page 47 of the report Mr Kerr lends weight to the arguments of Mr Slater to an extent that one might consider their findings a majority report.

As member for Dawson I understand better than any other representative the conditions of my own electorate, the proper feelings of the people and the necessity for zone allowances to restore some of the financial disadvantages of a taxation rebate. I refer to the new mining developments of the Bowen Basin. The arbitary boundaries set in 1945 are not realistic for 1981. The unease of the people working in these areas found its outlet in the miners tax strike of 1980. The majority report neglects them in every way. The earners of Australia's primary wealth deserve some consideration.

I speak of an area where there are difficulties of distance, road construction, road maintenance and weather. The cost of telephone rentals in outback Australia is now at a premium of $500 per year. Television is not bad; it is just non-existent. Insurance policies taken out by people living above the Tropic of Capricorn incur a surcharge because of storm and tempest and matters such as that. Some people in Australia complain about water salinity. We just do not have the resources to overcome the problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: — This evening I wish to raise two matters: One relating to the portfolio of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) and the other relating to the Department of Social Security. I am pleased to see that the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs is in the chamber this evening. He may recall that on 10 June this year I raised in this House a question relating to research work which Mr Chris Lennings, a psychologist working with the Marrickville community health centre, was attempting to carry out regarding the activities of young jobless people in Marrickville in my electorate. I asked the Minister why his Department refused to allow Mr Lennings to hand out a survey to the people who had applied for Commonwealth Employment Service benefits at Marrickville. I asked also whether the Minister had implemented a secrecy program in his Department.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister has demonstrated in the last few days in relation to the Community Youth Support Scheme, he can make quite loud and long speeches, but speeches without much content. But one of the interesting statements the Minister made in the rather lengthy, belligerant reply he gave me was:
Let me say that there is no policy of secrecy in this matter at all.

That was in relation to the type of work Mr Lennings was trying to carry out. Some time later on 7 August, the Minister provided me with a reply in which he said that while the spirit of Mr Lenning's research was appreciated the CES must adhere to its long-standing policy of strict confidentiality of client information. He went on to say that the Department was not willing to allow Mr Lennings to peruse its files in relation to his inquiries. I suggest to the Minister that that is a rather shortsighted attitude to take and that one would hope that the Government has based its present policy on the demise of the CYSS program on some sort of research basis.

Mr Lennings was attempting to develop a research base and a data base on what young job seekers were attempting to find from the Commonwealth Employment Service. He was refused that chance even though he was a well respected researcher in the Health Commission of New South Wales and had the support of that Health Commission. Indeed, he had the support of the Deputy Director of the Health Commission in his application. I think the Minister might reconsider his approach to the type of support that one can get from State authorities in developing a data base about the availability of work for young people.

The second question I would like to pursue in the few moments available to me this evening is the employment prospect of social workers in the Department of Social Security. Honourable members may recall that the razor gang proposed earlier this year that there should be a review of the activities of social workers in the Department of Social Security. That review was supposed to be completed by 31 August, a few days hence. The Professional Officers Association of Australia-the industrial organisation which represents social workers in the Commonwealth Public Service-has expressed severe criticism of this proposal and has expressed concern that this may be an attempt by the Government to reduce the number of social workers available in the Department of Social Security.

I object and other members of this Parliament object to the fact that in many instances our offices become a clearing house for the areas of responsibility that Department of Social Security officers should be exercising. I do not think that my staff should have to spend most of their time doing the job that the Department of Social Security should be doing. However, I am advised that there is a number of areas in New South Wales where the Department of Social Security does not have welfare workers at all. I am also advised that at present 40 officers of the Department of Social Security in New South Wales do not have any welfare staff at all. In fact, some time ago the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) issued a direction that there should be two social workers in each Department of Social Security office in Australia, but we find that in New South Wales at least 14 offices have no social workers at all-an absolutely deplorable situation. I find even more deplorable the fact that on the 11th of this month I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) pointing out this matter and asking when that situation would be rectified and I have not even received a reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent days a lot has been said in this House on the question of whether the Community Youth Support Scheme should be terminated. I want to speak tonight firstly about the way in which the decision which was reached was administered by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. I want to quote from a telegram sent by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs the day after the Budget was delivered. The telegram states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has advised a government decision to terminate all CYSS projects from 31st October 1981.
Accordingly, CYSS operations will close from that date.
Directors of the Department will meet in Canberra on 20 August and detailed instructions of action to be taken over the next few months will be advised as soon as possible after the meeting.
CYSS guideline clauses 72-77 outline the procedures regarding assets (equipment and furniture) that must be followed by local committees.
You are requested to carry out an immediate stocktake to ensure your assets register is up to date.
Officers from the Department will carry out an independent check of the Registers within the next 10 days.
Until further advice is received projects should continue. However no extension of commitments should be made.

I think that is a very insensitive way to deal with a very sensitive issue. There was not a word of thanks in that telegram to the many people involved in these schemes who have worked in a very dedicated manner over a number of years. I want tonight to place on the record of this Parliament my personal thanks to those who did work on behalf of the unemployed youth in my electorate in recent years. I will put the names of some of the bodies and people on the record because I think they deserve it-the Young Men's Christian Association scheme, Vic Whittombe; Centrecare, Guido Vogels; the Bayswater scheme, Mike Goff, Barbara Lewis, Glad McGough, Laura Tolliday; the Maylands scheme, Ruth Belben, Rob McArdle. I want to thank those people and bodies and others, the members of the various committees of management and the many volunteers attached to the Scheme for the work that they have done in recent years. I am just sorry that a more official thanks could not have been given by the Department when advising them of this decision.

Last Friday I met with the various representatives of the CYSS projects in my electorate. To their credit, they did not come to me to talk about their own jobs; they came to me to talk about the future of the youth participating in the various CYSS projects. They made the point, and I agreed with them, that many of those who participate in CYSS are a special category of unemployed youth-they have been unemployed for a long time. They lack confidence and they are basically often alienated from institutionally and school based programs. Many of them have a history of very negative experiences with many of these institutions. They will not necessarily be satisfactorily accommodated in broadly based and bureaucratically administered schemes.

The CYSS members I met with were concerned and wanted some kind of assurance that the greatly increased funds which have been made available for the expanded youth training programs would reach the youth who were using the CYSS program. Today I met with the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) to discuss this matter, to raise these points with him and to emphasise the need to ensure that the advantages of the personal approach used by CYSS will not be overlooked in regard to those youths in the new programs. I think this is a very important matter indeed. I am pleased that the Minister is in the House. I want to emphasise to him that the participants in CYSS, with their quite special needs, should be given special attention and every effort should be made to ensure that they can be satisfactorily accommodated in the new programs. I agree that the Minister has a very difficult problem to handle. We all know that this problem is nationally based. There have been some very good schemes and there have been some failures. It is very difficult to establish a national scheme when that kind of thing is happening. I certainly appreciate the efforts that the Minister has made to increase the national funding of programs for unemployed youth in this country. I think it is a very proper priority that we are giving to this problem. But I want to emphasise to the Minister that the unemployed youths involved in these schemes are quite special. We know their names, we know their addresses, we know the communities in which these schemes were based, and we know the good work that has been done. I want the Minister, if he can, to make sure that these unemployed youths will be specially dealt with in the new programs which the Government enunciated in the Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to detain the House. Therefore, I have asked permission of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) to incorporate in Hansard the bulk of my remarks and he has kindly consented to it. I seek leave of the House to have it incorporated at the end of my speech.
—Order! The request for leave is not in order. It is not in order to incorporate the substance of the speech.

—I am referring to a statement regarding an important event that is coming up on 1 September, a 10-year anniversary. It concerns something which is important to all Australians, particularly the education of young Australians, in the International Year of Disabled Persons, and that is the question of spelling reform. It has been calculated that between 5 and 10 per cent of the children who have the good fortune or misfortune to speak English suffer from the technical problems of English spelling. The time for the English language to undergo some of the reforms that have been achieved in other languages is long overdue. Again, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document prepared as a Press release, in which the spelling reform one spellings are used.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

On Tuesday, September 1, The Spelling Action Society (S.A.S.) will be 10 years old. In this short lifetime this movement has hundreds of members around the world, more than eny previous movement to reform spelling. It has as patrons two Nobel Prize winners who are also Fellows of the Royal Society, Sir Mark Oliphant the former South Australian Governor and Sir Macfarlane Burnet, the 'father of immunology'.

SAS is also unique in that the oldest-established spelling reform movement, patronized by the Duke of Edinburgh, has recognized and promoted SR1 as part of its program. SR1 or spelling reform one in the SAS program may be defined in the quatrain:
Eny clear short vowel sed as in 'hemorrhage' and 'led' may be red as 'e' insted of a spelling more widespred.
The dozen alternative spellings now current for this simple sound are illustrated in the 12 words of a less rational quatrain:
Grenwich frend ses Thems gest sed hemorrhaging lepard beried meny hefers ded.

Some 10 years ago I asked the then Minister for Education on notice if he would investigate the possibility of approving the use of SR1 as an alternative to the standards of such august authorities as the Oxford or Webster's dictionaries or the Public Service Style Manual. He got opinions from several literati. A few were in favour. Most tended to produce the usual superficial objections, such as the need to preserve fossilized spellings to help students of etymology rather than make spelling easier for beginners. Harry Lindgren had demolished these specious points in his 1969 Alpha paperback: Spelling Reform: A New Approach. A few language professionals suggested, obviously without having contemplated Lindgren's reasons for choosing SR1, that a better first step in spelling reform would be to replace ph by f, ignoring the fact that this would require exceptions to the rule or a second change away from f in several words including nephew, uphold, sapphire, off, riffle and an extra rule for rough, cough etc. The future changes so necessitated would cause difficulties unless first a rule similar to SR1 had become well established to distinguish the vowel sounds of rifle and riffle, and the vowel sounds of Navy and Navvy, and a similar rule was adopted for the v sounds of nephew and of. In other words, the expert writers were not expert in step-by-step reform based on English speech sound units insted of on existing spelling complexities.

In its first decade SR1 has been used in published anthologies, a novelette and a government discussion booklet which I issued on community helth policies for the A.C.T. SR1 has been adopted as standard by editors of journals, including one on educational research and one organ of a teachers' union. The Sydney Morning Herald's Education Supplement has advocated SR1, and it is used on request by virtually every major daily paper in Australia for letters to the editor concerning spelling reform.

Governments might well consider authorizing their employees, including teachers, to use SR1 as an alternative to more widespred standard spellings. This is not a radical idea since leading dictionaries commonly show alternative spellings for one word, especially a word for which Webster, and Americans generally prefer a more logical spelling than one first standardized by Dr Johnson, the 'father' of dictionary makers. No-one now spells 'debt' the way the French root of the word is spelt: 'dette'. The reason is that the dominant writer of his age, Dr Johnson, decided we ought to put in a 'b' to remind us of the earlier Latin root 'debit-'. Such spelling fossils are as useless as a whipholder on the dashboard of a 1981 model horseless carriage.

Interested Members and Senators should send $5 to join SAS, 40 McKinlay Street, Narrabundah, A.C.T. They will get Lindgren's book, a rubber stamp with the SR1 rule for use on documents where they use SR1, and 12 issues of the monthly newsletter Spelling Action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr N. A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is before the time of 10.30 p.m. when I have to ask for the debate to be extended. May I acknowledge the remarks of the honourable member for Perth (Mr McLean) with respect to the Community Youth Support Scheme and make a few remarks of my own in reply. The first point to be made is that this was a decision by the Government. I think the honourable member said that it was a decision by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. Of course, all decisions are decisions of the Government, and this was one such decision. Secondly, the honourable member maintained that no thanks had been expressed in the communication to which he referred to those associated with and working for some CYSS projects. I want to place on record that the Government acknowledges the work done by people who have worked in the CYSS area. We have made it plain on a number of occasions--
—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—I require the debate to be extended.
—The debate may continue until 10.40 p.m.

—The Government has maintained all along, of course, that there were good CYSS projects. It follows from that, of course, that a lot of good people took part in those CYSS projects. I think it really has been very unfortunate that their activities have been described by people in the Australian Labor Party as tokenism and as a recycling of young people (Quorum formed). I think it is unfortunate that that sort of comment was made by certain people about CYSS. The Government certainly does not subscribe to those views.

SPEECH.PARA: I make two points in conclusion. The first is that special attention will be given to the needs of disadvantaged categories of young people to whom the honourable member refers. The House may be aware that a Press release has been issued setting out the Government's intentions and plans with respect to the transition period as the CYSS program winds down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the Minister's time has expired.
—The Minister may continue for a further minute owing to the premature commencement of his response. There was some slight confusion on the time allocated.

—In the course of that statement I said that managers of Commonwealth Employment Service offices would be providing me with information they obtained after they visited the CYSS projects and spoke to project officers and participants. I said that that action, namely the reporting back to me by managers of Commonwealth Employment Service offices on information in special program action that was needed in local areas, might show the need, in the first place, for special training programs for Aboriginals and disabled young people. We will be particularly concerned to know whether that investigation shows the need for special training programs for Aboriginals and disabled young people.

SPEECH.PARA: I said also in the statement that special attention would be given to the long term unemployed and disadvantaged young people. I am pleased to say that particular attention will be given to the needs of those groups of young unemployed persons as the honourable member for Perth so properly suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the government able to terminate all mining and sales of uranium, permanenty, indefinitely or for a specific period, as recommended by the Fox Report; if so, would the Government be liable to compensation claims for the action.

(2) What was the specific nature of the doubts concerning the transfer of the Government's interest in the Ranger project to Energy Resources of Australia that necessitated the insertion of sub-section 41 (2AA) in the Atomic Energy Act 1953.
(3) Could the Government be implicated, in any way, as party to commercial contracts for sale of uranium arising from the sub-section 41 (2AA) amendment to the Atomic Energy Act 1953.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under Standing Orders, questions should not ask Ministers for legal opinion. I am advised that any answer to this question would require expression of opinion on a matter of law.

(2) In the course of finalising some aspects of the commercial documentation relating to the formation of Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA), legal counsel, acting for some of the Australian commercial parties involved, queried whether the arrangements for the continuing operation of the Ranger project envisaged between the Commonwealth and ERA as reflected in the divestment documentation would be 'on behalf of the Commonwealth' within the meaning of section 41 of the Atomic Energy Act and the Authority which was to be assigned to ERA. The Government examined the matter and decided that the Atomic Energy Act should be amended to put the matter beyond doubt, so that operations at Ranger clearly will continue to be 'on behalf of the Commonwealth'. The amendment was inserted in the Act as sub-section 41 (2AA).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that, in 1976 (a) 6% of private schools received more finance from State and Federal Government grants than they spent on education and (b) 56% of private schools received more than 80% of their expenditure from State and Federal grants.
(2) How many private schools receive more than (a) 80% and (b) 100% of their expenditure from State and Federal Government sources in each State since 1976.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The figures quoted in part 1 (a) and (b) appear in the April 1978 Schools Commission Report for the triennium 1979-81 and were based on 1976 data. In assessing school expenditure for these purposes, no allowance has been made for the payment of interest or repayment of principal in respect of loans for capital purposes, nor for the costs of making provision for future commitments or for expenditure on such capital items as furniture and equipment. All of these costs must be met, at least in part, from a school's cash income.

Surveys conducted by the Commission indicated that, in 1977, some 7% of non-government schools spent less on the provision of recurrent resources than they received from State and Commonwealth Government recurrent grants, while 55% of non-government schools received recurrent grants from Government sources totalling more than 80% of their recurrent expenditure. The equivalent proportions in 1979 were 6% and 58% respectively. Comparable figures are not available for other years.

If debt servicing is taken into account, the great majority of non-government schools (that is those in the Catholic sector) provide on average more than one-third of total expenditure from their own efforts, including the estimated value of contributed services; the remaining two-thirds being provided in the form of grants from Commonwealth and State Governments. These schools have on average recurrent resource levels about 30 per cent below those of the average government school.
Other non-government schools receive on average less than one-third of their recurrent expenditure in the form of Government grants.

After taking into account debt servicing and the other factors mentioned above, the majority of the remaining schools which appear to spend less on the provision of recurrent resources than they receive from State and Commonwealth recurrent grants are systemic schools. School systems receive block payments of grants in respect of all the schools in the system and every effort is made to ensure that system aggregate data reported to the Commonwealth Schools Commission are accurate.

However, the nature of systemic arrangements is such as to preclude exact allocations to each school. Services are often provided on a system-wide basis (e.g. remedial and advisory teachers) and systems often consolidate school fees, cope with bad debts, and pay salaries and associated costs, at a central level. In some instances, this has led to inconsistencies between income and expenditure figures as reported by individual schools. These inconsistencies balance out over the system and no system has received in any year more Government grants than it spent in providing recurrent resources.

There remains a very small number of instances since 1976 in which a school has actually received more recurrent funds from Government sources than it spent in a particular year. Such instances have been confined to aboriginal community schools in which substantial enrolment variations from year to year may create surpluses through unexpected increases in enrolments and hence in grants paid on a per capita basis. Adjustments are made in subsequent years to take account of such surpluses.

In my statement to Parliament on 4 June I announced that the Government has accepted the Commonwealth Schools Commission's recommendation that, from 1982 onwards, the total disposable income available to a school from private sources will be considered by the Commission in its assessment of schools or systems for subsidy proposes. By relating income to expenditure, the Commission believes that a better appreciation of a school's overall financial situation can be obtained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Schools Commission's Report for 1982-84 state, at paragraph 12.30, that 38 per cent of non-systemic schools spent less than 75 per cent of their available income, after they had serviced all debts, on the provision of recurrent resources for students; if so, how was the remaining income used and was any of it derived from public sources.
(2) Was any of the financial assistance provided from public sources spent on purposes other than the purposes for which it was granted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The figures quoted in Part (1) appear in the March 1981 Commonwealth Schools Commission 'Report for the Triennium 1982-84,' at paragraph 12.30.

The Commission indicated earlier in the same paragraph that in using the term 'available income' it was referring to income from private sources only. Such income comprises tuition fees, other receipts from students, church or parish grants, and other cash income from private sources for recurrent purposes; grants or donations for capital purposes from parish, parent organisations, building funds or bequests; proceeds from the sale of fixed assets; other capital cash receipts from private sources; and the value of contributed services of teachers and other professional staff.

In addition to meeting the cost of providing recurrent resources over and above those financed from Government grants, and meeting the cost of servicing all of the school debt, the income available to a school from private sources may be used in making provision for future commitments (for example, provision for future building projects), in meeting the cost of capital items not funded from government sources, in the reduction of working overdrafts, and, if the school is a boarding school, in financing any net deficit on the boarding operation.

I would point out that non-government schools are free to apply their income from private sources as they see fit. The Government has, however, accepted the Commonwealth Schools Commission's recommendation that, in future, the total disposable income available to a school from private sources should be considered by the Commission in making assessments for subsidy purposes. It is expected that this will help ensure that decisions regarding the level of Commonwealth funding to be granted to schools and systems will accurately reflect their overall financial situation. However, no non-government school will receive less than the basic Commonwealth grant of 20 per cent of average government schools standard costs.

(2) The accountability requirements attached to grants made by the Commonwealth Government to non-government schools and systems under States Grants (Schools Assistance) Acts have been satisfied in all cases; the funds were applied to the purpose for which they were granted. Accountability for funds granted by State Governments is the responsibility of the State Government concerned.

(3) Has the Committee also expressed its concern that the Hospital will have difficulty in continuing to provide services to veterans and continue its role as a teaching hospital if the theatre complex is not built.
(4) If the proposed cuts in the Public Service are applied to the Repatriation General Hospital, Daw Park, will at least one service currently provided to veterans have to be discontinued.

(5) Further to the Minister's answer to my Question No. 1030, confirming that the operating theatres need to be urgently replaced (Hansard, 26 May 1981, pages 2595-6), can the Minister intimate when these theatres are to be rebuilt and when construction will commence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Specialist Advisory Committee wrote to the Deputy Commissioner, Department of Veterans' Affairs, South Australia, in April 1980 and again in April 1981 expressing concern about the operating theatres at the Repatriation General Hospital, Daw Park.

(2) The letters from the Committee expressed concern about the future of the Hospital if a decision on replacement of the operating theatres is not made soon but did not specifically mention the time lag between a decision to build and completion of the project.

(4) The areas where staff reductions are to occur in the Department of Veterans' Affairs have not yet been decided. The Deputy Commissioner, South Australia, will determine the staff resources to be allocated to particular services, within the ceiling available to him.

(5) I am unable to provide any details about a possible date of commencement of the proposed project. The Government considered a number of proposals for capital expenditure in the context of the current Budget and decided to give further consideration to Repatriation General Hospitals later this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) When a claim for acceptance of a disability as service-related is received, arrangements are made for the medical investigation of the condition claimed and all available relevant medical evidence and service records are obtained.

When investigation of the claim is complete, all the evidence is submitted in the first instance to a Repatriation Board for determination. If the claim is rejected by the Board there exists a right of appeal to the Repatriation Commission. If the appeal is unsuccessful, the applicant may then apply to the Repatriation Review Tribunal for a review of the Commission's decision.

If the applicant elects to appeal or apply for a review he or she may submit additional evidence which, together with all the other evidence, is made available to the determining authority. The applicant may also attend a Tribunal hearing in person and be assisted by an advocate.

Where a claim for acceptance of a disability is successful at Board level, the Board may make a determination on assessment at the same time. If the claim is successful at Commission or Tribunal level, further medical opinion is normally obtained on assessment and the case referred to a Board for determination. If the claimant is dissatisfied with the decision on assessment he or she may apply to the Repatriation Review Tribunal for a review of that decision on assessment within three months of receipt of notification of that decision.

Where a veteran has an accepted disability(ies) and considers that the incapacity has deteriorated since last assessed, an application may be made at any time for increase in the rate of pension. In these circumstances, further medical evidence is sought and the assessment of incapacity reviewed by a Repatriation Board. A right to apply to the Repatriation Review Tribunal for review of a Board determination as above also exists in these circumstances. The applicant may also submit further evidence in the same way as for an entitlement case, and attend a Tribunal hearing in person.
In all cases the applicant is advised of the decision and the reasons for it.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many applications for Allied War veterans' pensions were (a) received and (b) granted in 1980 and during the period 1 January to 9 June 1981.
(2) What was the country of birth and nationality of these applicants or in what armed forces have they served in each war.
(3) How many of the applicants served with (a) regular, (b) irregular or (c) partisan forces, by nationality in each case.
(4) How many partisans, and from what countries, were granted the Allied War veterans' pension during the same period as that referred to in part (1).
(5) How many persons are presently waiting for their pensions to be granted, by nationality, and what is the average waiting period between application and the granting of the pension.
(6) What sum was spent during the period referred to in part (1) on the Allied War veterans' pensions.

(7) What is the situation in relation to the payment of this pension to those who served with (a) the Greek partisans, (b) the Italian army, (c) Yugoslav partisans, (d) Russian soldiers and partisans, (e) Vietnamese, (f) Kampucheans under the Pol Pot regime and (g) Afghanistan freedom fighters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The number of applications in 1980 from Allied veterans for service pension was 1,200. A further 338 applications were received from 1 January to 9 June 1981.
(b) In 1980, 920 Allied veterans were granted service pensions and from 1 January to 9 June 1981 the number was 262.

(2) Statistics are not compiled on service pension applications on the basis of country of birth of applicant. Figures on applications, according to the nationality of the forces with which the applicant served, are provided in the following table for the period 7 February 1980 to 9 June 1981. All applications were in respect of World War II service, except for one Russian World War I case.
7 February 1980 to 9 June 1981Belgium 4 Czechoslovakia 15 Egypt 2 Finland 3 France 14 Greece 338 Italy 5 Netherlands 471 Norway 3 Poland 329 Russia 1 USA 171 USSR 12 Yugoslavia 170

(3) Statistics are not readily available on the nature of the service in the Allied Forces with which applicants served. The Repatriation Act 1920 requires that, to qualify for service pension, Allied veterans must have served in forces which were not 'irregular forces'.
(4) It is not known how many former partisans have been granted service pension.

(5) As at 9 June 1981 the number of applications undetermined was 97. The following table gives the distribution of outstanding applications according to the nationality of the forces with which the applicant served.
Number of applications Country undetermined as at 9 June 1981
Czechoslovakia 2 France 1 Greece 20 Netherlands 26 Poland 16 USA 5 USSR 2 Yugoslavia 25

The average time between application and dispatch of notification for all service pension applications, regardless of whether or not pension is granted, is 49 days. A separate figure for Allied veterans' pensions is not available.

(6) A precise figure for the amount spent on service pensions to Allied veterans is not available but it is estimated that, for the period 7 February 1980 to 9 June 1981, an amount in the vicinity of $2.7m was paid in service pensions to Allied veterans and $1.6m in service pensions to their wives and widows.

(7) The general position with regard to the service pension eligibility of the forces in question is given below. Caution is needed in applying the information in particular cases as eligibility also depends on other factors.

(a) Former Greek partisans are ineligible for pension as they are considered to have comprised 'irregular' Allied Forces. However, Greek partisans who had prior service with the country's regular armed forces between the date of invasion, 28 October 1940, and the date of capitulation, 31 May 1941, may qualify for pension.

(b) Former members of the Italian Army in World War II would be eligible for pension if they served only in the period 8 September 1943 to the end of the European war on 8 May 1945. The Italian armistice with the Allies was signed on 8 September 1943 and from that date some Italian Forces fought with the Allies. Service with the Italian Army prior to 8 September 1943 would disqualify a veteran from pension on the grounds of service with a force which was at war with Australia at the time. Soldiers of the Italian Army in World War I would be eligible for pension, provided they did not also serve in the Italian Forces in World War II prior to 8 September 1943.
(c) Former Yugoslav partisans under Marshal Tito's command are eligible if they served on or after 22 December 1941, the date on which the 1st Proletarian Shock Brigade was proclaimed.
(d) Russian soldiers of World War II are eligible for pension if they served in one of the following periods:
(i) 21 June 1941, the start of the German offensive, to 8 May 1945; and
(ii) 8 August 1945, the date the USSR declared war on Japan, to 14 August 1945, the date the Japanese accepted surrender terms.
Russian soldiers of World War I are also eligible for pension.
The partisan movement in the USSR comprised 'irregular' Allied Forces and, thus, its followers do not qualify for pension.

(e) South Vietnamese servicemen who served during the Vietnam conflict would be eligible, but it is emphasised that, like other Allied veterans, they would have to meet the qualification of ten years Australian residency.
(f)-(g) Applicants for service pension on the basis indicated in part (7) (f)-(g) of the question would be ineligible.
The comments about eligibility in part (7) (b) to (e) are made subject to the veterans meeting all the other legislative criteria.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2663), Mr Campbell asked me a question without notice concerning money alleged to be owing to the Department of Transport by Ansett Transport Industries.

ANSWER.PARA: The following is the answer to the honourable member's question:

Following a review of rentals of domestic and international terminals, Ansett Transport Industries in 1975-76 took writs out of the High Court and the Supreme Court of Victoria challenging the validity of the resulting increases.
The Company has since made regular but partial payments 'without prejudice' to its legal position. Rental arrears did not at any stage approach $8m.

The matter has now been resolved and Ansett's rentals for terminals throughout Australia are fully paid at the rates currently fixed by my Department. These, of course, reflect the Government's policy of full cost recovery of airport terminals.

While in the past lease agreements did not provide for payment of interest on arrears of rentals, this matter has now been rectified following consultations with the industry in the Aviation Industry Advisory Council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 February 1981 (Hansard, page 233), the honourable member for Barton asked me a question without notice about the effect on Commonwealth taxation revenue of State and local government charges and imposts. The question was raised in the context of reports that the Sydney City Council was contemplating some form of levy, to be borne by developers, the proceeds of which would go to welfare housing. I undertook to see if I could obtain an assessment of the revenue effect.

ANSWER.PARA: As a matter of strict nomenclature, I note that where State and local government charges and imposts are properly paid by a business as business outgoings, and so are deductible under Section 51 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the payments are costs which are netted off gross income to arrive at assessable income. It is only in respect of concessions, such as the investment allowance or the 20 per cent loading on depreciation rates, that in the strict sense revenue costs or losses on any level of profits can be said to occur.

Nevertheless, State charges and imposts can and do affect Commonwealth revenue which would, obviously, be much higher, other things being equal, if those charges and imposts did not have to be paid and charged as business costs.

However to measure the effect is not a simple matter because the available data on State and local government charges and imposts are not readily dissectable between payments by businesses and payments by private persons or exempt bodies. As well, some charges and imposts borne by private persons (private rates for example) can attract an income tax rebate where the taxpayer's total concessional expenditure exceeds $1590.

Against that background, and as a broad indicator only, I note that, in 1978-79, State and local governments collected $425 million by way of 'business' taxes (liquor taxes, road taxes, fire brigade contributions and business franchises); $1,529 million by way of pay-roll tax; and $3,296 million by way of other taxes borne by households and by businesses. The whole of the 'business' taxes, most of the pay-roll tax and a substantial proportion of the other taxes would be tax deductible. The additional revenue that would have resulted if those amounts had not been allowed as outgoings properly deductible under Section 51 (1) would probably have been in excess of $1,000m. I note also that State governments receive certain royalty payments from businesses. Along with land rent, these amounted to about $305m in 1978-79. There would be some further impact on Commonwealth revenues from that.
